title: Assessing and Developing the Role of Independent Monitoring by Civil Society to Support Good Governance in the Fisheries Sector in Sri Lanka
description: The project aims to assess the potential role of independent monitoring of fisheries law enforcement by civil society in support of good governance in the fisheries sector in Sri Lanka. If a suitable model can be developed then the participating organisations will look at how the model could be expanded and developed in the future.
sector-text: Strengthening Civil Society

title: Independent Monitoring of Forest Law Enforcement and Governance (IM-FLEG) in Support of FLEGT VPAs in the Congo Basin
description: The project is managed by Forests Monitor, REM's project partner. This project aims to: 1) Contribute to transparency and governance improvement in the Congo Basin forest sector in the context of the FLEGT process implementation. 2) Support the implementation of IM-FLEG in Republic of Congo by Civil Society. 3) Increase Congo Basin Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) capacity to participate in the negotiation or implementation of FLEGT VPAs through the implementation of IM-FLEG mechanisms.
funding_organisations: ;Department for International Development (DFID);European Commission - European Development Fund

sector-text: Strengthening Civil Society;Forestry Policy and Administrative Management

title: Independent Monitoring of Forest Law Enforcement and Governance (IM-FLEG) in the Democratic Republic of Congo
description: The project, led by UK based NGO REM, provides an independent view of forest logging practices in the DRC and the legal and administrative framework to regulate them. Strengthening forest governance is part of the FLEGT Program discussions between DRC and the European Union, to combat illegal logging of tropical forests. The Congolese state has, with this project, engaged in a process designed to strengthen its law enforcement in order to guarantee the legality of the timber exported to the European market place. Our main objective is to contribute to the realization of the principles of good governance in forestry activities and provide support to the improvement of forest law enforcement. We do this by: 1) supporting the development of a law enforcement strategy and development of procedures within the forest ministry; 2) observing the application of forest law enforcement procedures; 3) observing the follow-up of forest exploitation illegalities and sanctions by the ministry; 4) ensuring publication of information relating to forest exploitation and governance; 5) ensuring the sustainability of independent monitoring through the participation of civil society.
funding_organisations: ;European Commission - European Development Fund - Programme d'appui a la gouvernance
sector-text: Strengthening Civil Society;Forestry policy and administrative management

title: Liberia Capacity Building for Independent Monitoring of Forest Law Enforcement and Governance (IM-FLEG)
description: The objectives of the project are: 1. To support training of the Forest Development Authority, Government of Liberia senior staff, civil society and private organisations on Independent Monitoring; 2. To develop a common vision for the Independent Monitoring in Liberia; 3. To develop a long term Independent Monitoring strategy adapted to Liberia; 4. Monitoring and evaluation framework developed.
sector-text: Strengthening civil society;Government and civil society, general

title: Rwanda Eastern Province Womens Literacy Project
description: The project will build the capacity of 7 civil society networks with a national reach to deliver Functional Adult Literacy (FAL) programmes to 5,600 adult learners (80% women) in the districts of Nyagatare, Gatsibo, Kayonza, Rwamagana, Ngoma, Kirehe and Bugesera in Eastern province of Rwanda over a period of 3 years (July 2011 - June 2014).;Impact: Increased adult literacy levels through equitable access to appropriate learning and life skills programmes by 2015. Outcome: Women in the 7 districts of Eastern province of Rwanda have access to Functional Adult Literacy programmes.;The project will target 5,972 beneficiaries. They comprise 140 facilitators (30% women) and 28 staff from 7 civil society organisations with a national coverage, 7 education officers & 95 social affairs officers, 7 district women leaders & 95 women?s sector council leaders, as well as 5,600 FAL trainees (80% women). FAL classes will mainly comprise youth aged 18-35 (46%) and adults aged 35-65 (50%).
sector-text: Functional Adult Literacy

title: Strengthening Livelihoods in the Dry Zone of Myanmar
description: The purpose of the project is to contribute to the reduced poverty of 12,600 people within 15 villages of Pakokku Township through (1) Increased skills for 1,250 people in food processing, (2) 25 new viable food based processing industries, (3) increased local capacity for value chain development in rural food processing and (4) improved capacity of local stakeholders to promote and raise awareness of key cross-cutting issues including gender, HIV/AIDS, DRR and environment. ;Goal: To contribute towards MDG 1 in Myanmar. Purpose: Contribute to reduced poverty within 15 villages of Pakokku Township through enhancing the capacity of 1,500 households in food processing.;15 villages of Pakokku Township 1,250 Landless casual labourer households (80% female headed); 350 Producer households (80 % female headed); 25 SHG & 10 HLPG; Attendees (landless households, seasonal migrant workers, jobless / unemployed youth, senior high school students) of gender sensitisation, HIV/AIDS awareness, DRR mitigation and environmental protection training. 7,200 beneficiaries from 1,500 HH (4.8 per HH); 5,400 attendees of trainings (2,700 women, 1,620 men & 1,080 children). Total of 12,600 direct beneficiaries

title: Nâ€™Guidgue Weoga Kuisse
description: The Nâ€™Guidgue Weoga Kuisse Project, which means, â€œFight against desertificationâ€ù in the local language, is designed to counteract increasing desertification by improving water and soil conservation measures, in addition to soil fertility and reforestation.;The project will work with 31,235 farmers in 30 villages in the Province of Bazega, in South Eastern Burkina Faso, near the town of Kombisiri. About150 model farmers will be trained as local trainers, who will then teach others how to protect and manage their natural resources through methods like promoting hedgerows, naturally assisted regeneration and the cutting and conservation of animal fodder. Techniques to improve soil fertility such as scarifying the land, half-moons, stone cordon dykes, â€œzaiâ€ù fertilizer holes, the treatment of ravines, and soil enrichment using leguminous mucuna will be applied to 2,535 acres (1,026 hectares) of degraded or unused land. This land will then be available for agriculture and pasture. In addition, ADRA will help build 900 compost pits, plant 100,000 trees, and 8 small dams will be constructed for the animals to drink from. The project is further expected to develop a community approach to natural resource management by developing and implementing communal environmental action plans, setting up 30 natural resource management committees at the village level and produce a manual on use of green manure. The project will also promote and support the construction of 6000 improved wood-fuel efficient stoves.
recipient-country: The project will work with 31,235 farmers in 30 villages in the Province of Bazega, in South Eastern Burkina Faso, near the town of Kombisiri.
sector-text: Climate Change Adaptation

title: AWMRE Migrant Women Project
description: ADRA is helping exploited Burmese refugee and migrant women in Thailand, to receive fair wages, to access health services and enroll their children in schools. Supported by DfiD, ADRA is empowering these vulnerable communities to know and access their rights.;ADRA is working with 4 grass roots Burmese community based organisations (CBO), helping them to improve services and advocate for the rights of vulnerable Burmese refugees and migrants and their children.
recipient-country: Mae Sot is a town in western Thailand that shares a border with Myanmar to the west.
sector-text: Advocacy

title: Improved Maternal Health Care Services for Women of Childbearing Age in Gokwe, North Province, Zimbabwe
description: The project aims to improve maternal health care services for 7,500 women of childbearing age in 3 wards of Gokwe North. The intervention will centre on a) The improvement of 4 health facilities; b) Improved maternal health service delivery by health care providers; c) Increased awareness and utilisation amongst women of maternal health services in targeted clinics and d) Increased awareness on health risks and services amongst communities. The project strategy is comprised of two interlinked components: firstly activities focusing on improving the availability and quality of maternal health services and secondly those aimed at increasing the demand and utilisation of the same services. Target Beneficiaries: The project will target 7,500 women of child-bearing age (mothers, girls aged 15 â€“ 17), pregnant women 15-49, 6,000 married men, 1,685 school boys (aged 11-17), 1,200 school girls (aged 11-14), 5 health staff from district hospital, 2 district pharmacists, 12 health clinic staff, 40 VHWs, 10 community leaders, 21 WDC members, 12,600 community health club members, 1,100 school health clubs, 322 TOTâ€™s, 28 water pump committee members and 30 ambulance committee members
sector-text: Maternal Health

title: Research, advocacy and communications to make the case for aid transparency
description: Advocacy and research to promote the value of transparency and open information, including participation at relevant conferences and events, resource sharing and advocacy strategy building with partner organisations, stakeholder mapping and a strong advocacy strategy for broader membership of the International Aid Transparency Initiative

title: Nepal country pilot to promote the value of transparent accessible data to underpin social accountability and aid effectiveness
description: A pilot study in Nepal to provide detailed data on all flows, build expertise for accessing and using aid information, support organisations to build tools and applications to increase accessibility of information. Support will also be given to organisations to disseminate information to citizens and establish feedback loops to governments and donors.

title: aidinfo phase 2
description: The aidinfo programme works to reduce poverty by empowering citizens to make better use of money spent on poverty reduction. By increasing access to information about resources for poverty reduction, it is hoped that ownership, accountability, effectiveness and efficiency of aid will be increased, improving the overall impact of aid and accelerating poverty reduction. Our work centres on research and advocacy on the value of transparency, support to the International Aid Transparency Initiative and supporting the users of aid information. This is the second phase of the aidinfo programme.

title: Supporting children, parents, teachers and police to reduce violence in schools
description: The project will reduce violence in and around schools by empowering community groups of parents and children living in violent and marginalized communities in Guayaquil with the capacity to engage more effectively directly with teachers and the police and raising awareness of police, teachers, government and NGO child right stakeholders of the incidence and the need to reduce violence in and around schools and to implement a joint action plan to this purpose, working with the community groups. This will lead to improved school attendance, performance and reduced drop out rates among the children attending these schools, leading to sustainable poverty reduction in the long-term.

title: DR-Haiti
description: Climate change and sustainable agriculture (1) The projectâ€™s objective is to promote sustainable agricultural practice and environmental protection to mitigate the effects of climate change in order to guarantee food security and risk adaptation. The main axes of work are food security, environmental protection, natural resource management (in particular water resources), and institutional strengthening of partner and community-based organisations. Two development workers are supporting the local partner organisation through (i) sustainable agricultural production and use of natural resources through agro-forestry and (ii) crop diversification and introduction of small livestock emphasising a balanced diet and proper use of food products in terms of food and nutrition security. The project is reaching 1,800 direct and 9,000 indirect beneficiaries in the northern border region of the Dominican Republic. Food Security: Rehabilitation of agricultural productivity of watersheds in central and north-eastern Haiti in support of gardening and fruit production(2) This project focuses on strengthening of the capacities of community-based organisations and farmersâ€™ associations of the departments of central and north-east Haiti, contributing to the fight against poverty and food and nutrition insecurity. The project also aims to improve environmental protection and management of natural resources, in order to enhance the productivity and sustainable development of the target communities. The empowerment of women and farmers is also a key part of the project as well as advocacy to increase investment in Haitian agriculture and production. The expected immediate effects of the project include: i) environmental, with an increase in hectares of agricultural land protected or saved from erosion and degradation, and volume of water retained and controlled for agricultural use; ii) production, with an expected increase of agricultural assets and productive units through more efficient management oriented towards local consumption and income generation; iii) marketing and trade, to increase the income level of families through processing activities and joint commercial initiatives; iv) organisational, through improved internal operating conditions of farmersâ€™ associations and community-based organisations, and more effective participation in processes and strategies to promote local food security. The project is reaching 500 direct and 2,500 indirect beneficiaries in the communities of Gens de Nantes, Lamine and Ouanaminthe (north-east Haiti). Strengthening the disaster risk management capacities of Caritas Haiti(3) The project aims to strengthen the coordination, the technical and the organisational capacities of the Disaster Risk Management Unit of Caritas Haiti National Office and to mainstream disaster risk reduction institutionally and on all levels. It is expected that at the end of the project, Caritas Haiti National Office has been institutionally strengthened in development, planning, monitoring and evaluation of disaster risk reduction programmes and projects at the national, regional and local level, in order to better address the problems and needs of their beneficiaries. This will lead to improved coordination of disaster mitigation programmes in particular at the community level, and in general a raised profile at the national and international level in terms of disaster risk management. Key components of institutional strengthening include the definition and structuring of rapid response mechanisms for emergency response, design of contingency plans for all three levels, the establishment of an emergency fund through development of projects linked to sustainable and resilient livelihood and the pre-positioning of emergency supplies and storage of non-food products as part of a preparedness strategy. Strengthening the management capacity of agricultural producers in the border communities of the province of ElÃ_as PiÃ±a (Dominican Republic) and the department of Plateau Central (Haiti)(4) This project will contribute to the improvement of living conditions of the population in the province of ElÃ_as PiÃ±a and the department Plateau Central, through improved conditions and coverage for exchange and collaboration between non-state actors and local authorities of ElÃ_as PiÃ±a and Plateau Central in issues of common cross-border interest, such as agricultural production and trade, culture and environment. The expected results are: i) the creation and management of an office for marketing of agricultural production in the Municipality of Comendador (province ElÃ_as PiÃ±a), in order to reinforce the structure and channels of local and bi-national trade and marketing; ii) creation and management of a cross-border Museum for Culture and Environment, to promote the development of environmental and cultural services within the framework of a cross-border plan for sustainable eco-tourism; iii) promotion of a process of strengthening capacities for governance and local management of municipal authorities, in order to enhance and construct a bi-national dialogue. The project is reaching out to 555 direct and 28,700 indirect beneficiaries in the communities of ElÃ_as PiÃ±a and Plateau Central in the southern Dominican-Haitian border. Building citizenship(5) This project will strengthen the capacity of non-state actors and local authorities in the provinces of Independencia and ElÃ_as PiÃ±a. The overall goal is to strengthen the coordination between local authorities and civil society organisations regarding the planning of local development and the development of municipal policies that respond to the needs of the population of 23 municipalities of the southern border provinces of DR and Haiti. Specifically, it seeks greater coordination between Dominican and Haitian border municipalities, and increased participation and coordination between civil society and local authorities for inclusive and sustainable local development. The project is supporting about 2,300 direct beneficiaries and approximately 26,000 indirect beneficiaries. Building together local governance based on participation and planning(6) This project aims to contribute to the strengthening of local governance in both the Dominican Republic and Haiti through the implementation of citizen participation spaces established within the framework of the Municipal Law 176-07 in the Dominican Republic and promoting partnerships between municipalities on the Haitian side and cross-border. The specific objective is to strengthen the capacity of non-state actors and local authorities in terms of the implementation of public policies, particularly the mechanisms of citizen participation, gender equity and planning established in the Law 176-07, in favour of local development. It also aims to strengthen the Haitian Federation of Municipalities as an ideal space to promote governance and reconstruction of Haiti and further strengthening the ties between the two nations. Regarding civil society, with which Progressio assume a key role in the implementation of the action, it is foreseen to strengthen public participation, enhancing the knowledge of citizens about their rights, duties and participation mechanisms, especially the Municipal Law 176-07 and promoting advocacy for its compliance. In addition, the project will strengthen the knowledge and resources of local authorities to fulfil their duties and thus create the conditions to plan and reach a consensus for municipal actions and policies that are inclusive for the welfare of all. Handicrafts of the Border: promoting employment and social cohesion in ElÃ_as PiÃ±a (Dominican Republic) and Plateau Central (Haiti)(7) The overall objective of this project is to increase social cohesion between local authorities and Dominican and Haitian civil society in the border towns of Elias PiÃ±a (Dominican Republic) and Plateau Central (Haiti) by implementing joint local development actions that lead to a public-private partnership for job creation in the local and bi-national handicrafts sector. The project represents a set of solutions in technical, economic, social and cultural terms intended to promote the development of the handicraft sector on both sides of the border. The expected outcomes are: i) artisans of the municipalities of ElÃ_as PiÃ±a and Plateau Central improve technical and business management skills through the implementation of municipal spaces for technical training and craft production; ii) the Municipal Association of Artisans and its network on provincial level interact with local authorities and bi-national coordination and consultation bodies, in order to constitute territorial agreements for the sector; iii) the provincial network of the Municipal Association of Artisans, in coordination with public and private stakeholders, is engaged in support and promotion of handicrafts. Strengthening the capacity of the state and civil society to promote, manage and coordinate actions to prevent, detect, address and penalise violence against women(8) The aim of this project is to accompany local actors from the border area to prevent violence against women. This is a follow-up project that monitors the processes that began in May 2011 with the project 'Gender-based violence prevention and response to the needs of women in the border between Haiti and Dominican Republicâ€ù and the project â€œPrevention and attention of violence against women in the border provincesâ€ù implemented during 2012 by Progressio and co-funded by UNFPA and UN Women. The project â€œPrevention and attention of violence against womenâ€ù seeks to ensure that local organizations and authorities (municipalities, prosecutors, medical centres etc) in the provinces of DajabÃ_n, ElÃ_as PiÃ±a, Independencia, Pedernales, Santiago and Monte Cristi coordinate with each other to carry out action plans that are viable and specific for the prevention and attention of violence against women in their provinces. In the current phase, Progressioâ€™s development worker is accompanying and monitoring these organisations and institutions in order to consolidate joint initiatives of action plans for each province, to consolidate and strengthen the Management Committees formed in 2012 and to support awareness-raising and advocacy activities. Rebuilding a new and all-inclusive Haiti: strengthening Haitian civil society in rebuilding their country(9) The overall project goal is to strengthen Haitian civil society in their efforts to build a new Haiti which is socially inclusive and transparent. This project responds to the demands of civil society after the Haitian earthquake in January 2010, particularly over the lack of transparency and accountability on reconstruction plans and policies and aid distribution, and the lack of effective civil society participation in policy-making on reconstruction and development of Haiti. This new Haiti aims to break with the past where decisions were made without citizen participation and coordination, and where centralisation still limits regional and local development and rights are poorly respected. The specific objective of the project is to track and analyse the actions taken in the framework of the countryâ€™s reconstruction through the Observatory of Public Policy and International Cooperation and divulge objective and reliable data on international cooperation, public policies and the situation of Haitians, especially the most vulnerable sectors of the population, to Haitian civil society, national and international stakeholders. Added to this, internationally, Progressio works to influence decision-makers in the UK and Europe on the reconstruction of Haiti and raise public awareness of the problems facing the country. Advocacy and communication, with an emphasis on public policy related to the strengthening of the Dominican-Haitian relations(10) This project aims to strengthen the capacities in advocacy and communication of the local partner Centro BonÃ_ and the processes of national and bi-national platforms created between networks and coalitions working with the institution, in order to contribute to the fight against poverty and social exclusion. This includes strengthening communication and media strategies, which include production of press notes and audiovisual broadcasting material for different media and digital networks and monitoring and media analysis. The development worker will also support the different processes led by Centro BonÃ_ to strengthen Dominican-Haitian relations, both on the political and institutional level as well as on the grassroots level. Institutional strengthening, with emphasis on design and project management, of Funcar-Centro Puente in DajabÃ_n(11) This project aims to strengthen the capacities of the staff of the local organization Funcar-Centro Puente on both sides of the northern border, and local grassroots organizations they work with, in particular womenâ€™s associations, in design, planning and implementation of sustainable initiatives, with special emphasis on empowerment and income-generating activities for rural women. The development worker will also provide support on gender equality issues, communication and advocacy. It is expected that at the end of the project the organisation has been supported in the development of methodological guidelines and tools for assessment, monitoring and evaluation, allowing a better systematisation of results, impacts and lessons learned within implemented projects. The development worker will also contribute to the intercultural and bi-national approach promoted within the partner organisation and beneficiary grassroots organisations on both sides of the border. Institutional strengthening and capacity building for the identification and implementation of an agroforestry school at the Centre JesÃºs Peregrino in San Pedro de Macoris, Dominican Republic(12) This project will assist the Centre JesÃºs Peregrino to set up an agroforestry school as part of the institutional strategy of the Centre. The development worker will develop in collaboration with the local staff the necessary tools for soil studies, organisational assessments directed to the beneficiary grassroots organisations, as well as monitoring and evaluation of activities. The development worker will also provide capacity building for the technical team of the Centre in the implementation of an agroforestry training school and strengthening of their skills in agroforestry and agro-ecological production.

title: Yemen
description: Enhancing civil society organizationsâ€™ capacity to support civic activism and advocate for effective local governance and womenâ€™s political participation(1) The aim of the project is to enable poor and marginalised people, especially women, to have greater influence on decisions and policies which affect their lives in order to reduce their poverty. The Yemeni constitution guarantees equality in rights and obligations for both men and women, including the right of political participation and participation in decision-making. Nevertheless, womenâ€™s political rights and participation in decision-making processes are yet to be realized. The project will build a solid platform of local people â€“ poor, marginalized, women â€“ to be able to influence government plans and policies. Project activities will include capacity building of civil society organisations, particularly in relation to advocacy campaigns; civic education and awareness-raising; building citizensâ€™ networks; and promoting effective governance by supporting citizen involvement in policy and planning processes. This will improve the level of representation of people who are poor and marginalised by civil society organisations engaging with national government. Progressio will also address key issues around transparency, accountability and responsiveness of local and national governments so as to promote the voices of poor and marginalised people, especially women. Combating discrimination against women in Hodeida(2) The purpose of the project is to increase the capacity of women particularly those who are poor and vulnerable to achieve equality within Yemeni institutions and society. This achieved by removing barriers to access by women to local authority and government line ministry services, through increasing the level of womenâ€™s participation in local decision-making processes. The project will also strengthen institutional processes within the police force and judiciary in favour of women and girls in cases of domestic abuse and legal redress. By the end of the project, the social attitudes condoning customs which breach the rights of women and girls will have been challenged, hence increasing womenâ€™s participation in political and legal institutions. The primary beneficiaries of this project will be women, girls and marginalised communities. Activities include workshops and meetings to create awareness about the rights of women, media campaigns and dialogues with men to challenge attitudes and norms that marginalise women in society. Strengthening the capacity of civil society organisations in tackling HIV and AIDS in Yemen(3) This project aims to reduce the widespread stigma and discrimination experienced by people living with HIV in Yemen. Progressio provides technical support through Development Workers to build the capacity of CSOs and faith groups to be able to create awareness about HIV and AIDS, provide support to people living with HIV, and reduce stigma and gender discrimination. Widespread HIV/AIDS awareness has been created through training of peer educators, while stigma and discrimination has been reduced through mobilization and training of faith leaders. The project has also strengthened associations with people living with HIV and trained various groups including health workers, journalists, refugees, fishermen, sex workers and other vulnerable groups in HIV/AIDS prevention and awareness. The beneficiaries are vulnerable populations including the youth, fishermen, refugees, women and sex workers. Other beneficiaries include local NGOs, people living with HIV and their associations, faith leaders and health workers. Communicating water awareness(4) This project aims to improve the quality of life of poor and marginalised people through increased equitable and sustainable management of natural resources, especially in the light of climate change and resource scarcity. The objectives of the project include: 1: To promote sustainable management of water resources for the benefit of poor and marginalised people in Hodeida Governorate. 2: To develop awareness and advocacy capacity of local councils and the National Water Resources Authority and to link them with regional and national networks to address climate change, resource scarcity and degradation, and water rights; thereby ensuring that beneficiary communities in Hodeida Governorate, especially the poor and marginalized, have sustainable and equitable access to natural resources.
implementing_organisations: ;Hodeida Civil Society Forum ;Aden Civil Society Network for Development ;Al-Wadian Association;Al-Tawasal Association;Ministry of Local Administration;CSO Forum Hodeida;Women Committee;Reach Out Foundation ;Abu Musa Al Ashary Charitable Association ;Interaction in Development;Womenâ€™s Association for Sustainable Development ;National Water Resources Authority (in Sanaâ€™a with a branch in Hodeida);Yemeni Society for Protection of the Environment (local NGO based in Hodeida);Wadi Zabid Irrigation Council;Progressio

title: Zimbabwe
description: Action for better governance: Realising the common good(1) The project seeks to empower poor and marginalised people especially women to have a greater influence on decisions and policies that affect their lives. This aim is to be achieved through building the capacity of faith groups, leaders and communities to promote democratic participation and influence local and national government plans and policies. Activities include: training of trainers, training of CCJP diocesan and parish members and volunteers, training of Bishops and other church leaders to advocate effectively on key governance issues, undertaking awareness raising and capacity building activities for church members within the diocesan parishes and small Christian community structures, and supporting the establishment of faith/secular partnerships. Hear our voice! Speaking for HIV services and care support(2) he project aims to reduce stigma and discrimination and increase access to HIV care, support and prevention among poor and at-risk groups, specifically employees, truck drivers, prisoners and children vulnerable to HIV and AIDS. The specific objectives include: â€¢ To increase HIV knowledge, reduce stigma and discrimination and provide care and support to groups vulnerable to HIV, including inmates, prison officers and long-distance truck drivers; â€¢ To increase the voice, influence and capacity of people living with HIV, vulnerable groups and their representative organisations to represent their rights and improve service delivery and policies that affect their lives; â€¢ To increase access to prevention and care services, and reduce levels of stigma and discrimination by promoting the development and implementation of workplace policies and programmes in small/informal companies and in the transport sector; and â€¢ To increase the capacity of local implementing partners to improve their response to the needs of PLHIV and those most vulnerable to HIV. 11,520 people are going to benefit directly and 30, 000 people are to benefit indirectly. Mitigating Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV) and HIV and AIDS(3) The project aims to strengthen the capacity of faith-based organizations and their leadership to engage more proactively in the fight against sexual and gender-based violence and HIV and AIDS in Zimbabwe. Activities include capacity building of NFBCZ as an organisation undertaking HIV&AIDS-related interventions among faith communities; production of documents and training manuals; training of local church leaders and congregants at the community level on both SGBV and HIV/AIDS; psychosocial and counselling support programmes for victims of gender violence; documentation and information dissemination on gender-based violence from a faith perspective. The project is directly benefiting 160 church leaders and 320 provincial coordinators. Indirect beneficiaries include approximately 1,000,000 church goers as a result of their leadership becoming clearer and more committed in dealing with SGBV and HIV in church. Enhancing livelihoods and food security among rural communities in Zimbabwe(4) he project seeks to improve the quality of life of poor and marginalised people in Zimbabwe through more equitable and more sustainable management of natural resources especially in the light of climate change and resource scarcity. The main project activities include: â€¢ Promoting the adoption of soil and water conservation farming techniques by communal farmers â€¢ Promoting the use of alternative energy sources amongst communities â€¢ Setting up Environment Action Groups and training the groups on the management of natural resources â€¢ Training Environment Africa field officers on agro-ecology, marketing and business development, and lobbying and advocacy â€¢ Advocacy - producing policy briefs, agro-ecology manuals and publications on agro-ecology and product development Supporting visual and hearing impaired persons in Zimbabwe(5) The aim of this project is to contribute towards the reduction of new HIV infections among disabled people in Zimbabwe by providing support to The HIV and AIDS Management Service Organisation (THAMASO) and the Disability HIV and AIDS Trust (DHAT) in the production and distribution of HIV and AIDS information for visual and hearing impaired persons. The main activities include production and distribution of HIV and AIDS information in Braille and sign language; and production of training manuals, policy monographs and briefs. The project will also strengthen the capacity of THAMASO and DHAT to advocate for the rights of disabled persons among duty bearers that include relevant government departments, village heads, chiefs and traditional healers with regard to HIV and AIDS information, prevention, treatment and care. This project is expected to benefit directly 650 visual and hearing impaired persons and approximately 4,000 family members from Hwange and Harare districts in Zimbabwe

title: Timor-Leste
description: Inclusive local governance(1) The purpose of this project is to strengthen civil society organizations at the national, district, and local level to engage with government units in light of the national governmentâ€™s plan to decentralize, or devolve power to the local levels. Beneficiaries include one national-level organization, six district NGO networks, and local members. Activities include training and mentoring in organizational development, budgeting, work planning, and strategic planning. Raising womenâ€™s voices(2) This projects works with the National Womenâ€™s network and one district womenâ€™s organization which aim to support women engaged in the political process, actively implement laws supporting and protecting women, and support womenâ€™s livelihoods. Beneficiaries are poor women in Oecusse and womenâ€™s civil society organizations. Strengthening capacity of pro-poor organizations(3) This project works to strengthen the capacities of several national-level civil society organizations in the areas of organizational development, strategic planning, board development, and general planning. Beneficiaries are the partner CSOs and their target communities. Building accountancy capacity to increase effectiveness(4) A major concern, effecting both CSOs and government agencies, is a lack of accountancy capacity. This project aims to support a range or CSOs in basic accountancy, book keeping, financial reporting, and the use of finance software. Beneficiaries are CSOs at the national and district levels. HIV-AIDS support(5) This project aims to support governmental and nongovernmental organizations in their work on HIV/AIDs education and organizational development. It includes training and advising in organizational development as well as in content-oriented HIV education and prevention. Primary beneficiaries are persons living with HIV and at-risk groups. Institutional Capacity Development - Caritas(6) The purpose of this project is to assist the Roman Catholic Diocese of Maliana in the development of a Caritas organization that will focus on justice, livelihoods, and peace-building. The beneficiaries are the women and marginalized citizens of this rural area.

title: Somaliland
description: Strengthening the capacity of civil society organisations (CSOs) to promote democracy and good governance in Somaliland (NW Somalia). The beneficiaries of the project are women, youth and the local authorities(1) The overall objective of the project is to strengthen the capacity of civil society organizations (CSOs) to promote democracy and good governance in Somaliland (NW Somalia). The beneficiaries of the project are women, youth and the local authorities. The activities include: â€¢ training of trainers for key CSOs on human rights, voter education, and conflict resolution and peace-building â€¢ lobbying and advocating for enactment of relevant legislation â€¢ development and implementation of relevant policies to address concerns of marginalised groups â€¢ awareness raising on human rights, gender, democracy, good governance, and civic education â€¢ monitoring and documentation of civic and human rights violations â€¢ dialogue with key stakeholders and community members on human rights violations â€¢ capacity building of youth in civic participation â€¢ capacity building support for local government authorities on resource mobilization, finance, administration and documentation â€¢ election observation and preparation of post-election assessment report. Promoting equitable representation of women in decision-making(2) The overall objective of the project is to advocate for the adoption of a womenâ€™s quota in political governance in Somaliland. The project beneficiaries are the political parties, cabinet ministers, Parliament, local and international non-governmental organizations working in Somaliland, the media, Somalia/Somaliland development partners (donors), and women caucuses in all districts. The project activities include: â€¢ training of women candidates with essential skills in campaign management, community mobilization, public speaking and conflict management â€¢ dialogue meetings with parliamentarians, political associations, political parties, National Election Commission, donors and the cabinet â€¢ village outreach awareness raising through the regional womenâ€™s caucus workshops, mass media and sensitization meetings â€¢ sensitization meetings with the religious and traditional leaders at their centres, including Mosques â€¢ workshops for regional level womenâ€™s pressure groups on effective advocacy. Integrated Prevention, Treatment, Care and Support (IPTCS) for HIV and AIDS in Somaliland(3) The general objective of the project is to contain and reduce the HIV epidemic in Somaliland. The target beneficiaries include people living with HIV and AIDS, people who are willing to donate their blood, people who visit the IPTCS centres for HIV counselling and testing, IPTCS staff, and the general population who participated in World AIDS Day and other activities. The activities included anti-retroviral therapy and treatment of opportunistic infections, treatment of sexually transmitted diseases, counselling and testing, blood safety, universal precautions, support for people living with HIV in terms of psychosocial aspects and awareness raising, laboratory services, prevention of mother to child transmission, improving the health infrastructure in all the sites, and staff training in areas of support, prevention, care and treatment. Access to justice(4) The objective of this project is to support the UNDPâ€™s Access to Justice Project by assisting the Somaliland Women Lawyers Association (SWLA) to develop a legal empowerment and womenâ€™s justice training programme that is systematic, addresses the legal training needs of SWLAâ€™s own members, and is relevant to the needs and interests of Somaliland civil society organisations. Activities include: â€¢ designing and conduct of a rapid training assessment of SWLA membersâ€™ selected core legal trainers â€¢ designing a training course that focuses on both content/substance and methods/approaches â€¢ developing a training guide â€¢ conduct of training for SWLAâ€™s core legal training team â€¢ assisting SWLA in designing and analysing the quick survey on CSOsâ€™ legal training and interests â€¢ designing a basic course on legal empowerment for communities and CSOs, including accompanying training materials â€¢ co-facilitate the first pilot training on legal empowerment and womenâ€™s justice for region-based CSOs â€¢ review the basic course on legal empowerment for communities and CSOs and revise accordingly together with SWLAâ€™s legal trainers. International Election Observation in Somaliland 2012(5) To lead and coordinate a team of International Election Observers (IEOs) for local elections in Somaliland in 2012. The team will observe campaigning and electoral preparations, implement an observation programme on election day, and continue to engage with stakeholders in the period immediately following the election. Following on from the election observation, a report on the learning points from the election will be published, in order to further inform and support the democratisation process in Somaliland.

title: Faulu Kenya Limited
description: Faulu Kenya is one of the largest Non Bank Financial Institutions (NBFI) in Kenya. Initially Faulu Kenya focused on micro enterprise lending in Mathare slums of Nairobi. However, over the last 17 years, as lending methodologies and systems were improved, Faulu Kenya grew to become a company with 31 branches and a presence in most districts of Kenya. The objective of this project is to support Faulu Kenya as it transforms from a credit only institution to a regulated deposit taking institution. This transformation is characterized both by the development of a broader product offering as well as by the formalization of the shareholding structure and regulatory framework the institution adheres to. The addition of liability products will provide secure savings to clients as well as more control over funding and asset liability management for the institution. The shareholding structure will evolve, as the original NGO founder will be reduced from a majority owner to a minority shareholder, bringing a more commercial ownership and governance structure to match the more formal role Faulu Kenya will play in the financial sector. The proposed project consists of local currency debt (up to KSH 450 million, USD6 million equivalent) with warrants (for up to a 19.9% equity stake approximately equivalent to KSH 200 million or USD 2.7 million on a fully diluted basis).
sector-text: Commercial Banking - Microfinance and Small Business;

title: KIMP (Kenya Multimedia ICT Park)
description: The project provides advisory support to the government of Kenya in establishing a multimedia ICT (information and communication technology) park that will be critical to achievement of the country?s Vision 2030 objectives. In addition to its multimedia components, the park will include multi-use facilities such as office blocks, industrial parks, recreational facilities, a golf course, shopping malls, hotels and restaurants, and residential houses, among other facilities and amenities. Project objectives include completion of four major reports by the end of the first year, and one successful bid concluded by two years from implementation start date. Establishment of the multimedia ICT park is expected to trigger the growth of such knowledge-based industries as BPO (business process outsourcing) services, software and hardware development, and the development and packaging of multimedia local content, among others, and to improve the productivity and competitiveness of private sector enterprises in Kenya.

title: The Education Bridge
description: The Education Bridge will bridge the gap between educational policy and the reality as experienced by vulnerable children in three districts of Ghanaâ€™s UER.;The objectives of The Education Bridge are to: (1) Progress towards universal provision and attainment of primary education in the 3 operational areas (2) Empower the schools, communities and children in the three areas, to contribute to bringing about the achievement of universal education (3) Ensure parents and care givers show an understanding of the education services available, and a demonstrable commitment to their children's education (4) Ensure the GES School Management Committee (SMC) model becomes practically applied in the three operational areas (5) Ensure community education committees are proactive in encouraging provision and uptake of education (6) Ensure schools adopt and replicate the AfriKids child rights club model to help motivate enrolment and retention of pupils (7) Ensure communities adopt the AfriKids community education promotion and advocacy model to help ensure enrolment and retention of pupils in school
sector-text: The Education Bridgeâ€™s ultimate purpose is to ensure that children are in school and receiving a quality education whilst there.

title: Improving Girls Access through Transforming Education (IGATE)
description: The project seeks increase enrolment and, retention and to improve learning outcomes of a least 15,000 marginalised girls aged 10-19 in Zimbabwe through addressing some of the key barriers to access and quality of education. Working with communities and local governance structures as drivers of change the project will tackle economic and social/cultural barriers and empower girls to improve learning outcomes, enrolment and attendance rates. The project will utilize community-based structures to strengthen capacities of local authorities to understand, monitor and integrate evidence-based strategies to address girl child education and will develop an evidence base for continued engagement with MoESC. World Vision will lead the consortium with CARE International and SNV.

title: Bulawayo Emergency Water Augmentation Project
description: BEWAP - Bulawayo Emergency Water Augmentation Project Ensuring the health and wellbeing of the residents of Bulawayo, particularly the vulnerable, disabled, elderly, and those in unserved areas, by ensuring the maximum use of limited existing water and sanitation resources

title: Designing, Monitoring and Implementing Beneficiary Feedback Mechanisms GPAF Pilot
description: This GPAF Beneficiary Feedback Mechanism Pilot project is funded by DFID and implemented in 9 GPAF partner health projects in 8 countries. The pilot involves testing three different approaches to gathering and using feedback from intended and unintended beneficiaries for improved impact in GPAF projects. A specific feedback mechanism low resource approach using mobile feedback will be implemented in the country

title: Temotu Tsunami Response
description: World Vision are conducting a 30 day response to support 3,329 people affected by the tsunami in Temotu Province of the Solomon Islands.

title: Secure land tenure for women and vulnerable groups in Brazil
description: This project will develop the capacity of civil society organisations and excluded women to advocate for their rights to secure tenure and property through changes in law and practice. Part of the project will involve working with the local authorities to make their process more transparent and responsive to the needs of women and vulnerable groups on tenure issues. The project will benefit 2,500 families directly and 800,000 families indirectly.
implementing_organisations: ;Habitat for Humanity Brazil;One World Trust;Habitat for Humanity International - Latin America and the Caribbean Area Office
sector-text: Land Rights

title: Adaptation Learning Program (ALP) for Africa
description: The goal of the Adaptation Learning Programme is to reduce the impacts of climate variability and change on vulnerable households in Sub-Saharan Africa.
sector-text: Climate Change

title: ART Adherence Research
description: This project explores the impact that cash transfers can make to households directly impacted by HIV/AIDS and in particular those who are on Antiretroviral Medication Therapies (ART).
sector-text: HIV/Aids

title: CARE Protracted Relief Programme Final Phase
description: This Programme aims to enhance sustainable food security and nutrition, and increase the livelihoods and economic security of chronically poor, labour-endowed rural households in the Bikita, Chivi, Masvingo, Mwenezi, Mberengwa and Zaka Provinces of Zimbabwe.
sector-text: Agriculture and Natural Resources

title: Design and Implementation of Bihar Health Sector Reform Strategy Management and Technical Support
description: The goal of this Technical Assistance is to improve the health and nutritional status of people in Bihar, particularly the poorest and excluded, by ensuring that key government Departments and other key stakeholders are equipped to deliver on reforms in their respective areas and thereby accelerate the stateâ€™s progress towards the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).
sector-text: Health

title: Emergency care & support to Ivorian refugees in Grand Gedeh Country
description: This project will provide 15,000 newly arrived refugees from Cote D'Ivoire into Grand Gedeh with mosquito nets, sleeping mats, blankets, cooking/household utensils, water storage containers and increase their access to clean water, construct latrines in safe locations for women and girls as well as carrying out an extensive campaign and awareness building on sexual and gender based violence.
sector-text: Emergency Response

title: Ghana Research & Advocacy Programme
description: The Ghana Research and Advocacy Programme (G-RAP) is a pooled funding mechanism for supporting the institutional development of Research and Advocacy Organisations (RAOs) in Ghana, offering multi-annual core funding to a group of the most established RAOs selected on a competitive and needs-assessment basis together with one-off grants and technical assistance to emerging RAOs.
sector-text: Governance

title: HSNP 2 Reg Phase
description: The goal of this preparatory phase is to provide adequate planning for those who shall be targeted in phase II, registering all households in Marsabit County with comprehensive data capture for all households.
sector-text: Food Security

title: Innovative Microfinance Services (through GRM)
description: This project seeks to facilitate sustainable linkages between the graduates of urban ISAL participants and formal microfinance service providers in selected suburbs of Harare with an emphasis on access to working capital loans and to improve access to a wider range of financial services through the development of new products (e.g. micro-insurance, micro-leasing and/or micro-pension, Alternative energy).
sector-text: Micro Finance and Small Business

title: Securing Fair Access to Public Services and Resources for Smallholder Coffee Producers in Peru
description: This project aims to empower marginalised smallholder coffee communities and their representative organisations in Peru to demand and secure an equitable amount of public resources and services.

title: Safe Peanuts: Improved smallholder livelihoods in Malawi
description: The project aims to increase household income for smallholder farmers and reduced aflatoxin prevalence in Malawian groundnuts

title: Improving Public Accountability in Zambia School Bursary Schemes
description: The project aims to improve access and quality in the Zambia education system to enable more vulnerable Zambian children to access state provided fee-based education in a child-friendly environment. An informed and engaged civil society will be empowered to claim their rights and hold government to account on the funding commitments made to their children and the abuse they face in schools. The MoE will be supported to implement an efficient and accountable bursary scheme and Child Protection Policies. The project will achieve greater capacity of, and closer collaboration between, state and non-state actors and systemic change in the education sector to better manage public funds and stop child abuse.

title: Community action for girls education in Zimbabwe
description: This project is mobilising Camfedâ€™s extensive partnership networks at local and national level behind a â€˜Together We Canâ€™ campaign towards revitalising education at this critical time in Zimbabwe. Civil society and education authorities will be supported to co-operate to increase resource flows to schools, improve accountability over these resources, and monitor school performance, with a view to enhancing the quality and safety of education for all children. The project will engage local stakeholders in an education policy review process to ensure that statutory instruments are relevant to the rural context, and that these are widely implemented.

title: Advancing Girls Education in Ghana
description: This project is improving school enrolment, retention and learning outcomes for 31,000 vulnerable children, especially girls, in impoverished, rural districts in Ghana. It covers provision of social cash transfers to decrease barriers to poor childrenâ€™s education, training teachers in pastoral care, increasing local female teacher recruitment, and improving school resource deployment with training of community-school partnerships in governance and data-driven decision making.

title: Zimbabwe Girlsâ€™ Secondary Education
description: This project is strengthening the scope and quality of educational services in Zimbabwe, enhancing student access, retention, and achievement in the secondary cycle with special attention to disadvantaged girls. The project will extend secondary school bursary support to 24,000 girls in Zimbabwe over 4 years. Meanwhile, the support systems around the girls will be strengthened as the project provides training for Teacher Mentors, school based committee members, and district committees.

title: A new â€˜equilibriumâ€™ for girls
description: Under this project, Camfed is working in partnership with Pearson to transform educational opportunities for girls in Zimbabwe and Tanzania. 60,000 girls who have either dropped out of school or are at high risk of doing so will receive direct support to complete secondary education (40,000 in Zimbabwe, 20,000 in Tanzania). An additional 400,000 girls and boys in 970 rural secondary schools in 24 districts in Zimbabwe and 10 districts in Tanzania will benefit from actions to improve their learning and push up their results. CAMA, Camfedâ€™s peer supported network of young women school-leavers will play a key role in delivery of this project as they roll out an innovative Learner Guide model.

title: Secondary School Bursaries for Girls in Malawi
description: This project forms part of DFID Malawi\'s \'Keeping Girls in School\' programme. It is providing bursary support for 15,000 poor and vulnerable girls studying in partner schools in 17 marginalised rural districts to complete four years of secondary school. The project will simultaneously strengthen capacity within schools to manage the bursary scheme, facilitate coordination and support to schools by district level authorities and encourage the adoption of best practice by the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology, with regards to keeping girls in school.

title: Child-centred schooling: innovation for the improvement of learning outcomes for marginalised girls in Zambia
description: This project is improving retention in education for 15,418 marginalised girls in 118 upper primary schools and improving learning outcomes for 2,954 marginalised girls in 90 schools. The project is introducing Fundacion Escuela Nuevaâ€™s (FEN) democratic school governance model and flexible, child-centred pedagogy to Zambia for the first time, embedding it in the existing Camfed Model in Zambia. The new, combined model will promote girlsâ€™ learning, safety, confidence and knowledge, keeping them in school to learn and grow, opening up the potential for further education and greater control over the major decisions in their lives.

title: Incentive Support for Girls in Secondary Education - Ghana
description: This project is providing bursary support for 31,000 girls (8,000 in JHS, 12,000 in SHS) over four years in 30 districts. The project includes wrap around support covering: Planning for School Excellence using school data in 260 schools; engagement with the Ghanaian governmentâ€™s Girls Education Unit; training Girls\' Education Officers and Teacher Mentors; district exchange visits for GES staff; and training for DECs participating in Planning for School Excellence.

title: Nepal Ex Kamaiya Education and Poverty Alleviation Project
description: Backward Society Education (BASE) has been implementing DFID funded project titled Nepal Ex-Kamaiya Education and Poverty Alleviation Project (NEKEPA) Since January 2013. This project has been envisioned and implemented by BASE in partnership with World Vision Advocacy Forum (WVAF). The project is intervened in mid and far- western district namely Dang, Banke, Bardiya, Kailali and Kanchanpur of Nepal. The project supports over 186,000 of Nepal's ex-kamaiya community (freed bonded labourers). In 2000, following peaceful civil society protests, the Government of Nepal abolished the kamaiya system but the ex-kamaiyas are extremely poor, without land or livelihoods. Almost 15% have not received their rehabilitation packages because most are unaware of their entitlements and because accessing them is obstructed by bureacracy, inefficiency and corruption. Un- and under-employment is high, with 69% experiencing income/food insecurity for at least nine months/year. Evidence suggests that 11% of children are out-of-school and likely to be in child labour. The project aims to support ex-kamaiyas to gain their entitlements, to mobilise them for savings and credit, and to provide vocational training. The ex-kamaiyas will increase their incomes and gain productive employment; children (with a focus on girls) will be supported to attend school and complete primary education. ;Contribute to achieve MDG's No 1, 2 & 3 Goal 1: Eradicate extreme poverty and hunger Goal 2: Achieve universal primary education Goal3: Promote gender equality and empower women ;10077 nos of Ex Kamaiya Families

title: My very first activity
DFID PPA Framework agreement
A Fair Cup: Ensuring the rights of smallholder tea farmers in Kenya
description: This project will reduce poverty and improve the rights and livelihoods of smallholder tea farmers across three districts in Kenya by enabling them to develop a collective voice, engage directly with local decision making processes, and ensure transparent and accountable representation amongst tea sector representatives. This includes: raising awareness of farmersâ€™ rights under new government tea legislation; supporting farmers to form groups through which they can make their collective voices heard; and working with tea factories to make them more transparent and accountable. Expected outcomes include a 20% increase in farmersâ€™ income; improved control over their livelihoods (improved production, input into where their tea is sold) and greater farmer representation at factory and KTDA level. This will benefit 30,000 farmers and their families (180,000 beneficiaries).

title: Alleviating Poverty in North East Bangladesh
description: This project will ensure sustainable livelihoods for poor and marginal communities, particularly women, in Northern Bangladesh through improvements to small-scale agriculture. By organising farmers and linking them to information, skills, services and markets, the project will reduce costs of production, increase productivity and improve access to resources. This will lead to a 50% increase in income, directly benefiting 6,000 households (40% women) and their families (30,000 people).

title: Beekeepers economic Empowerment Tanzania (BEET)
description: This project will increase incomes for poor communities, including women, in Tanzania by improving their beekeeping skills and knowledge. The project will organise beekeepers into groups and link them to information, skills, services and markets. This will increase production, improve honey quality, and reduce costs of production leading to a 20% increase in income from honey sales, directly benefiting 2,760 beekeepers and their families (16,560 people).

title: Increasing Retention and Completion at 40 Ugandan Schools
description: The project aims to increase retention and completion rates amongst 13,981 pupils at 40 rural Ugandan schools. This will be achieved by providing training for 8,841 parents, 520 School Management Committee members and 283 teachers to ensure that parents actively participate in school development and that the schools are well managed and governed. In particular the project will focus on ensuring that the specific needs of the 7,072 female pupils are addressed.

description: The central aim of the proejct is to address the needs and promote the rights of people with mental disorders in western Nepal. This will be achieved through the implementation of the mental health and development model developed by BasicNeedsd.

description: People with mental illness in Ashanti and Brong-Ahafo Regions of Ghana will satisfy their basic needs and their basic rights will be recognised and respected. The user movement will be strengthened through the formation of 130 self help groups thus enabling people with mental illness and epilepsy to gain confidence, participate in livelihoods and lead advocacy.

description: The aim is to empower orphan and vulnerable youths in Northern Uganda to meet their needs and exercise their rights. It is anticipated that 150 self help groups will participate in IGAs and be able to advocate for their rights.

title: Improved livelihood of women families in Northern Uganda through market led development
description: This project will establish productive farms and create access to commercial markets for women-headed households who have been re-settled in the districts of Lira, Apac and Oyam after the conflict in northern Uganda. It will run for two years from August 2011. It will directly support 1,800 poor women, each of whom looks after 5-8 children, many of them orphans, enabling them to improve the diet and food security for their families and generate incomes. An additional 3,000 families are expected to benefit from the market access, facilities and skills training provided.
recipient-country: This project is focused on the districts of Lira, Apac and Oyam in northern Uganda.

title: Disaster Risk Management - Pakistan
description: This programme aims to support the Pakistan Red Crescent Society in progressing itsâ€™ Community Based Disaster Risk Reduction (CBDRR) approach to risk reduction and strengthen its rapid emergency preparedness and response capabilities in the face of potential floods and IDP (internally displaced people) scenarios. It focuses on community and organisational preparedness in 12 districts and a national preparedness and response capacity with a focus on prepositioned stock. Key activities: â€¢ Procurement, prepositioning and part distribution of emergency relief stocks, sufficient to meet the needs of 200HH at 25 DM Cells (total 35,000 people). â€¢ Training 60 PRCS staff in disaster management and response training. â€¢ DM cells operational in 12 communities.
sector-text: Disaster Risk Reduction

title: Programme Partnership Agreement - PPA
description: Programme Partnership Agreements (PPAs) are one of DFIDâ€™s main support mechanisms to Civil Society Organisations and the British Red Cross. The PPAs are strategic level agreements based around mutually agreed outcomes and individual performance frameworks against which organisations report on an annual basis. Critically, subject to performance, PPAs provide organisations with multi-year funding, enabling them to better plan and deliver programmes, including in more difficult, higher risk environments. PPAs are aimed at organisations with a global reach and leaders in their field who can add value to DFIDâ€™s portfolio, support the realisation of its objectives, achieve real results in terms of poverty reduction and provide good value for money. In April 2011, the British Red Cross was awarded a three year CHASE (DFID's Conflict, Humanitarian and Security Department) PPA following a competitive application process and due diligence assessment, which was later extended for an additional two years. ItÂ´s worth Â£8,189,97 in total. This strategic funding aims to help the British Red Cross scale up its support to strengthening the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movementâ€™s ability to enable individuals and communities to better prepare for, withstand and recover from crises, emergencies and disasters through strengthening leadership, coordination and technical capacity at global, regional and local levels.
recipient-country: In year one (2011/2012) the PPA has improved the British Red Crossâ€™ support to the Movement across 52 countries, 17 of which are priority countries for DFID, across the full scope of our International programming.
sector-text: Disaster Management;Partnership Development (Resilience);International Humanitarian Law;Humanitarian Policy;Performance and Accountability;Grant Management

title: Reducing Community Risk and Strengthening Disaster Response - Uganda
description: Uganda is at high risk from a variety of natural (and man-made) disasters which have the potential to derail progress on poverty reduction. This programme will work with local communities and governments to reduce vulnerability to disasters in ten communities in eastern Uganda which are at high risk of flooding, and increase national capacity to respond to future disasters. Key activities: â€¢ Reduce vulnerability and increase resilience to flooding in 10 high risk communities. â€¢ Strengthen URCS DM capacity to respond efficiently and effectively to disasters. â€¢ Improve effectiveness of URCS engagement in national policy development and co-ordination to enhance humanitarian efforts.
sector-text: Disaster Risk Reduction

title: Disaster Risk Reduction - British Overseas Territories
description: British Red Cross overseas branches are in Anguilla, Bermuda, British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Montserrat and Turks and Caicos Islands susceptible to hurricanes, floods, landslides, mudslides, winter storms and volcanic activity and other natural disasters. This programme seeks to build community resilience across the 6 territories they serve and also build their capacity to mitigate and respond to disasters and climate change in the region. Key activities: â€¢ Reduce vulnerability to disasters in 25 high-risk communities (5,200 people) across the 6 Overseas Territories. â€¢ Increase disaster response effectiveness in the OSBs of the British Red Cross (reaching 13,792 people). â€¢ Increase each Overseas Branch disaster management capacity, including 25% increase in active volunteer capacity, to fulfil its defined role as per the national Disaster Management plan.
sector-text: Disaster Risk Reduction

title: Earthquake Preparedness for Safer Communities - Nepal
description: The programme contributes to the Nepal Risk Reduction Consortium (NRRC) an initiative which aims to support the Government of Nepal in developing a long term Disaster Risk Reduction Action Plan. The programme is centred around community-level multi-hazard risk reduction interventions targeted at 66 communities and a mass communication campaign to raise the awareness of the entire population of Kathmandu Valley about the risks they face and risk reduction actions they can take to protect themselves and their families. It also seeks to improve the NRCSâ€™s capacity to respond to disasters. Key activities: â€¢ Decrease risks encountered by 66 vulnerable communities through community based strategies to enhance awareness, organisational preparedness and resilience. â€¢ Develop an earthquake preparedness mass communication campaign targeting 2 to 4 million people. â€¢ Strengthen capacity of NCRS to respond to a major disaster emergency within the national disaster management system.
sector-text: Earthquake Preparedness

title: Contigency Plan for Potential Pre/Post Election Humanitarian Response to the 2013 Kenyan General Elections
description: Kenya conducted the last general election in 2007 which witnessed the most pronounced violence episode since independence which led to the death of an estimated 1,133 people and the displacement of more than 600,000 people in three provinces (Nairobi, Rift Valley and Nyanza). As Kenya prepares itself to participate in the next general election on the 4th of March 2013, Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS) has prepared a contingency plan based on its experience from the last elections; its analysis of the current political situation; dialogue with Government and other agencies. The aims of the election preparedness plans are: - To preposition emergency shelter, relief, health care and nutrition stocks. - To increase the capacity of KRCS teams to undertake assessment and provide emergency response. - To disseminate Red Cross principles and create awareness of international humanitarian law

title: Strengthening the role of poor, peri-urban communities in development planning and poverty reduction strategies in Luanda, Angola
description: This project will support poor communities living on the outskirts of Luanda in Angola to engage with government and participate fully in the newly emerging democracy. The project will therefore help to ensure that the voice of the poor is heard by government and that development plans for Luanda genuinely lead to improved living conditions and reduced poverty for the cityâ€™s poorest residents.

title: Empowering Colomboâ€™s urban poor to realise their right to adequate living conditions.
description: This project will develop the skills and capacities of poor communities in Colombo, Sri Lanka, enabling them to engage better with government and establish working partnerships around slum upgrading which will lead to the improvement of tenure, housing and infrastructure conditions.

title: Innovative partnerships for water and sanitation delivery in Kenya
description: The project will increase access to improved and sustainable water and sanitation in Nairobi and Kisumu, Kenya, benefiting 30,580 slum dwellers with improved water supply and 13,400 with improved sanitation. This will be achieved by building their capacity to implement and manage infrastructure, promoting greater involvement of the urban poor in basic service delivery and governance, and better collaboration between civil society and infrastructure providers

title: Community-led water & sanitation delivery in Tanzania and Zimbabwe
description: In 10 cities of Tanzania and Zimbabwe, the project will benefit 30,680 slum dwellers through access to improved and sustainable water supply and 21,520 through sanitation, together with solid waste management, hygiene promotion and school water & sanitation. This will be achieved by building the capacity of communities, innovative finance through revolving loan funds, greater involvement in service delivery, and better collaboration with infrastructure providers and authorities.
implementing_organisations: ;Homeless International;Dialogue on Shelter for the Homeless in Zimbabwe Trust;Centre for Community Initiatives

title: Penal Reform International (PRI) - Head Office, UK
description: PRI works on penal and criminal justice reform worldwide. Our strategic goals for 2010-15 are: 1. Reduction in the use of imprisonment 2. Prevention of torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment 3. Incarceration of children as the last resort 4. A proportionate and sensitive response to women offending 5. A leading international resource for penal reform 6. Exploration of new ways and locations to promote penal reform. PRI's Head Office in London leads and co-ordinates international policy and advocacy activities, co-ordinates multi-regional programmes and supports PRI's Regional Offices in four regions and local partners in two further regions to implement country and regional programmes to achieve PRI's strategic goals. PRI Head Office also provides planning, programme development, fundraising, publications and online information and training resources, monitoring and evaluation functions as well as overall governance, personnel, administrative and financial management for PRI International.
