title: DFID Innovation Fund - EXTRA Project
Social and economic empowerment of adolescents in rural Uttar Pradesh, India
description: The overall aim is to eliminate poverty and rights abuses. Expected outcomes are: 2,100 adolescents will acquire literacy and other life skills, particularly basic health and hygiene practices and prevention of diseases, vocational skills and awareness of their rights and how to access them; 1,680 adolescents will become productive adults through vocational education courses; the RTE Act will be effectively implemented in the project area; and implementing partners will have increased capacity. 2,100 adolescents will have greater gender sensitivity and enhanced confidence and ability to articulate their needs. Training will improve the standard of living of both adolescents and their future families. Their families will benefit from sharing their knowledge and communities will access government schemes and services, particularly quality education through their own advocacy initiatives.
funding_organisations: ;Find Your Feet;UK Department for International Development
implementing_organisations: ;Sarathi Development Foundation (SDF);Parayaran Evam Prodyogiki Utthan Samiti (PEPUS);Saksham India Trust (SIT) ;Sabla

title: Promoting the labour rights of marginalised brick kiln workers in rural Uttar Pradesh
description: The overall goal of this project is to reduce poverty among marginalised brick kiln communities in Uttar Pradesh, India. A total of 9,483 marginalised people from brick kiln communities in four districts of Uttar Pradesh will be empowered to realise their civil, economic, political and social rights, through the establishment and strengthening of local level structures advocating for the rights of marginalised brick kiln workers and their families. Brick kiln workers will have increased understanding of their labour rights and strengthened capacity to demand those rights collectively, resulting in fair pay and improved working conditions. Brick kiln communities will be actively participating in civil, socio-economic and political life, leading to improved livelihood opportunities and increased access to government services and social welfare schemes.
implementing_organisations: ;Paryavaran Evam Prodyogiki Utthan Samiti (PEPUS);Indian Rural Technology Development Institute (IRTDI);Sarathi Development Foundation (SDF)

title: Farmer innovation to increase food security and income for 2,900 farming families in Chimanimani, Zimbabwe
description: The project will increase food security and income for 2,900 farming families in Chimanimani, Zimbabwe, by supporting them to participate in a community-based process of learning, innovation and knowledge exchange. This process will be led by exemplary â€˜Tsimeâ€™ (â€˜Sourceâ€™) farmers, who will share their knowledge and skills with follower farmers, enabling them to produce more food, increase their income and conserve the land on which they depend.
implementing_organisations: ;African Farmers Organic Research and Training (AfFOResT);Chikukwa Ecological Land Use Community Trust (CELUCT);Towards Sustainable Use of Resources Organisation (TSURO);Zimbabwe Organic Producers and Promoters Association (ZOPPA)

title: Empowering 2,500 of the poorest and most marginalised women in Nepal, mostly from the Tharu tribal group, to improve their food security and incomes and influence local decision making processes
description: This project will support 2,500 of the poorest and most marginalised women (mainly tribal) in rural Nepal. It will work towards improving food security, incomes and self-reliance through the adoption of environmentally sustainable agriculture and will provide access to low-cost credit to establish micro-enterprises. The women and their fellow community members will also be empowered to influence local decision-making processes through community groups established by the project.

title: Indigenous women improving family nutrition in the Peruvian Amazon Jungle
description: The project will contribute to improving health and nutrition of the population in Satipo Province. It will train native women to use local products in order to increase food security. It will strengthen the capacities of local partners and other CSOs to undertake studies on nutrition, carry out regular monitoring of nutrition programmes, and advocate for inclusion of local products within those programmes. The action will build the capacities of local governments to produce public expenditure reports related to nutrition programmes and strengthen existing platforms to improve coordination of those programmes.

title: Improving Maternal and Child Health for 116,744 internally displaced women and children in Somaliland
description: The project aims to improve maternal, neonatal and child health status in Somaliland contributing to MDGs 4 and 5. The project will support maternity work at Hargeisa Group Hospital, 11 health facilities and add a child and newborn care component to complement existing work in Marroodi Jeex region where the majority of internally displaced people/returnees are settled. It is envisaged that over 100,000 women of child-bearing age and children will benefit from this work.;IDP women of child bearing age (22% project area population) Infants (4% of project area population) Children under 5 years (20% of project area population) Health workers (government and community)
sector-text: The direct impact of this project will be improved maternal, neonatal and child health status among poor and marginalised

title: Improving Maternal & Child Health outcomes for 128,123 women and children from marginalised pastoralist communities in Mandera, Kenya
description: The project aims to improve maternal and child health (MCH) outcomes for marginalised pastoralist communities in Mandera, Kenya towards the achievement of MDGs 4 and 5. Activities will increase the quality and appropriateness of MCH services at government health facilities whilst creating demand for services from communities through awareness raising and behaviour change activities. It will create integrated, sustainable health services that are inclusive to all sections of society.

title: Reducing Malnutrition Rates in children under five years old in Southern Laos PDR
description: This project aims to reduce the prevalence of malnutrition amongst children under-five years old in remote communities of southern Lao PDR by: improving behaviours related to health and nutrition and food practices; providing village women with the skills to manage community malnutrition; supporting poor families with agriculture inputs and livestock as well as providing them with safe drinking water; and training government staff to support communitiesâ€™ access to food and water. ;Population of project target villages including VDC members, VWNF, poor farmers, CU5 and WCBA; and provincial and district government staff of PAFO/DAFO, PLWU/ DLWU and PHD/DHO

title: Rwandan Girls' Education and Advancement Programme
description: In Nyaruguru, Rwanda, many girls are excluded from education for financial and socio-cultural reasons. Lack of education is a root cause of poverty and ill health, so HPA is working with the community to effect long-lasting change for girls in this area with funding from the DFID-Girls Education Challenge. The impact of this project will be to improve the life chances of marginalised girls, with 11,900 girls in Rwanda able to complete a full life cycle of education and demonstrate learning as a direct outcome of the project.

title: Assessing and mitigating the seasonality of poverty in vulnerable households in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan
description: This programme supports the goal of reducing extreme poverty caused by extreme weather â€“ harsh winters in particular â€“ in vulnerable households including those with older people in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. It works through 17 older peopleâ€™s groups to collect a full year of data on poverty indicators and local variables that affect poverty levels, to identify the impact of seasonal variations. The groups also coordinate community micro-projects aimed at stabilising the livelihoods of the most vulnerable in their communities. The programme will develop targeted recommendations for governments and development actors based on its findings.;To enable communities to prepare for and cope with episodes of seasonal ultra-poverty;To increase awareness of seasonal vulnerability of regional governments and development actors

description: The overall objective of the project is to achieve a sustained improvement in quality of life and well-being of older people and their families in Mozambique. The specific objective will ensure that older people in 29 communities exercise their right to access services, to active citizenship and to live free from discrimination and abuse.;Older people integrated and active participants in systems that both protect them and hold government and communities accountable for progress in achieving rights and entitlements for older people. ;The capacity of older peopleâ€™s organizations is strengthened to better represent the interests of their members and vulnerable older people.;Key Government policies and plans show increased commitment to achieving the rights of older people and to implementation of the National Plan for Older People. ;Direct support to 8,000 older people within the project communities, with benefits to 185,000 older people and family members within the project districts of work.

sector-text: Global action 4: Global and local movements to claim the rights and entitlements of older people

title: Assessment Capacities Project (ACAPS)
description: The project goal is to improve the effectiveness of humanitarian responses through provision of comprehensive, context-specific information, thus leading to effective humanitarian responses. Its purpose is to strengthen the capacity of the humanitarian sector to carry out coordinated multi-sectoral needs assessments before, during and after crisis. In addition, ACAPS will help improve the quality of analysis that is required for evidence-based decision-making through provision of expert advice, including to the Needs Assessment Task Force (NATF) and the Humanitarian Dashboard initiative. This is a consortium project between HelpAge International, Merlin and the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC). HelpAge International is the lead agency for the period September 2009 until June 2012, when the lead agency role transferred to NRC. ;To develop a core of effective, reliable and trained assessment experts that facilitate and support timely, high quality, coordinated multi-sectoral needs assessments and assessment preparedness on behalf of IASC Country Teams.;To help improve the quality of analysis for evidence-based decision-making through provision of expert advice, including to the Needs Assessment Task Force (NATF).;The key target stakeholders include sectoral assessment experts from clusters and NGOs as well as members of the ACAPS roster. ACAPS training activities will be adjusted and replicated to reach wider groups of the humanitarian community (for example to train staff based in disaster prone countries). The planned training activities will focus on three target groups : Assessment Experts, First Responders and Decision Makers.
funding_organisations: ;Canadian International Development Agency;Danish International Development Agency;European Commission Humanitarian Aid department (ECHO);Swedish International Development Authority;USAID/Office for Disaster Assistance;Irish Aid;Department for International Development;HelpAge International - unrestricted funds

title: Accelerate Livelihoods of Left-behind Older Workforce (ALLOW)
description: The programme supports and develops the livelihoods for 1,000 older people-headed households living on the river islands of Kurigam and Lakshmipur districts, and who are directly affected by migration of family members and at risk of natural disaster. The intervention is a process facilitation initiative, operating through Community Support Centres. These centres act as a focal point for service delivery, follow-up and technical support for: income generating activities; linking households to social protection entitlements; health education and support, and disaster risk reduction training. The centres also help households regain or retain contact with migrant family members when needed. ;Improved income of targeted households, with 50% of targeted households realising a 35% increase in income, and a 20% decline of number of household members begging.;Improved physical coping capacities of older people, with 45% of older people in targeted households seeking medical attention in good time and receiving health care support from extended families. ;Improved household assets and expenditure, with 45% of targeted households demonstrating: at least a 25% increase in expenditure on food and medication; a 35% increase in the value of assets held, and 15 % of targeted households reporting women in families having independent choice of purchase. ;Improved levels of social support, with 30% of targeted households reporting regular communication with migrant family members and 30% of targeted households reporting their increased participation in social events.;Improved disaster coping capacity (as a measure against IGA erosion), with 25% of targeted household reporting a 15% decrease in level of loss of productive assets and 25% of targeted households reporting their inclusion in disaster risk reduction initiatives. ;Older people and family members from 1,000 households affected by economic migration of other adult wage-earners.
funding_organisations: ;Economic Empowerment of the Poorest (EEP)/Shiree programme, Bangladesh
implementing_organisations: ;HelpAge International;Pidim Foundation;Bangladesh Institute of Theatre Arts

title: Hunger Safety Net Programme â€“ Social Protection Rights Component
description: The objective of the Social Protection Rights Component is to inform potential participants in the Hunger Safety Net Programme (HSNP) in northern Kenya of their rights to participate and to provide a vehicle for addressing complaints and grievances that arise in the implementation process. The total number of beneficiary households in the programme will be 60,000. This programme is a commercial contract with the UK Department for International Development. ;To define a Charter of Programme Rights, including the design of a cost-effective system for complaints and grievances and to implement an outreach programme for this in the programmeâ€™s locations of work. The Charter of Programme Rights should outline the rights and responsibilities of programme participants in relation to the HSNP management and delivery structures. ;To provide a â€œProgramme Complaints Adjudication and Referralâ€ù function in four districts for up to 24,000 beneficiary households per district depending on population size and prevalence of chronic poverty and hunger. ;The grievance system should serve the approximately 800 â€œcontrolâ€ù households included in the Monitoring and Evaluation component of HSNP. The grievance system will also need to handle complaints from non-beneficiaries, though this will need to be proportionate and feasible to the overall scale of the project.;The Social Protection Rights Component must ensure internal monitoring and evaluation to capture innovation, action research and lesson learning in the design and implementation of this component. The monitoring and evaluation system must be co-ordinated with other components of the programme and focused on areas agreed in the comprehensive workplan and effectively link in with the HSNP Management Information System (MIS) such that this will include registration, enrolment and case management information and dispute adjudication, referral and resolution for tracking to enable overall progress monitoring.;60,000 targeted households in four districts identified by the programme on the basis of poverty and hunger prevalence (Turkana, Mandera, Marsabit and Wajir).
funding_organisations: ;Department of International Development;Help the Aged/HelpAge International UK
implementing_organisations: ;HelpAge International;District Pastoralist Association;Pastoralist Integrated Support Programme (PISP);Rural Agency for Community Development and Assistance (RACIDA);Women for Peace in Development

title: Hunger Safety Net Programme Phase II - Social Protection Rights Component
description: The goal of the Social Protection Rights (SPR) component is to contribute to a reduction in extreme poverty in Kenya. Its purpose is to support the establishment of a government-led national social protection system delivering long-term, guaranteed cash transfers to extremely poor and vulnerable people. This is the second phase of the SPR component and will work to ensure: 1. Individuals who are entitled to a cash transfer are receiving it 2. Human rights principles are mainstreamed into all HSNP components and adopted by other local and national service providers 3. Effective statutory complaints and redress mechanisms are made accessible to poor and marginalized groups 4. Capacity of local NGO partners is built in order to sustain improvements made by the HSNP 5. Learning from the project is accurately collected and disseminated to inform development practice and influence policy ;Outcome 1: Percentage of HSNP complaints successfully resolved through the HSNP grievance mechanism within one cycle;Outcome 2: Percentage of complaints resolved through the One Stop Shop model (reasonable timeframe to be determined during pilot - first OSS to be established in 2013);Initially, 67,000 targeted households in four districts identified by the programme on the basis of poverty and hunger prevalence (Turkana, Mandera, Marsabit and Wajir). Over this phase of the programme, the HSNP may scale up to cover 350,000 households.

title: Accountability in Tanzania
description: This programme seeks to address the lack of knowledge and understanding older people, particularly older women, have in regard to their rights and entitlements and of local government structures, functions and processes. The goal of the programme is to contribute to the achievement of the MDGs by ensuring that older Tanzanians are increasingly able to claim and exercise their rights as citizens. HelpAge in Tanzania, therefore, aims to ensure that the movement for older people, and their organisations, is strengthened and founded on functional older peopleâ€™s forums able to use credible evidence in advocacy and demonstrating upward levels of engagement with decision makers at community, ward, district and national levels connected to global networks. ;Older people, particularly older women, have improved access to information on their rights and entitlements, and have the power to demand for these rights and their access entitlements.;Increased demand for access to quality services in the areas of health, education and agriculture, and are included in local development processes.;Increased engagement of older people and age-care organisations in policy and budget allocation processes resulting in the entitlements of older people mainstreamed into district planning and budgeting processes, National HIV and AIDS, Household Budget and Food Security surveys, and emergency responses.;Implementation of National Ageing Policy (2003) and MKUKUTA phase two facilitate achieves a wider reach of response to the needs of older people and communities.;2.5 million older people across the regions of Tanzania and districts are working effectively to implement existing entitlements and motivated to engage with decision makers at all levels of government to ensure that their life-long contribution is recognised and rewarded; their voices are heard and are respected within families and communities. Older people are protected from killing and are fulfilling their potential, leading dignified, healthy and secure lives.

title: Field test of the Safe Water Trustâ€™s Aquafilter family model in Haiti
description: This 3-month project aims to test the feasibility and effectiveness of the Aquafilter water purifier/pump with rural families in Haiti, specifically testing whether it is used persistently over time, with or without training provided on its use. HelpAge will train community agents in the use and maintenance of the pumps and in basic hygiene and water management. The community agents perform monitoring of the condition of the purifier/pumps and data collection on their use and maintenance as well as on the level of satisfaction of the beneficiaries.;To demonstrate if families in rural Haiti will use the Aquafilter persistently over time.;600 families - average 6 persons per family for a total of 3,600 direct beneficiaries.

HelpAge International will target 4,517 of these households.

description: Emergency response programme to provide immediate support for 10,000 household affected by Typhoon Haiyan. The response focus is for households with vulnerable members and specific responses to older peopleâ€™s needs.;37 older people's organisations (OPOs) trained to provide psycho-social support to 3,000 extremely vulnerable /traumatised older people.;1,000 households with highly vulnerable members receive cash and/or locally appropriate inputs to reconstruct shelter;10,000 households with highly vulnerable members receive food and essential non-food items;Older people in 16 evacuation centres have facilitated access to emergency assistance and services by establishing help desks;50,000 typhoon affected persons based on five persons per household.10,000 households are the target beneficiaries: 1,500 households from Negros Occidental, 8,500 households from Northern Leyte province. In addition a further 3,500 extremely vulnerable older people will be targeted with psycho-social support.

title: Learning with older people about their transport and mobility problems in rural Tanzania: focus on improving access to health services
description: The African Community Access Programme (AFCAP) addresses the challenges of providing reliable access for poor communities. AFCAP undertakes research and provides advice to help deliver safe and sustainable access to rural communities.;The high level objective is to identify and promote mobility-focused interventions which will aid older people living in rural areas and those in their care to achieve better health and well-being. The findings will relate not only to local needs in the project area, but nationally in Tanzania and internationally across sub-Saharan Africa.;To provide an evidence base concerning how rural older peopleâ€™s access to transport currently shapes their health service access and levels of economic empowerment. This needs to have detailed gender- specific, age- and disability-adjusted dimensions. ;To identify specific transport-related strategies which will enable older people living in rural areas to access better health care and thus more effectively support themselves and those in their care to achieve better overall well-being. ;To ensure these findings reach key policy makers and practitioners locally, nationally and internationally, who then act on them.;Older people living in rural areas who make up 82% of all older people in the country (around 2 million people) that are facing difficult to access health care service because of transport and mobility related problems.
implementing_organisations: ;HelpAge International;Research on Poverty Alleviation (REPOA);HelpAge International;Research on Poverty Alleviation (REPOA);Good Samaritan Social Services Tanzania (GSSST) ;HelpAge International;Research on Poverty Alleviation (REPOA);Good Samaritan Social Services Tanzania (GSSST) ;Durham University;HelpAge International;Research on Poverty Alleviation (REPOA);Good Samaritan Social Services Tanzania (GSSST) ;Durham University

title: Consultancy Services for Delivery of Regional Dissemination Workshop on Making Transport for Health Accessible to Vulnerable Groups
description: As part of the African Community Access Programme (AFCAP), the assignment proposes to hold a regional workshop bringing together stakeholders with a potential interest in identifying approaches responding to the mobility and transportation challenges faced by older people and other vulnerable groups in accessing health care, especially in rural areas.;Higher level: To address the mobility and transportation challenges of older people and other vulnerable groups (such as those with disabilities) in accessing health care in East Africa.;Lower level: to disseminate and promote mobility-focused interventions which will aid older people and those in their care, as well as other vulnerable groups (such as those with disabilities) living in rural remote areas to achieve better health and well-being, leading to policy review and change especially in the fields of health and transportation.;Older men and women, and other mobility affected groups such as those with disabilities and Older People's Associations.

title: Humanitarian Innovation Fund - Rapid Assessment of Malnutrition in Older People
description: An action/research programme aimed at providing humanitarian agencies with a simple, quick, reliable, robust and cost effective method for assessing the nutritional status and vulnerabilities of older people in emergencies. The methodology can also be used as a project evaluation tool to assess the impact of the humanitarian response on older people. The resulting evidence will provide governments and humanitarian organisations with the necessary data to plan relevant and timely response to address older peopleâ€™s needs. ;Finalise the design and test a rapid assessment method to assess the nutritional needs of older people in emergencies.;Produce and disseminate a guideline and training materials on the complete method.

title: SI Bangladesh
description: The 5 year project, implemented through our partner the Centre for Disability in Development, has been working to ensure that deafblind people have access to specialist advice, opportunities and support.Â  Integral to the project are training and mentoring to support 16 partner organisations and professionals to provide quality services to deafblind people. At the same time networks of deafblind people, their families and teachers have been established to raise awareness and influence policy at government level.

title: SI India
description: The main purpose of the project is to expand services provided to deafblind children and young adults through two Regional and six State Learning Centres across India. This project ensures that, in the target areas, newborns are screed for deafblindness and early intervention services are available; deafblind children have access to education and deafblind young adults have opportunity for income generation. In addition we also build capacities of government teachers to educate deafblind children and also we gave skills to parents and deafblind persons to advocate for their rights with local and national governments.

title: Reinforcement & Empowerment for Effecting Civil Socirty Hope in Guinea (REFRESH)
Independent Monitoring of Forest Law Enforcement and Governance (IM-FLEG) in Support of FLEGT VPAs in the Congo Basin

This project aims to: 1) Contribute to transparency and governance improvement in the Congo Basin forest sector in the context of the FLEGT process implementation. 2) Support the implementation of IM-FLEG in Republic of Congo by Civil Society. 3) Increase Congo Basin Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) capacity to participate in the negotiation or implementation of FLEGT VPAs through the implementation of IM-FLEG mechanisms.

title: Developing Good Governance in the Niger Delta
description: A five year programme seeking to build the capacity of local government to deliver needs driven basic services; and of civil society to hold local governments in the Niger Delta to account and demand services critical to the reduction of poverty. LEF will engage with three Nigerian NGOs that have experience of working with stakeholders in the region to bring about change. The results sought include greater functional skills from the local government and engagement with the oil industry to lay a foundation for sustainable development. Practical action will focus on planning and implementation of pilot sustainable development projects in six local government authorities across three Niger Delta States. Also the project will create a platform for LGA and civil society engagement as well as a budget monitoring mechanism at the LGA level. A programme of cultural activities, underlining the relationship between traditional values and good governance, will reinforce outcomes.
sector-text: Improve Governance in Nigeria

title: Community peace-building in Mali
description: Project outcome: The project seeks to build social cohesion across 90 villages in the Timbuktu region, thereby reducing incidents of conflict; and to increase community participation in national peace-building processes. Project approach: Living Earth believes that inclusive dialogue, at the grassroots level, is essential to building social cohesion. It is essential that dialogue mechanisms build upon existing social capital and align with traditional governance structures in order to ensure community adhesion to such mechanisms. Although Northern Mali has a tradition for community meetings and dialogue, the recent crisis and the media insistence of describing events along ethnic lines has severely damaged the social fabric of these communities. A neutral, external, (but local, Malian) facilitator is required to kick-start the dialogue process.;Living Earthâ€™s community peace-building project has been developed in partnership with local partner, AMSS, and community leaders in Timbuktu. The project responds to the need to ensure that communities have a voice, and are able to play an active role in the national peace-building and development planning processes that will shape the future of the region. The project has been developed to ensure that there are bottom-up, grassroots focused, dialogue efforts to accompany top-down government programmes.

title: Climate Action Teams: Mobilising Kenyan Youth for Action on Climate Change
description: This project targets young people who will form Climate Action Teams (CATs), with 25- 35 members in each team, working across 20 localities in Kenya. These will operate as green business CBOs, enabling youths to generate income whilst developing and promoting climate change adaptation and mitigation mechanisms, and influencing local and national policy. The project aim is to increase the capacity of Kenyan youth to tackle impacts of climate change through outreach and entrepreneurship, inspiring community action and influencing Local Government responses and uptake of Kenyaâ€™s National Climate Change Action Plan. http://www.livingearth.org.uk/projects/climate-action-teams-mobilising-kenyan-youth-for-action-on-climate-change/

title: Gas to Power
description: The Gas to Power project contributes to a larger programme; the Sustainable Utilisation of Nigeriaâ€™s Gas and Renewable Energy Resources (SUNGAS), which aims to encourage the sustainable use of Nigeriaâ€™s energy resources through harnessing gas from flares to meet local energy needs in the Niger Delta. For communities living in the Niger Delta, gas flaring is the most visible and insidious representation of the oil industry. Nigeria has approximately 180 trillion cubic feet of gas reserves, the seventh largest in the world, currently exporting around 3 billion cubic ft. per day and flaring around 2.5 billion cubic ft. per day; equal to 30% of the entire EUâ€™s annual gas consumption. However, only 0.5 billion cubic feet per day is supplied to the domestic power sector, despite 70% of the population not having access to electricity or modern energy services. Harnessing gas from the flares to meet local energy needs is critical to local development in the region.;The Gas to Power demonstration project will utilise associated gas from either a flow station or oil well and using a micro turbine, generate electricity for domestic and small business consumption. The project will deploy a 0.5 MW gas turbine to produce and distribute electricity to around 3,000 households, 500 small businesses, 5 health centres and 6 schools. A strong community ownership element has been built into the project design; the entire assets and operations will be managed and maintained by a community-based utility company, owned by the community. The siting of the project will be preceded by a technical feasibility and economic viability assessment since the project aims at full cost recovery. In addition to electricity generation, the project has scope to incorporate other components including gas to liquid and gas to fertiliser, and these additions will operate on a fully commercial basis. This is the first time in Nigeria that a community will generate its own power from a hi-tech micro turbine rather then unsustainable diesel generators that create high levels of pollution. The scale of the project makes it replicable in other parts of the Niger Delta; as a sustainable local solution to domestic and industrial energy needs.

title: Promoting Womenâ€™s Entrepreneurship in the Niger Delta
description: Living Earth Foundationâ€™s multi-country â€˜Waste to Wealthâ€™ project is responding to the urgent need to improve the lives of the increasing number of improvised and vulnerable people residing in urban slums in sub-Saharan Africa alongside its local project partner in Port Harcourt Nigeria; ANPEZ Centre for Environment and Development; as well as Kampala (Uganda) and Douala (Cameroon). The project is creating a virtuous circle wherein slum dwellers in nine urban areas in the cities of Port Harcourt (Nigeria), Douala (Cameroon) and Kampala (Uganda), take responsibility for collecting and managing household solid waste, instead of sending this off to landfills. Social ventures and micro-enterprises are currently overseeing the process of sorting waste, recycling and reuse. The project is ensuring environmental sanitation improvements are being sustained, with subsequent benefits in the health and well being of slum inhabitants. The project is fostering the emergence of a skilled and effective business sector wherein social enterprises, founded by and in poor urban communities, are deriving wealth from the provision of environmental services and derivative recycling and re-use activities. The waste is therefore becoming the catalyst for their income generation and creating employment opportunities.

title: Increasing employment opportunities, income and participation in decision-making for women and youths in the context of an emerging oil economy in Hoima and Buliisa Districts in Uganda
description: The project will address the poverty situation in two districts in Western Uganda that have recently experienced the discovery of oil. It will help 6,000 poor women and young people take advantage of the opportunities this brings by improving their access to employment and to skills training. The potentially negative social and environmental impacts of the oil industry will be addressed by ensuring that all residents are fully involved in decision-making about the future of the districts.

title: Promoting Economic Recovery and Local Governance in Timbuktu
description: In December 2014, Living Earth received follow-on funding from the UK Governmentâ€™s Conflict Poolto enable us to continue to build upon the successes of our community peace-building approach, linking dialogue to concrete actions. This new phase of the project, which will run for six months until May 2015, sees us join forces with our current partner AMSS, and with new partners International Alert and ARGA, Alliance Malienne pour Refonder la Gouvernance en Afrique. Over the next six months we will work together to expand the dialogue â€“ action approach to three new districts and to carry out participatory research on local markets and economic opportunities, on attitudes towards internally displaced people and on traditional governance systems. These research pieces will be used to inform our own programme development and will be shared more widely within the NGO and donor community and with national government.

title: Nepal Aid Transparency Pilot Project
description: To help national stakeholders working towards aid transparency in Nepal make use of appropriate tools and technologies for enhanced efficiency and effectiveness in their initiatives. ;To build capacity of national stakeholders, specially NGOs in making use of appropriate tools and technologies to better manage and present aid data using IATI format 2. To maintain and update Nepal Aid website (www.nepalaid.net) with relevant features, resources and content to to reflect on activities and initiatives around Aid Transparency in Nepal. 3. Mobilize local technical community to develop appropriate visualization tools to better present aid data 4. Initiate a small pilot open data initiative to make government spending and foreign aid on a specific thematic area (eg. Water and sanitation) available to general public in coordination with relevant stakeholders. 5. Disseminate information on how different tools and technologies can help organizations achieve better aid transparency.

title: Mobile Social Networking
OpenNepal Phase I
description: Open Nepal looks to translate the impact of international initiatives like International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI), Open Government Partnership, Open Aid Partnership and others into Nepalese context. Open Nepal is a collective effort of a coalition of organisations including Freedom Forum, NGO Federation of Nepal, Young Innovations and the aidinfo programme at Development Initiatives,that looks at catalysing and supporting an ecosystem around transparency and access to Information. We aim at translating the impact of international initiatives like International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI), Open Government Partnership and other similar ones in Nepalese context. Our work to date suggests that there are four essential elements to catalyse and support an ecosystem around open development in Nepal During Phase I of the project, YoungInnovations is specifically looking into development, deployment and maintenance of open data portal (www.opendatanepal.org ) along with some work on capacity development and awareness raising

title: Climate Action Teams (CATs) - Project for Youth in Kenya
description: In 2010 InterClimate Network (ICN), in partnership with ERMIS Africa, launched a 4 year innovative project, Climate Action Teams, which aims to tackle two of the worldâ€™s most pressing challenges: youth unemployment and helping communities to limit and adapt to climate change. School-leavers in groups of 25 are forming in 15 localities across Kenya. After business training and market research, business plans focused on environmental needs in their community will be developed for micro financing. The group will operate from a shared office and demonstration area in each locality. Business mentoring will continue for 3 years leading to viable businesses at the end of that time. Young people will share their knowledge and skills with others, influencing opinion leaders and engaging communities to promote sustainable development and ultimately reduce poverty.
sector-text: Education and training leading to sustainable green businesses

title: Strengthening Village Education in South Sudan
description: Strengthening Village Education aims to improve access to and quality of primary education in 100 marginalised communities in South Sudan, especially for girls, by empowering School Mothers and PTAs to advocate for their rights to education and to participation in decision-making that affects their communities. Expected outcomes: (1) Increased capacity of School Mothers and PTAs to understand and advocate for their rights, especially educational rights; (2) Increased capacity of Resource and Open Learning (ROLE) Centres to deliver education projects; (3) Improved government-Civil Society engagement on local education provision; (4) Improved girlsâ€™ access to and attendance at primary schools. The project aims to produce a change in government policy and practice through introducing regular Civil Society â€“ Ministry of Education (MoE) engagement meetings on education provision, resulting in more inclusive decision-making.

title: Somali Nomadic Education Programme
description: Provision of basic education and training to children and young people in nomadic pastoralist communities across Somalia
sector-text: Community led education including basic literacy and numeracy skills for children and young people, as well as vocational training and early childhood development

org-name: All We Can (formerly Methodist Relief and Development Fund)
reporting-organisation: All We Can (formerly Methodist Relief and Development Fund)
title: Improving Water, Sanitation and Hygiene in Central Uganda
description: This project is increasing access to clean water and adequate sanitation for 26,376 community members and 3,600 children in 63 underserved villages of Uganda. To ensure the benefits of the project are maintained, delivery of water and sanitation facilities is combined with hygiene and sanitation education and the formation and capacity building of 138 Community Based Organisations and 9 School Health Clubs. Beneficiaries are also be trained to lobby for better government services related to water, sanitation and health provisions.

org-name: All We Can (formerly Methodist Relief and Development Fund)
reporting-organisation: All We Can (formerly Methodist Relief and Development Fund)
title: Realising rights and improving livelihoods of the elderly in rural communities
description: This project is improving the lives of the elderly in 26 remote rural communities of the North West Province of Cameroon, an area characterised by extreme poverty, high migration and government neglect. The project directly benefits 13,500 poor, elderly people, 60% of whom are women. The project supports the formation of elderly peopleâ€™s clubs; provides micro-credit for enterprise development; raises awareness of the rights of the elderly; advocates with and on behalf of the elderly to government and the general public; and provides skills training and inputs for agriculture and income generation activities.

title: Reducing Womenâ€™s Susceptibility to HIV Infection as a Result of Gender Inequality in Ghana
description: This project aims to contribute in a reduction in the number of women being infected by HIV/AIDS in Ghana by working with communities to recognise and understand attitudes and practices that increase the risk of HIV infection; by pushing for the government to properly resource HIV and AIDS programmes; by raising awareness on the links between gender inequality and HIV; and by strengthening the capacity of the local partners to become a stronger organisation.
implementing_organisations: ;Gender and Human Rights Documentation Centre (Gender Centre);Pro-Link ;Rural Watch Ghana
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Good governance through increasing womenâ€™s participation in Ghanaâ€™s political processes
description: This project aims to increase women's participation and representation in local and national politics by providing practical support and training to women who wish to get involved in politics. The project does this by raising awareness of women's right to political participation, by educating communities on supporting women's participation and by pushing all political parties to ensure that 40% of their members are women. We support our local partner to build their capacity and become a stronger organisation.
implementing_organisations: ;WiLDAF-Ghana (Women in Law and Development in Africa)
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Tackling Violence Against Women in Peru: Strengthening Policies and Practices
description: This project aims to reduce poverty, exclusion and marginalisation of women and their families in Peru. We support our local partner to lobby officials and parliamentarians in order to improve the development and implementation of laws, policies and programmes to tackle violence against women. We also support them to raise awareness about violence against women, legislation and the effectiveness of regional services and programmes. Our partner also trains women leaders and women's organisations to monitor government policies and programmes to ensure their demands and proposals are included at all levels.
implementing_organisations: ;DEMUS (Institute for the Defence of Womenâ€™s Rights)
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Increasing womenâ€™s participation in parliament and local government in Zimbabwe
description: The aim of this project is to increase women's participation in politics and decision-making at all levels by providing information and skills training to women MPs, prospective candidates and councillors; by providing a place for women leaders and community women to meet and discuss women's issues; and by lobbying political parties and government to adopt and implement effective gender quotas to achieve 50% of women representation by 2013.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Increasing womenâ€™s participation in Zimbabweâ€™s peace building process
description: The aim of the project is to improve peace and security of women and families, which contributes to implementation of MDG3. This will be achieved by empowering women to take action regarding peace and security, raising awareness with public offcials, iincreasing public awareness on the impact of political violence on women and the importance of womenâ€™s participation on peace building in Zimbabwe. The project will also increase awareness in the UK of the challenges and importance of womenâ€™s participation as part of building sustainable peace and decreasing poverty. The change that this project will achieve is that it will contribute to the building of sustainable peace and increased security for women and their families, necessary conditions for achieving MDG3.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Good governance through increasing womenâ€™s participation in Ghanaâ€™s political processes

The project does this by raising awareness of women's right to political participation, by educating communities on supporting women's participation and by pushing all political parties to ensure that 40% of their members are women. We support our local partner to build their capacity and become a stronger organisation.

We also support them to raise awareness about violence against women, legislation and the effectiveness of regional services and programmes. title: Increasing womenâ€™s participation in Parliament and local government in Zimbabwe
description: The aim of this project is to increase women's participation in politics and decision-making at all levels by providing information and skills training to women MPs, prospective candidates and councillors; by providing a place for women leaders and community women to meet and discuss women's issues; and by lobbying political parties and government to adopt and implement effective gender quotas to achieve 50% of women representation by 2013.

title: Access to justice for victims of violence (Kenya)
description: This project seeks to empower women with knowledge and information on their rights in line with the new constitution, enhancing their capacity to respond to issues of VAW in the Family, Community and Society level in the targeted areas.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Promoting women human rights and paving the way for womenâ€™s participation in 2012 general elections (Kenya)
description: This project aims to mitigate sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) in the province of Kibera, Nairobi, by strengthening support systems and services delivery and increase women political participation at the local and national level, in order to include socio economic and political agendas of women in decision-making arenas.
sector-text: Women's equality organisation's and institutions

title: Advancing the Rights of Women in Post Conflict Setting in Uganda
description: This project will empower women conflict survivors in north and north eastern Uganda by increasing their participation in government decision making and tackling VAW. Leadership training for women and the provision of spaces for 180 women and 90 men to interact with government will not only raise awareness among policy makers of the practical needs of women in post-conflict Uganda, but will also help women have a deeper understanding of the cycle of planning, acquire skills in lobbying and advocating for their needs and enable women to hold decision makers to account. This project will also help tackle VAW through improved data collection on the underlying causes on GBV in Pader, Katakwi and Kitgum and livelihood support to communities struggling to rebuild their lives following violent conflict.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions;Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Combating Gender Based Violence against Women and Girls in Four Regions of Uganda
description: This project aims to reduce gender-based violence against women and girls (GBVAWG) by making community members aware of womenâ€™s rights and GBVAWG, as well as increasing knowledge of existing legal and psycho-social support services in four regions of Uganda.
implementing_organisations: ;National Association of Women's Organizations in Uganda
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Supporting women affected by HIV or AIDS (Ghana)
description: This project aims to provide counselling, legal aid, court representation, and referrals to medical, social, and legal services to women affected by HIV/AIDS; offer paralegal training to community members; raise awareness on the links between HIV/AIDS and discriminatory and violent practices towards women; and train service providers in gender equality, womenâ€™s human rights, and their obligations.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Empowering Dalit women to act against gender-based violence Peacebuilding and Democracy Project
description: This program aims to set up Dalit womenâ€™s groups; offer training on womenâ€™s rights, counselling for violence against women; organise community awareness meetings and events on violence against Dalit women; and offer counselling through support centres.
sector-text: 15164 - Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Strengthening implementation of the Domestic Violence Act (Nepal)
description: This program aims to relate service delivery experience to policy recommendation; support the implementation of the Domestic Violence (DV) Act; increase awareness of the DV Law among community people and service providers; hold an awareness raising program; strengthen SAATHIâ€™s network through meetings, communications, etc.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Changing community attitudes and practices to reduce discrimination and violence against women and increase access to justice (Sierra Leone)
description: This project aims to strengthen the realization of womenâ€™s rights thereby reducing the incidence of discrimination which leaves women vulnerable to violence, in the Moyamba district of southern Sierra Leone. It will achieve this by getting the community and its leaders to actively support and uphold womenâ€™s rights and strengthening the ability of women and girls to defend their rights and seek justice when their rights have been violated in 3 chiefdoms.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Increasing access to justice for rural women in Sierra Leone
description: The project will seek to increase rural womenâ€™s access to justice by protecting and promoting the welfare and rights of women and girls who suffer as a result of violence perpetrated against them. The objective is to support individual women survivors of violence to access justice; change attitudes in communities towards violence against women; and ensure that all women understand their rights and how claim them and that those who have a responsibility to protect and promote those rights do so. This will be done by using a number of strategies including specific awareness raising activities with different community stakeholders (traditional/opinion leaders, CBOs such as womenâ€™s and youth groups, etc) on basic human rights principles ,providing legal, medical and other support to survivors while they access justice. This project is co-unded by Womankind (through the DFID PPA) and The Sigrid Rausing Trust and the costs published represent only the Womankind PPA component.
implementing_organisations: ;Women Against Violence and Exploitation in Society (WAVES)
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Increased protection and support to women survivors of violence in 4 districts in Sierra Leone
description: The project aims to work in 4 districts comprising 8 rural communities to eliminate violence against women by directly supporting women to be active participants in calling for the realisation of their rights and gender equality. It will achieve this by working with women to heal wounds, access support services, empower them and protect their human rights. It will also address the discrimination and culture of impunity that exists by increasing public awareness of womenâ€™s needs, and improve policies and practices from public officials and service providers. This project is co-financed by Womankind (through the DFID PPA) and an additional donor and the costs published represent only the Womankind PPA component.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Monitoring the Implementation of the Elimination of Violence Against Women Law (Afghanistan)
description: This project will create a monitoring system to track the effectiveness and implementation of the new Ending Violence Against Women (EVAW) law on a year-by-year basis. AWN will use surveys, interviews, group-discussions and observation methods to assess the national government's attitude towards the EVAW law and its ability and willingness to enforce it. This project will also document how various interventions by national and international organisations have helped to strengthen Afghanistan's response to tackle violence against women.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Legal Aid Centre for Female Survivors of Violence in Jalalabad
description: This project aims to set up a legal aid centre in Jalalabad, where cases of violence against women will be register with the cityâ€™s family court. This project also aims to promote a culture of free legal aid through partnership with the Law University of Jalalabad, organise initial meetings with lawyers and representatives, and campaign for the implementation of the EVAW law and family law.
implementing_organisations: ;Humanitarian Assistance for the Women and Children of Afghanistan
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Empowering Media for Inclusive Governance (Liberia)
description: This project will focus on strengthening the role of the Liberia Women Democracy Radio (LWDR FM 91.1) and 35 journalists in educating the public and highlighting issues critical to womenâ€™s wellbeing in Liberia. This project will expand the stationâ€™s reach, providing women in other counties the opportunity to benefit from the stationâ€™s enriching programs. It will also train a number of journalists in specialized reporting with emphasis on gender sensitive reporting and legal frameworks and policies that promote womenâ€™s rights. This project is co-financed by Womankind (through the DFID PPA) and another donor. The costs published represent only the Womankind PPA component.
sector-text: Women's equality orhanisation and institutions;Women's equality orhanisation and institutions

title: Reducing Violence against Women (VAW) through Provision of Shelter Services
description: This project aims to increase women survivorsâ€™ capacity to rebuild their lives, extricate from violence and assert their rights. This will be achieved through a safe house run by Musasa in Harare providing temporary shelter and holistic services such as counselling, legal support and skills training which will increase survivorsâ€™ confidence to return to their communities and families and lead fulfilling lives with reduced vulnerability to violence and poverty.
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

description: Unrestricted funding received from DFID has been used to support staff salary costs and team activities
sector-text: General budget support

title: Support to Womankind's UK Programme Operating Costs
description: Unrestricted funding received from DFID has been used to support staff salary costs of Womankind's Head of Programmes and one Programme Manager, in addition to Country Visit by Programme Managers to partners in 14 countries. Due to the unrestricted nature of the PPA grant, the exact allocation of staff costs to DFID PPA funding varies.

title: Support to Womankind's Communications Activities
description: Unrestricted funding received from DFID has been used to support staff salary costs of Womankind'sHead of Communciations and New Media (50% of salary)
sector-text: General budget support

title: Project Support and M&E
description: Unrestricted funding from DFID has been used to support the new position of Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning Advisor (100% of salary) and to conduct an Independent Progress Review of the DFID PPA grant
sector-text: General budget support

title: Womankind Overhead Costs
description: Unrestricted funding received from DFID has been used to support overhead costs, as follows (Percentages represent percentage estimates of full salary from PPA funding - these will vary due to the unrestricted nature of the strategic funding) Head of Policy (35%) Head of Programmes (40%) Policy Manager (100%) Programmes Manager (100%) MEL Manager (100%) Communications Manager (50%)
sector-text: General budget support

title: Support to Womankind partner organisations in 14 countries to implement programmes that promote and protect women's rights
description: Womankind supports women's rights organisations in 14 countries to implement programmes that support survivors of violence, prevent violence against women and girls, and strengthen women's participation. Unrestricted funding from DFID is used to fund specific programmes, support partner organisation's core operating costs, and provide match funding for other grants, according to the specific country context

title: RIGHTS-BASED HIV PREVENTION & IMPACT MITIGATION AMONG PRISONERS, THEIR PARTNERS AND FAMILIES AND PRISON WORKERS IN KENYA

org-name: Friends of the Earth England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

title: Sustainable livelihoods through community empowerment in rural Paraguay
description: The project will strengthen the ability of rural communities to hold decision-makers to account for the implementation and improvement of socio-environmental legislation to support the promotion of sustainable rural livelihoods in Paraguay.

title: People In Aid
description: Achieving mission of People In Aid through implementing the 3-year strategy and annual workplans.

title: Sexual Exploitation No! Mobilising young people and duty bearers in Rio de Janeiro
description: The project will reduce sexual exploitation of children and young people in Rio de Janeiro. 40 girls and boys will access psychosocial support and information about their rights and sexual health. 400 children and youth will lead awareness campaigns on sexual exploitation, mobilising 2000 community members to understand, address and prevent it. 334 child-rights professionals, duty-bearers and authorities will be trained to tackle and prevent the problem.
implementing_organisations: ;OrganizaÃ§Ã£o de Direitos Humanos Projeto Legal;Instituto Promundo
sector-text: Includes elements of other sectors: STD control, sexual health education, participation of children and young people in advocacy, support to local NGOs

title: Bringing the MDGs back on track: Improving health and nutrition outcomes for women and children among vulnerable families living in urban and rural areas of West Bengal
description: The project aims to reduce infant mortality and improve maternal health by ensuring accessibility and quality of essential government health services and social welfare schemes. PNC for women will be improved and malnutrition decreased amongst children below two years of age in two of the poorest districts in West Bengal. Young women, particularly those from minority groups will be empowered and act as 'Change Agents'Â to contribute towards achieving the MDGs.

title: Girls Education Challenge- Securing access and retention to good quality education
description: The project will support 15,053 extremely vulnerable girls aged 4-19 who are either not attending school or unable to thrive at school and do not receive stimulating or transformative education due to factors such as early marriage, child migration, sexual abuse and exploitation. They will instead access learning, knowledge and skills necessary to enable the realisation of their full-potential.
sector-text: Includes STD control, sexual health education, participation of children and young people in advocacy, support to local NGOs

title: Preventing violence against children
description: Protecting children in conflict with the law from violence, and helping them return to a safe and secure family environment

title: Empower Children and Adults to Ensure Children Fully Access their Right to Protection in Tanzania
description: The project started in 2011 to facilitate the Tanzanian government to develop and coordinate the delivery of effective action plans to protect vulnerable girls and boys from violence, and empower vulnerable girls and boys in Arusha and Kilimanjaro regions to meaningfully inform these plans and to hold duty-bearers to account
sector-text: ;Particularly children's rights

title: Increasing Womenâ€™s Participation and Voice in DRCâ€™s Political Processes
description: The overall aim of this programme is to empower women in two geographic target areas and to create the space for increased womenâ€™s participation and voice in the institutions, policies and plans of the Congolese State at local and national level. The main outcomes will be: 1) Increased number of women playing an effective role in local leadership positions 2) Local women, especially illiterate women are more aware of their civil and political rights and are actively engaged with local authorities on issues that are a priority to them; 3) Improved understanding of and commitment to gender equality amongst key stakeholders (traditional and community leaders, local authorities, political parties) and 4) Effective policy and legislative measures, including a quota system, in place at national level to secure increased womenâ€™s political participation. The main direct beneficiaries will be local women living in poor communities in the target areas, in particular illiterate women and women candidates for local elections.
sector-text: Strengthening Civil Society and in particular empowering women to take positions in local leadership.

title: Increasing food security, income and resilience to climate change for 51,800 people in southern Malawi.
description: TrÃ_caire, in partnership with 7 Malawian civil society organisations, will implement a three year food security, income generation and climate change adaptation programme in Southern Malawi, to improve progress towards MDGs 1 and 7. 12,225 households (67,000 people), including 8,509 headed by women, elderly or children, or those infected/affected by HIV, will benefit from greater access to food and income, and improved ability to adapt to and recover from droughts and floods.

title: Enhancing the socio-economic status of women and girls to play an active role in advancing their overall development
description: Concern Worldwide and WSA are working to empower the poorest and most vulnerable women and girls in Dessie Zuriya Woreda, Amhara Region, Ethiopia through improving their socio-economic status, working through schools, community-based organisations and local government. The project will directly reach 18,000 women and 2,000 men and a further 52,000 will feel the positive effects of the project. The project helps to increase womenâ€™s business skills through training in income generating activities to create cash flow. Womenâ€™s community savings groups are established to generate capital and low interest loans for the members to set up their own businesses, leading to an increase in economic empowerment, as well as providing economic, social, and emotional support in times of need. The project helps to foster positive community and family relationships through family and community dialogues. Teachers help to raise awareness of socio-economic problems affecting young girls to help prevent school drop-out due to issues such as early child marriage.

title: Improving agriculture-based livelihoods, nutrition and participation in governance for 210,146 marginalised members of communities in Northwest Tanzania.
description: An integrated approach will help to reduce hunger & improve the livelihoods of the poorest in NW Tanzania. Food production will increase & nutrition will improve through introduction of new techniques, learning, & materials. Women will be empowered economically (access to productive assets e.g. land), & socially (increase in decision making), helping the communities voices to be heard by the local government, fostering long-term benefit.
implementing_organisations: ;Agricultural Non State Actors Forum â€“ (ANSAF);Rulenge-Diocesan Development Office(RUDDO);Relief to Development Society (REDESO)

title: Reducing Poverty for Extremely Poor Men and Women by Increasing Sustainable Income, Improving Food Security, and Enhancing Social and Political Participation in the District of Layyah, Pakistan
description: This project targets one of Punjabâ€™s most remote and vulnerable Districts, which falls in the top-five Districts with more than 31 per cent of the population living beneath the poverty line (Sustainable Development Policy Institute, 2013). Under this project, the six-most vulnerable Union Councils (UCs) of Choubara Tehsil have been identified for various interventions aimed at assisting the extreme poor who have severely limited resources/assets or very low returns on assets, which are contributing to their vulnerability and poverty. To contribute to poverty reduction and improve food security in target areas, the primary project activities include: improvement of agricultural techniques; introduction of high-efficiency irrigation systems; capacity-building/awareness-raising of communities on various topics (Disaster Risk Management, advocacy, participatory development/management, equality/human rights, among others); and development of entrepreneurship skills to diversify livelihoods/income sources. Throughout the project, Concern/partners are also facilitating the involvement of Government departments to bridge the gap between communities/authorities, which will help ensure that communities become more self-reliant in the long term with the linkages necessary to advocate for their development needs in the future.

title: Empowering Faith Leaders to Reduce HIV-related Stigma and Discrimination in Lagos, Nigeria
description: The project aims to reduce HIV/AIDS stigma and discrimination and build capacity for church community care of PLWHA in 10 Lagos local government areas. Key faith-based community influencers will have skills and capacity to be effective leaders for community action against HIV/AIDS stigma and discrimination. Church leaders will form a network in 10 lGAs to coordinate an anti S&D campaign and foster community-based care and support. Duty bearers will be made aware of the need to strengthen action against S&D. 90% of targeted church communities will offer non-stigmatising community care. Rates of voluntary testing and disclosure of status will increase in the 10 LGAs. Beneficiaries: PLWHA who experience discrimination and lack of community-based services.

title: Empowering Civil Society Organizations and Volunerable Communities in Pakistan for Effective Adaptation to Climate Change
description: This project aims to increase the capacity of poor and vulnerable communities in Pakistan to implement climate change adaptations to protect their livelihoods and contribute to bottom-up policy development. Training on climate change will result in CSOs and target communities having the required knowledge, skills and capacity to influence local, national and international decision making. Development of LAPAs will ensure climate change policy reflects local perspectives, knowledge, needs and realities, with 30 locally relevant adaptation micro-projects leading to enhanced sustainable livelihoods. Through building a CSO climate change National Advocacy Network civil society will be able to contribute to climate change discourse and policy development. Links will also be made with Pakistani diaspora groups in the UK, raising their awareness of climate change and building links to project communities.
recipient-country: Sindh and Punjab provinces of Pakistan

title: Empowering Civil Society Organizations and Volunerable Communities in Pakistan for Effective Adaptation to Climate Change
Widowed Survivors Empowerment Project (WSEP)
description: WSEP will transform the lives of genocide widows, and their dependants, by eradicating extreme poverty and hunger and empowering them to integrate into Rwandan society.

title: Philippines cyclone response
description: Emergency mapping and information management support for response coordination

title: Madagascar tropical storms response
description: Emergency mapping and information management support for response coordination

title: Emergency missions
description: MapAction missions in response to humanitarian emergencies
sector-text: Emergency mapping and information management

title: An Early Years Service for families in Dushanbe: Creating an alternative to the institutionalisation of vulnerable and disabled young children under 6 years old
description: The purpose of the project is to create an innovative system of community-based services for families in Dushanbe as an alternative to the institutionalisation of vulnerable and disabled young children under 6 years old. The expected project outcomes will be that (a) parents are strengthened through new skills in child care, economic and social support; and (b) children with additional needs because of disability or deprivation are enabled to grow up in their families and access mainstream education. This project is needed because there is an established practice of abandoning young children to institutions. When children enter a baby home, they start on a road of social and educational exclusion, developmental impairment and human suffering. This project contributes to the achievement of MDGs 1 and 2 through the social inclusion of vulnerable families in line with the UNCRC and Tajik governmentâ€™s Poverty Reduction goals.

title: Improving the lives of people in Charkent District, Afghanistan, by improving (maternal, newborn & child) health, hygiene, nutrition and livelihoods
description: Improving the lives of people in Charkent District, Afghanistan, by improving (maternal, newborn & child) health, hygiene, nutrition and livelihoods

title: The Southern Africa Gender Protocol Alliance
description: Synopsis The Southern Africa Gender Protocol Alliance and Partnerships portfolio is a flagship programme of Gender Links providing â€œlinksâ€ù to the organisationâ€™s core programmes; contributing to holding governments accountable and empowering citizens to claim their rights using the SADC Gender Protocol with 28 targets to be achieved by 2015. Following the successful campaign for the signing of the Protocol in 2008, GL coordinates the Southern Africa Gender Protocol Alliance. The Alliance is a â€œnetwork of networksâ€ù which began as a loose coalition. It now comprises 15 country focal networks; eight theme and two interest group clusters led by organisations with comparative advantage in their respective area. The Alliance organisational chart and partners are attached at Annex A of this report. Objectives The Alliance seeks to: â€¢ Hold Southern African governments accountable for the achievement of gender equality through signing, ratifying, and implementating the SADC Protocol on Gender and Development, a sub-regional roadmap for MDG 3 (gender equality). â€¢ Lobby Southern African governments to be to adopt an Addendum to the SADC Gender Protocol on Gender and Climate change. â€¢ Strengthen the capacity of civil society, especially gender NGOs, to demand that governments deliver on commitments to gender equality. â€¢ Empower citizens especially women, to become aware of the SADC Gender Protocol, engage critically with governments to claim their rights; and demand effective and responsive governance. Activities In 2011/2012 the Alliance: â€¢ Held eight reference group meetings to validate the findings of the SADC Gender Protocol Country Barometers. â€¢ Produced the 2011 SADC Gender Protocol Barometer, introducing the Southern African Gender and Development Index (SGDI). The report also featured 44 case studies demonstrating the SADC Gender Protocol @ Work. The Alliance launched the Barometer in Mozambique, Seychelles, South Africa, and Zimbabwe and Angola. â€¢ Held the Alliance annual meeting in August 2011, conducted a SWOT analysis of the institutional mechanisms and Programme of Action. A strategy session identified two regional campaigns to focus on in 2011/2012: the Fifty-fifty as well as gender and climate change campaigns. The meeting elected an Alliance Think Tank to work with the Secretariat in guiding its work. â€¢ Assisted two countries, Namibia and Seychelles, to develop costed Gender Action Plans aligned to the SADC Gender Protocol. Seychelle is the first SADC country to align its Gender Policy to the 28 targets of the SADC Gender Protocol. â€¢ Tracked implementation of the key provisions of the Gender Protocol through the monthly e-newsletter, Roadmap to Equality: Southern Africa Gender and Development Barometer. â€¢ Held 143 village meetings. â€¢ Disseminated over 6000 simplified versions of the SADC Gender Protocol in SADCâ€™s three main languages (English, French and Portuguese) as well as 23 Indigenous languages. â€¢ Strengthenied the institutional base the Alliance Network: Three more country networks signed MOUs. Strong lead organisations have emerged for the faith based and menâ€™s sector. Theme clusters have started to take the lead in their areas (see ISS example below). Peace and security regional theme cluster Since the Institute of Security Studies (ISS) took the lead on gender, peace and security within the Alliance, four national working groups have been established in Zimbabwe, Malawi, DRC and Madagascar. These are all countries experiencing characterised by political conflict and violence. Each of the country focal points has convened at least one meeting as part of replicating the structure at national level. In Madagascar, this culminated in a National Conference on Gender, Peace and Security in November 2011. Early results include increased awareness on Article 28 of the SADC Gender Protocol; successful lobbying and advocacy by clusters for development of national action plans on UNSCR 1325 by SADC countries; increased womenâ€™s representation in the peace and security sectors at regional and country level. ISS comments: â€œThe Alliance needs more strategic planning exercises â€“ one once a year is not sufficient. We will continue to work with Gender Links to strengthen the Alliance. The formation of an alliance think tank, when operative should go far in consolidating the work.â€ù For full profile go to http://www.genderlinks.org.za/page/sadc-gender-protocol-partners The SADC Protocol @ work â€“ Gender and climate change At the launch of the 2010 SADC Gender Protocol Barometer, Alliance partners in Mozambique pointed out that the SADC Gender Protocol is silent on sustainable development and climate change. In 2011, the Alliance embarked on a campaign calling for an Addendum to the SADC Gender Protocol on Gender and Climate Change as a way of influencing regional policy building on past successes. The October 2011 Gender Ministers meeting in Winsdhoek noted the importance of integrating gender into climate policies. In November 2011 the Alliance regional Secretariat gave technical inputs at the Gender/Womenâ€™s Affairs Ministers and Senior Officials meetings to engender the SADC Regional Strategy for the 17th Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework for the Convention on Climate Change (COP 17). Building on the momentum of COP 17 the Southern Africa Gender Protocol Alliance has launched a petition calling on SADC governments to adopt, as matter of urgency, the principle of an Addendum or amendments to the Gender Protocol â€“ see http://www.genderlinks.org.za/page/sadc-climate-change. The Gender and Climate Change petition campaign is up on the GL website as another way of enlisting citizens to support the campaign for an Addendum to the SADC Gender Protocol on Gender and Climate Change, with 100 signatures so far. Outputs â€¢ The 2011 SADC Gender Protocol Barometer.This features the SGDI and 44 case studies of the SADC Gender Protocol @ Work. â€¢ A gender policy (Seychelles) and gender action plans aligned to the SADC Protocol in Namibia and Seychelles. â€¢ An additional four MOUs between Gender Links as the Secretariat and Alliance focal organisations from Angola (Platform for Women Action), Tanzania (Tanzania Gender Networking Project) and Zambia (Women in Law Southern Africa â€“ Zambia) and with Botswana Council of NGOs as regional theme cluster lead for the Education Sector. This brings the total number MOUs signed to 21. â€¢ A draft Addendum to the Protocol on Gender and Climate Change. Outreach Direct beneficiaries: GL held 143 village level workshops (three more than the target number). GL also held six country reference group meetings for the Barometer and five launches. In total the programme reached 5103 people directly: 3202 (63%) women and 1901 (37%) men. Indirect beneficiaries: The programme reached an estimated 55,245 beneficiaries through indirect methods. These include: website hits (the alliance website (www.sadcgenderprotocol.org) received 35 701 unique hits from March 2011 and February 2012).
