Data on use of services by survivors First-hand accounts of GBV experience. Media case studies of GBV coverage. Political speeches -Research reports, pamphlets and commentary pieces -Launch events, presentations of findings in study sites -23 planning workshops with 317 people participating -317 people trained on IT for advocacy -109 first hand accounts -27 cyber hubs set up Reasons for failing to achieve anticipated outputs in this programme area 1. Project inception is dependent on stakeholder consultation processes to obtain political buy in. This has often delayed implementation. 2. Access to administrative data requires GL to request and then wait until mostly more senior officers give clearance. This has been a challenge and has delayed the implementation of the administrative data component and affected the project as a whole. 3. The collection of first-hand accounts of violence requires GL to partner with support organisations. The turnover time for signing of MOUs by the partners has posed delays. Another challenge is the access to a critical mass of survivors who are willing to tell their stories. 4. Human resources capacity has posed an impediment to progress. Project manager is contributing most of the content work in addition to the managerial tasks. The Mauritius report is still outstanding because the process of findings validation is now dependant on the availability of the Prime Minister. Adjusting milestones The target to complete KZN and Western Cape Reports will have to be moved into the 2012-2013 work plan because GL still awaits the administrative data from the two provinces and an organisation to partner with in the collection of I stories in Kwazulu Natal. The remaining time in this year will be dedicated to finalising and validating the Mauritius report. Outreach How do you ensure a cascading effect in your work through; please give examples GL uses different platforms to ensure a cascading effect in this work including the media, social networks, the GL website and strategic distribution of publications. For each new publication, the editor sends press releases and opinion pieces based on the results through the GL list-serve. The media pick and use the commentaries. For example the SABC news, Daily News, News 24, Rutgers and ICTJ News republished the commentary piece entitled â€œpolice statistics still fall shortâ€ù which recommends the use of survey methods for collecting GBV data as opposed to relying on police data. Women 24, SABC News, Iq4 News and Cape Times republished the commentary piece entitled â€œPolice statistics still do not include domestic violenceâ€ù which called for the South African police to honour their commitment to include domestic violence statistics in the annual crime reports following the recommendations of the Gauteng study. All Africa, Mopane Tree, Silo Breaker, Africa Focus, I4u & African news wire republished the commentary titled â€œState of Emergency call to end violence against womenâ€ù which calls for action to address the high prevalence of GBV shown by the Botswana study. GL is using social networks for example the Enough is Enough Facebook page which was created following the outcomes of the Gauteng research. The page is a campaign initiative aimed to promote activism against GBV. To date more than 11,000 people â€˜likeâ€™ this pa ge. For each new publication, the web administrator puts up an e-announcement on the website. The Botswana and Gauteng reports are available on the GL website. Project staff compiles the results from each study site into reader friendly research reports. GL launches the event at well publicised events attended by relevant stakeholders. GL also strategically distributes the publications to national and regional stakeholders. Outcomes â€“ results â€¢ Buy in by the Botswana, South African and Mauritius government. â€¢ Indicators built into national action plans in Botswana, Mauritius and SA -Indicators project cascaded to other SADC countries.
extending_organisations: ;The Netherlands Government Ministry of Foreign Affairs' MDG3 Fund;UK AID;Norwegian Council for Africa

title: The Southern African Gender Protocol Aliance
description: Eleven of the 13 governments that signed the SGP (more than two thirds) have ratified the sub-regional instrument, making the SGP one of the few SADC Protocols to go into force in record time, as a result of lobbying and advocacy by the SGPA coordinated by GL. In a video address to the SADC Protocol@Work Regional Summit , Malawi President Joyce Banda, committed to ensuring that Malawi ratifies the SGP before the August Heads of State Summit to be hosted by Malawi. During the SADC Protocol@Work summit, high level delegations from Botswana and Mauritius, the only two countries that have not signed the Protocol, pledged to make a concerted effort to do so. The Alliance has lobbying strategies for both countries. The SGDI, a measure of progress by the 15 countries against 23 indicators in six sectors (education, political participation, the economy, health, HIV and AIDS, and the media) for which empirical data is available moved from 66% to 67% (1% lower than target). Major achievements include the adoption of a quota for women in local government in Mauritius (see Outcome 3); the new Constitution in Zimbabwe that incorporates 75% of womenâ€™s demands ; reductions in maternal mortality and access to PMTCT. There is progress towards giving women greater voice in the media (see Outcome 2) but the region is still far from achieving its goals of gender parity in politics, the media and the economy; and of halving GBV by 2015. However, one of the most significant contributions of the SGP has been to provide a tool for citizens to demand accountability. Through the SGPA, all three GL programmes working together, the energy and muscle of the 300 media and local government COEâ€™s coming together in 12 national and a regional summit in the first quarter of 2013, GL has managed to gather substantially more case studies of the SADC Protocol@Work than target. An analysis of the 672 case studies gathered in 2012/2013 shows that the provisions of the Protocol most referred to correlate closely to GLâ€™s programmes â€“ media, GBV, productive resources and governance. This affirms GLâ€™s efforts to move from paper provisions to changing lives in its own work. The constitutional and legal rights provisions also feature strongly, thanks to strong SGPA networks in this area. However, the SGPA needs to work harder in the education, HIV and AIDS, health and peace building sectors, as well as building advocacy networks in countries like Angola and Seychelles, that did not host summits or submit entries. GL has strengthened the SGPA network through identifying country focal networks in all countries, including the five countries where GL does not have offices . The fact that three of these â€“ DRC, Tanzania and Malawi- hosted successful summits in March 2013 is an indicator of country networkâ€™s taking greater ownership. VSO Regional Aids Initiative Southern Africa (VSO RAISA) has not formally signed an MOU due to internal processes to lead on care work but has been an active member of the network. GL has made headway on MOUâ€™s with the menâ€™s sector and FBOs (see additional information). The campaign for an Addendum on Gender and Climate Change gained momentum with an online petition signed by 1027 citizens (55% men; 45% women) , and gender ministers formally backing this proposal. The SGPA is now preparing to take advantage of the HOS in Malawi, hosted by the regionâ€™s only woman leader to make the case for reopening the SGP. The campaign is an example of gender activists pushing the envelope through their insistence that the SGP be a responsive, â€œlivingâ€ù instrument.

title: The GL Opinion and Commentary Service
description: This year the focus will be on climate change as GL and the SGPA push for an Addendum on Gender and Climate to the SGP. GL will ensure close synergies with the Opinion and Commentary Service (OCS). The Lusophone service has demonstrated how the media COEâ€™s and OCS can work together through taking journalists on a field visit to cover the effects of mounting floods as result of climate change. These 15 stories, read 591 times on the website, generated debates on the effect of climate change on traditional medicine and subsistence agriculture. The OCS exceeded its numerical targets in the English, French and Portuguese services, in part because of a special Portuguese series during the SADC HOS held in Mozambique last year and a three-language daily newsletter during the February Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) meeting on GBV.

title: Gender and Governance
description: Womenâ€™s political participation is a key MDG and SGP target: women cannot achieve voice and choice if they are excluded from decision-making. The current local government COEâ€™s reach approximately 28,887,004 people in the SADC region, 21.3% of the population in these countries. After narrowing down this measure to the COEâ€™s that GL works with to ensure more accurate attribution, a key finding is that women in the COE councils constitute 28% of the total: six percentage points higher than the regional average of 22%. However, the figure is two percentage points below the 2013 PPA target of 30% for COEâ€™s that GL works with. The difference is largely due to the Mauritian local government election held in November 2013 in which GL in credited with successfully advocating for the gender neutral quota that led to an increase in womenâ€™s representation from 6.4% to 26.2%. All the municipal and district councils in Mauritius are local government COEs. GL Mauritius went beyond advocating for the quota by seeking out women candidates and training them for office. To ensure that this success goes beyond numbers and translates into gender responsive governance, GL is cascading the COE process to 55 villages. â€œLocal government ministries and authorities will collaborate and champion gender equality and mainstreaming at national and local level as well as provide human and material support for doing so.â€ù - Hon. Herve Aimee, Minister of Local Government and Outer Islands, Mauritius; keynote speaker at the SADC Gender Protocol@Work Summit. 'Citizens are moving away from such blatant stereotypes towards a more affirming position that women make a difference in politics by voting for them.' Cehl Meeah, Member of Parliament and leader of the Mauritian Solidarity Front (FSM). The local government Gender Score Card (GSC) measures gender responsiveness in councils. The GSC includes 25 questions that cover five key areas: the gender policy framework, governance, mainstreaming gender into existing programmes, gender specific programmes and employment practices and environment. It is a participatory tool in which beneficiaries assess themselves with independent verification by GL during visits and finally by summit judges. Overall, the 124 councils verified in early 2013 scored 63%, eight percentage points higher than their baseline score of 55% in 2012. South African COEs scored highest (75%) while Lesotho made the most progress (20%). Every country except Swaziland (a traditional monarchy, where the score dropped from 58% to 54%) made progress. The Learning through listening: Findings of the 2013 Gender and Local government COE verification analyses the successes, challenges, strategies and next steps. Budget allocation to gender work by COEâ€™s compared to donor contributions The budget allocations cover a variety of areas including: â€¢Towards the councils participation in the SADC Gender Protocol Summit. â€¢For the implementation of the gender action plan. â€¢Logistical costs for COE workshops. â€¢Specific campaigns such as the 16 Days of No Violence Against Women A key VFM finding of the verification analysis (see table above) and indicator of the success of the programme is that Councils now allocate twice what GL has spent on the COE process (6.5 times the PPA spend) for taking forward gender work. Capricorn District Municipality in South Africa (the best performer in the 2012 and 2013 summits) allocated GBP 33 000 towards improving gender mainstreaming in service delivery. Ownership, capacity and performance are also being enhanced through training Drivers of Change: â€œI first interacted with Gender Links when they came to train us in Maseru on gender mainstreaming. Now I am one of the trainers for the council. In my work as a councillor, I ensure that there is supply of water for the community and that broken taps are maintained. As a council, we also issue licenses for small dams. We educate people to become aware of climate change. Our programme involves working with social workers in the care of orphans and care workers in the community. We resolve conflicts among people who fight for land or development sites. We ensure accessibility of roads within the village.â€ù Cllr Thatho Mokuena, Senekane Community Council, Lesotho

title: Gender Justice
description: The VAW indicators and baseline research provides data on the extent, response, support, prevention, political commitment and individual costs of VAWG using a prevalence/attitude study and various other research tools to come up with figures currently deficient in police and court records. GL initiated the GBV Indicators research in partnership with government, local government and civil society partners in Botswana, Mauritius and South Africa. GL completed the research in the South African Provinces of Limpopo, Western Cape and Kwa Zulu Natal (Target for Year 1) and cascaded the research to three additional countries (Target for Year 3), Zimbabwe, Lesotho and Zambia. All the elements of the research are complete in Zimbabwe and in process in Lesotho and Zambia. GL presented the findings of the research to date at a forum of African Gender Ministers convened by UNECA at the CSW, GL has been asked to join a UNECA reference group designing a study on the costs of GBV, an area that requires further exploration in the research. GL envisaged that the research would unfold in a linear way. The plan was to do the research in South Africa, Mauritius and Botswana followed by advocacy and lobbying. The envisaged result was a GBV National Action Plan that incorporated the indicators and baseline data in the three countries. Two factors affected the original plan: the burgeoning interest in conducting the baseline study in several SADC countries and the need to work with governments at their pace in a way that ensures ownership and muscle for the follow-up processes. In addition to the three countries where GL has moved ahead thanks to PPA flexible funds and accompanying grants from Sida, UNWOMEN and the UNDP, Namibia, Mozambique, Seychelles and Malawi have expressed interest in undertaking the research. With regard to the follow up processes in the countries where the research has been launched, an important first step has been to elevate political buy in and support. This has been most successful in Botswana and Mauritius. â€œIn Botswana, the (VAW Baseline Study) findings have sparked an unprecedented engagementâ€_ The results provided a springboard for a countrywide drive to address GBV. Cabinet sent the Women's Affairs Department back to the drawing board to come up with baseline data for every district beyond the 'narrow statistical sample' to better understand the dynamics in each locality. The President of Botswana (Ian Khama) has tasked everyone in the country to map the response that each current and prospective stakeholder would undertake as part of a multi-sector approach to address GBV as a response to the findings.â€ù Valencia Mogegeh, Director, Womenâ€™s Affairs Division, Botswana. Four ministers, the head of the Equal Opportunities Commission and an editor in chief of a major newspaper attended the launch of the Mauritian report, that has since been the subject of a cabinet memorandum. The high profile campaign that ran through the Sixteen Days of Activism from 25 November to 10 December 2012 brought together all GL programmes to â€œget the nation talking.â€ù Municipal libraries of the local government COEâ€™s hosted daily cyber dialogues in creole on each chapter of the report. MBC radio linked in with a one hour talk show. The report received extensive coverage in the mainstream media. The stage is now set for reviewing the existing National Action Plan on Gender. South Africa is more complex. GL had hoped that its membership of the National GBV Council would leverage support for cascading the research to the whole country, but this structure has been slow to get off the ground. GL has followed the parallel strategy of presenting the research to provincial governments (for example to the executive committee of Gauteng province, chaired by the Premier) and canvassing the Commission on Gender Equality (a Constitutional body) to use its muscle to get government support for the roll out. The wheels of bureaucracy move slowly, especially in larger countries.

title: Gender and Media Diversity Centre
description: Virtual and physical resource centre (VRC) The VRC is an online resource centre that comprises the research database, clippings database and the media alerts and highlights. The Centre uploaded 90 English and 11 French media alerts and highlights on its VRC database. The GMDC strengthened partnerships that exist with training institutions in the region training media students from Malawi Polytechnic (63 students), Malawi Institute of Journalism (25 students) and National University of Lesotho (16 students) on how to write media alerts and highlights. Photo library and multimedia database Currently there 8222 photos have been stored in the database. By December 2012, the GMDC had shortlisted 400 images from the database on all the SADC Gender Protocol themes for the photo e-shop. The images will be sold as part of the GMDC efforts to generate income. The GMDC is now storing audio-video footage collected from the field into an audio visual archive called CAT DV. The footage is tagged (country, programme and theme), split and then used to create customised products. This is an an innovative way of collecting evidence of the impact of GLâ€™s work in the field. Seminars The GMDC continued with the media freedom seminars in 2012. The academics who attended the Advisory Group discussed about gender and media freedom from their different countries. Some of them had the opportunity to go to the University of Pretoria through the GMDC to attend to listen to a public lecture by the Africa Union Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Expression and Access to Information, Advocate Pansy Faith Tlakula. Seminar Nature Female Male Total Mainstreaming or male streaming: Gender @ work in organisations Regional (South Africa) 21 38 59 Half full or half empty? Gender gains and losses in the African Platform on Access to information Regional (South Africa) 18 14 32 Youth leaders, HIV and AIDS Regional 28 18 46 Women in Politics roundtable discussions Regional 7 5 12 Gender and freedom of dressing in Malawi Malawi 31 31 62 From 30%-50% Women in Local Government Swaziland 42 26 68 Sexual harassment in institutions of higher learning Lesotho 43 9 52 Sexual harassment in institutions of higher learning Namibia 4 9 13 A total of 247 females and 185 males participated in all the seminars. The seminar on male streaming and mainstreaming targeted participants from local government COEs. Participants discussed gender mainstreaming in the COEs, the challenges as well as sharing best practices on the subject. In February 2012, male street vendors in Malawi stripped women wearing short skirts and trousers. The GMDC took the opportunity to host a seminar at Malawi Polytechnic to discuss freedom of dressing in Malawi. During the Sixteen Days of Activism, the GMDC and nine academic institutions held seminars on sexual harassment. The outcome of these seminars in Lesotho is reported on in the Opinion and Commentary Service report.

title: Developing Smallholder Farmers in South Ethiopia
description: The project will bring change to the lives of 1600 poor and vulnerable smallholder farmers and their families (9600 people) in southern highlands of Ethiopia, especially women, to become food secure, productive and self-confident agents of their own development through increased farm productivity, improved environmental management, creation of new employment opportunities, establishment and development of community support systems, women's empowerment and inclusion of socially marginalised groups
implementing_organisations: ;Kale Heywet Development Programme;Send a Cow Ethiopia

title: Kotoba Sustainable Food Security and Livelihoods Project
description: The aim of the Kotoba Food Security and Livelihoods Project is to empower the people living in the Kotoba region of Dendi district of western Ethiopia to achieve food security and sustainable livelihooods. 1000 families (5000 people) will be directly assisted to become self-reliant, to increase productivity of land and livestock so they have nutritious food to eat, improve their understanding and management of naturarl resources to conserve the environment and increase marketing and income generation opportunities
implementing_organisations: ;Alliance of Knowledge and Action for Sustainable Livelihoods Management (AKAM)

title: Improving UK NGO Effectiveness, Transparency and Shaping EU Aid Performance
description: DFID Accountable Grant to consortium of Bond, NIDOS and CADA to work with UK NGOs on Effectiveness and Transparency, and to work with European partners on shaping EU member states' aid performance

title: Advocacy for more and better aid in the UK and Europe
description: 3 year grant to deliver following objectives: 1. To provide UK NGOs with leadership, support and coordination to increase the effectiveness of their common advocacy asks and messaging towards the UK Government on UK development policies, international positioning and aid; 2. To build positive UK political and public support for aid and development in the lead up to the projected increases of UK ODA in 2013; 3. To ensure EU priorities, policies, institutional structures and funding to 2015 and beyond deliver positive international development outcomes.

title: Joint campaign on food and hunger
description: Grant to deliver a joint NGO campaign on food and hunger

title: NGO Effectiveness, Transparency and Joint Civil Society Action
description: (i) The development of models, systems and processes that will aid overseas development NGO's to enhance their effectiveness in delivering aid together with creating greater transparency within the sector (ii) Influencing and enabling joint civil society action for positive EU and international development policy and global post -2015 development framework.
recipient-country: The recipients will be UK based international development NGOs

title: Improving access and completion rates at primary level among bidi-rolling dalit communities in rural Maharashtra
description: to increase access and completion rates among boys and girls at primary level, among a bidi-rolling Dalit community in Sangamner, rural Maharashtra. This will be achieved through an integrated intervention involving educational, livelihoods and health initiatives.

title: Advancing civil societyâ€™s capacity to monitor and improve access to education for children with disabilities
description: This project seeks to increase the life chances of children with disabilities (CWD) through improved access to primary education in Mozambique. The purpose is to capacitate civil society to independently protect, promote and monitor implementation of policies, national plans and legislation on rights of CWD to education. It will deliver: (i) increased technical capacity within FAMOD to monitor and protect education rights of CWD; (ii) increased legitimacy and credibility of FAMOD with policy-makers through evidence-based knowledge of issues around access to education for CWD; (iii) decision-makers and audiences more aware and active towards obligations to education of CWD under domestic and international instruments. As a direct result of the project 1,000 more CWD will have better access to schooling; up to 180 schools will implement changes to be more accessible to CWD; GoM will consider recommendations for changes in practice, policy and law to comply with international policy on CWD access to education.
implementing_organisations: ;FAMOD - Forum of Mozambican Associations of Disabled People

title: Empowering marginalised coastal communities in Ecuador to engage in local decision-making and manage their natural resources
description: The project aims to empower marginalised coastal communities of Esmeraldas Province to engage fully in local and national planning and decision-making processes to protect and fulfil their rights over access to natural resources and basic services critical to improving livelihoods.;El proyecto tiene como objetivo empoderar comunidades costeras marginalizadas de la Provincia de Esmeraldas para participar enteramente en procesos de planificaciÃ_n y la toma de decisiones locales y nacionales para proteger y cumplir sus derechos sobre recursos naturales y servicios bÃ¡sicos crÃ_ticos para mejorar sus medios de vida.

title: Enhancing Education in Rural Communities
description: This project will improve education in 8 rural community schools in Zio District of Togo. These schools were created by poor farmers for their children, and are in remote areas where the Government has failed to build schools. The project will provide them teaching and learning materials and train volunteers teaching in these schools so that they become more skilful and make school more interesting and attractive for pupils. Governance and management will be strengthened through the training of Parentsâ€™ Associations, and the status of women and girls will be strengthened through awareness-raising on gender issues. The improved schools will contribute towards improved literacy in the communities and facilitate future development initiatives. Income generating projects yielding both short-term and long-term income will be established for the benefit of the schools and teachers. The project will benefit directly or indirectly, around 7,000 people.
sector-text: provision of support to community primary schools, including supplying materials, training teachers and parent-teacher associations, and establishing income generating projects

title: Building Capacity for Commercial Viability India
description: The project is building the capacity of Jeevikaâ€™s 5 partners in Orissa and Tamil Nadu to plan/manage project delivery effectively, improving monitoring/reporting and impact-assessment methodology. This is being achieved through a programme of stakeholder workshops and a development forum, linked to the application of an assessment framework and peer-group evaluation. This is being extended in Orissa into capacity-building for 300+ small-scale women beekeepers in order to consolidate the commercial viability of small-scale honey producers through the provision of training, equipment, marketing, banking linkages and knowledge-sharing. It will also create district-level Resource Centres for honey pooling, filtering and storage for wholesale purchase; form a Women Beekeepersâ€™ Association to strengthen stakeholder collaboration and, in the longer-term, enable Fair Trade registration and development of export opportunities.

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: Capital Markets Climate Initiative (CMCI)
description: The Capital Markets Climate Initiative (CMCI) was set up to help scale up private capital flows in low carbon, climate resilient activities in developing countries. Specifically, CMCI is targeted at supporting governments in developing a stronger and common understanding and appreciation as to why and how to effectively and efficiently leverage private capital by helping to address these information barriers. In turn, this should contribute to the scaling up of private capital flows as better informed governments are more willing to put in place appropriate enabling environments and use scarce public climate finance to help address identified barriers and market failures.
sector-text: ;Low carbon development

title: Climate Public Private Partnership (CP3) Platform
description: The UKâ€™s International Climate Fund (ICF) will fund: (1) Equity investment in the Climate Public Private Partnership Asia Fund â€“ CP3 Asia in the amount of Â£60,000,000 to catalyse low carbon investments in Asia. (2) Equity investment in the IFC Catalyst Fund (CF) in the amount of Â£50,000,000 to strengthen the financial infrastructure for low carbon investments globally. (3) Grant financing for the Technical Assistance and Project Development Facility (Â£20,000,000) to assist with project pipeline and fund development. (4) Programme development costs: Â£384,401.94 contracted; up to Â£100,000 additional work projected (total project development costs: not exceeding Â£500,000). This is funded by the Department for International Development and Department of Energy and Climate Change (DECC). This refers only to DECC spend.

title: Partnership for Market Readiness Multi-Donor Trust Fund
description: The PMR brings together developed and developing countries, creating a platform for capacity building, sharing knowledge/expertise and best practice on Emisson Trading Systems (ETSs). The PMR provides grant funding to 15 developing/middle income countries to build market readiness components and pilot domestic ETSs and new crediting mechanisms.
sector-text: ;Low carbon development

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: International 2050 pathways partnerships
description: Expanding and building on the innovative UK-developed interactive energy and emissions scenario â€˜2050 calculatorâ€™, DECC is assisting ten developing country governments to build similar calculators as strategic platforms toward a low carbon future. DECC will be providing Â£1.5 million over 2012-2014 to work directly with the developing country governments to help them build their own version of the UKâ€™s 2050 Calculator. DECC will provide training on how to use it to explore viable low carbon development pathways with stakeholders and to inform policy making. Through engaging in a dialogue around the 2050 calculator, involved countries are encouraged to evaluate their unique opportunities and risks towards low carbon development. The tool will support developing countries drawing up their own low-carbon development plans helping them to be analytically robust, transparent and easily communicated. Recipient countries may include Bangladesh, Brazil, South Africa, India, Mexico, Colombia, Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia, Algeria and Nigeria. The 2050 calculator has already been used to influence low carbon plans in the UK and Belgium, and the China is in the early stages of analysing what their version means for their low carbon development. To complement the national calculators this project will also develop a comprehensive, robust and influential â€œGlobal Calculatorâ€ù. It will primarily be a communications tool aimed at energising the debate on climate change ahead of the 2015 negotiations, by helping to answer questions on how the global energy, food and land use system â€œadds upâ€ù (for example: what is the maximum global potential for nuclear power?; do we have enough raw materials to support possible future consumption habits?, and; what is the trade off of land for bioenergy, food production and forestry?). The target audience is businesses, NGOs and government officials working in strategy functions and international negotiations (from finance, environment, energy and transport ministries). The project would begin at the start of 2013 and finish by the end of 2014. This timetable means the tool would be rolled out in advance of the UNFCCC 2015 negotiations aimed at reaching a new international agreement with legal force to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
funding_organisations: ;Uk Department of Energy and Climate Change
accountable_organisations: ;UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
sector-text: ;Low Carbon Development

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: Green Africa Power
description: Green Africa Power (GAP) has been developed jointly by the UK Department of Energy and Climate Change (Â£25m) and UK Department for International Development (Â£53m) and in total the UK is contributing Â£98million over 2012 to 2015 to tackle specific constraints to private sector investment in renewable power generation in Africa. The UK will provide Â£95 million to capitalise GAP - a new company that will be established under the Private Infrastructure Development Group (PIDG) Trust. GAP will invest in renewable energy projects to demonstrate the viability of renewable energy in Africa so that future projects are more likely to happen and attract private developers and investors. A further Â£3 million will be used to set up the project, monitor and evaluate these impacts and capture and disseminate this knowledge. GAP aims to support projects that will install ~270MW of renewable energy in Africa in 4 years, avoiding an estimated 2.3m tonnes of CO2 emissions.
funding_organisations: ;Uk Department of Energy and Climate Change;Uk Department for International Development
sector-text: ;Low Carbon Development

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: Low Carbon agriculture in Colombia
description: The UK is providing a Â£15m grant over 2012 to 2016 to support the growth of silvopastoral systems (SPS) in Colombia to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve the livelihood of farmers, protect local forests and increase biodiversity. Agriculture is one of the biggest sources of greenhouse gas emissions in Colombia and many other developing countries, and a key driver of deforestation. Addressing this fact, the UK and partners are working with cattle ranchers to improve degraded grazing land by using SPS. This means managing the land in a different way: planting trees, shrubs, fodder crops and living fences and conserving existing forest. Participating small farmers, the majority of whom are living in conditions of rural poverty, are able to raise more, healthier cattle on their existing land using SPS, increasing their income and reducing the need to clear forest. This project aims to convert 28,000 hectares of grazing land to SPS, saving around 2MtCO2e over the next 8 years, and create a strategy for increasing the use of SPS in Colombia and beyond.
funding_organisations: ;Uk Department of Energy and Climate Change
accountable_organisations: ;World Bank - International Bank for Reconstruction and Development

title: International Carbon Capture and Storage Capacity Building
description: Build developing country capacity to deploy carbon capture and storage technologies. The UK will provide Â£60 million of finance from the International Climate Fund (ICF) to support developing countries to develop both the technical and institutional knowledge necessary to enable the deployment of CCS technologies. Financial support would be channelled toward a range of projects with the aim of ensuring sufficient political support is created to pave the way for full scale demonstration and ultimately the deployment of CCS.

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: GET FiT - On Grid Small Scale Renewable Energy in Uganda
description: GET FiT will support small-scale renewable energy projects in Uganda in an effort to promote private sector investment in renewables. The UK will provide Â£20m to â€™GET FiTâ€™ to help meet an anticipated increase in energy demand in Uganda through renewables and avoid either an energy shortfall or the use of fossil fuel generation, in particular after 2014. The project will provide a mix of financial incentives, risk guarantees and technical assistance which include: a top up grant to the existing financial incentives (Feed-in-Tariffs) for renewables; facilitating the purchase of World Bank Guarantees by renewable energy developers to cover project risks; and capacity building support to the Ugandan Energy Regulatory Authority. GET FiT will demonstrate to private sector developers that investment in renewable energy in countries like Uganda is worthwhile and financially attractive, and it will also demonstrate to Ugandan and regional governments that private sector renewable energy works. This is jointly funded by DECC and DfID and this refers to DECC spend only.
funding_organisations: ;Department of Energy and Climate Change;Department for International Development

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: Global Climate Partnership Fund (GCPF)
description: GCPF is an innovative public-private partnership with the objective of increasing the flow of finance to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and households for energy efficiency projects, and to a lesser extent renewable energy, by mobilising private finance. Targeting projects across developing and emerging economies, it aims to deliver greenhouse gas emissions savings and support local development. GCPF was established by the German Government (BMU) and development agency (KfW) and has been operating successfully since 2011 and is open ended with no set close date. GCPF is a Fund that is commercially run by Deutsche Bank. The majority (at least 70%) of the Fund will be used to provide local financial institutions with credit lines, with which they in turn offer market rate loans to SMEs/households for renewable energy or energy efficiency projects. A smaller part of the Fund, up to 30%, will make direct investments (equity or debt) in similar projects. GCPF has a complementary technical assistance facility for local financial institutions to introduce or enhance innovative climate change oriented loan products to facilitate new and protect existing investments of the Fund. The private sector (both local financial institutions and the wider capital markets) has a lack of experience and hence confidence in providing finance for small-scale renewable energy and energy efficiency projects. This means that appropriate finance is either not available to SMEs and households, or that lending is offered at prohibitively expensive rates to compensate the high risk that is perceived due to lack of experience of this type of lending. This is a particular issue in developing countries. GCPF aims to address this by using public funds to take a greater level of risk with a lower rate of return than commercial investors would accept in order to mobilise investment in to the Fund. By demonstrating that low carbon investments can be economically attractive and sustainable GCPF aims to accelerate and attract additional capital at scale into climate financing. GCPF does not offer finance at concessional rates to local financial institutions which helps ensure the development of a sustainable market.

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: BioCarbon Fund
description: This fund will mobilise finance to reduce carbon emissions in forest and agricultural ecosystems. DECC has invested Â£50m to support investments in a number of country programmes, which are currently being developed and agreed. The Fund will 1) provide technical assistance for REDD+ implementation and measures which improve the enabling environment for private sector investment; 2) offer finance for Verified Emission Reductions associated with avoided deforestation; and 3) secure private sector finance, for example through purchasing commitments for sustainable commodities produced in the jurisdiction (sometimes called â€˜offtaker agreementsâ€™). 1. Each country programme under the BioCarbon Fund will operate at the jurisdiction-scale, that is within a landscape-wide area that is governed by a single political jurisdiction. Activities that are likely to be supported include small scale plantation farming, sustainable forest management, afforestation and reforestation, regeneration, National Park designation / no-deforestation zoning, agroforestry and sustainable agricultural practices.
funding_organisations: ;UK Depatment of Energy and Climate Change

reporting-organisation: UK Department of Energy and Climate Change
title: Carbon Market Finance (CMF) - Climate Initiative for Development (CiDev)
description: CMF has been developed jointly by the Department of Energy & Climate Change and the Department for International Development and in total the UK is contributing Â£50 million over 2013 to 2025 to build capacity and develop tools and methodologies that will help least developed countries, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, to access finance from the carbon market. The UK will provide Â£49 million to the World Bankâ€™s Carbon Initiative for Development (Ci-Dev) to deliver CMF. Ci-Dev will invest in low carbon technologies that deliver community and household level benefits, particularly focused on improving poor peoplesâ€™ access to clean energy. By successfully demonstrating the ability of carbon finance to deliver low carbon development in least developed countries Ci-Dev hopes to increase future carbon finance flows to these countries. A further Â£1 million will be used to monitor and evaluate these impacts and capture and disseminate this knowledge. CMF aims to achieve significant development impacts, installing upwards of 165MW of new renewable energy generation, avoiding an estimated 2.6 MtCO2e, and mobilizing Â£982 million of private sector finance into clean technologies.
funding_organisations: ;UK Department of Energy and Climate Change

title: INNOVATIVE FINANCIAL SERVICES MODEL TO PROTECT NEPALS WORKERS
description: One quarter of Nepalâ€™s population lives on less than Â£0.16 per day, and a further 55% lives on less than Â£0.80. 96.2% of Nepalâ€™s workforce is employed in the â€˜informal sectorâ€™ â€“ primarily smallholder farmers and landless wage labourers - which means that around 11.3 million workers are deprived of access to formal social protection measures, directly impacting on working conditions, wages, and safety nets such as insurance and access to legal, technical and financial services that guard against times of low economic demand and offset hard times. The proposed project fully contributes towards MDG 1b, â€˜Achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all, including women and young peopleâ€™ by increasing the capacity of workers in the informal economy to escape from poverty and better manage risks and shocks. In many of the poorest, most geographically isolated hill and mountain regions of Nepal, residents rely on â€œself-help groupsâ€ù known as Village Savings and Loans Associations (VSLAs) for support. VSLAs help marginalised households to access information, peer support and services, as well as creating group-based savings and loan funds, which can then be used as insurance, working capital for self-employment activities, emergency funds, and savings. An estimated 300,000 of these informal VSLAs exist in Nepal, but they often suffer from poor governance and embezzlement and end up failing to carry out the role for which they were created. As a result, many Nepali people often depend heavily on high-risk informal loans to cover consumption and emergency needs, with many families taking annual loans averaging Â£350 at interest rates exceeding 60% per annum. Many are unable to repay these loans in cash, and therefore often make repayments with crops or take out a second or third loan to repay the first loan, resulting in a cycle of debt from which it is almost impossible to emerge. Facilitating access to formal Savings and Credit Cooperatives (SACCOs) for informal VSLAs therefore serves as in important intermediary step that allows vulnerable groups to benefit from formal financial services, technical services, and social protection mechanisms. However, to expand access to such formal SACCOs effectively, qualified intermediary organisations like NEFSCUN must be capable of forming and expanding their networks while at the same time enforcing minimum standards of governance and extending legal protection. Whilst NEFSCUNâ€™s activities have proven effective the organisation has yet to reach some of Nepalâ€™s poorest and most underserved districts due to remoteness and the costliness of operating in these areas. Furthermore, given that their Cooperative Development Process remains costly to implement and is not outreach-based, the reach of their network remains constrained. As such, Mercy Corps and NEFSCUN will partner to develop a cost-effective, outreach-based model to reach the vast array of informal, community-based VSLAs already in existence.
implementing_organisations: ;NEPAL FEDERATION OF SAVINGS AND CREDIT COOPERATIVE UNIONS (NEFSCUN)
sector-text: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT - FINANCIAL SERVICES, WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT

title: INCREASING FOOD AND WATER SECURITY IN NANA MAMBERE
description: Output 1: Rural and peri-urban populations in the intervention areas benefit from increased access to a safe water supply and basic sanitation services. The project will Train 80 community committees to manage and effectively maintain water sources and 120 hygiene committees in health centres, schools and communities. The project will also Construct or rehabilitate 120 public latrines (60 blocks of 2 VIP latrines) in schools and health centres; and mobilise communities to construct 300 traditional latrines. Output 2: Significant improvement in availability and quality of staple foods to households in the intervention area. MC will work with its current network of farmers and the government extension agency ACDA to Develop and implement a training program for producers on red bean and peanut cultivation, and facilitate marketing and local consumption of beans and peanuts. To limit the cases of illness linked to badly prepared manioc, the project will train producers in a rapid drying method developed and tested by LASBAD, as well as hygienic preparation techniques. Output 3: The population in the intervention zone demonstrates increased knowledge and awareness on hygiene and sanitation practices, good nutrition, and related health concerns. MC will train a network of hygiene volunteers who will supervise, support and motivate community hygiene focal points in their areas. The public awareness campaign will be carried out in communities and schools on a yearly basis, and will be reinforced by a series of radio programs that will be developed by MC and local actors. To increase knowledge and practice of good nutrition, the project will Establish 40 FAN Clubs, train 40 community animators on â€˜Healthy Harvestâ€™ Methodology, and train beneficiaries on good nutrition, hygiene and alimentary practices. The basis of this approach is to provide knowledge on the principles of good nutrition, support community members to grow nutritious food stuffs on communal gardens.
sector-text: FOOD AND WATER SECURITY ;

title: IMPROVED WASH FOR GOMAS PERI-URBAN AND RURAL POOR

title: Supporting the Education of Marginalised Girls in Kailali (STEM)
description: Over fifty-five percent of Nepalese live below the $1.25/Â£0.78 daily poverty line clustered by geography, caste, and gender. Some of the most marginalised and disadvantaged, in terms of access to education, social and economic life opportunities, are Dalit and Janajati girls and their subcastes living in the Kailali District of the Far West Region. These subcastes include the Tharu people who were previously indentured servants to higher castes , and the Badi people who are the most marginalised of the â€˜untouchablesâ€™ with adolescent Badi girls socialised and defined by their caste as commercial sex workers at puberty. Dalit and Janajati girls in Kailali District face a triple disadvantage of (1) living in a rural location where education is a low priority, (2) belonging to the lowest of castes and therefore forced to perform undesirable work and social tasks, and (3) being devalued by society for being female. Supporting The Education of Marginalised Girls of Kailali (STEM) will begin to erode the cultural and financial barriers to education and work these marginalised girls face by supporting them to Enrol in school, Learn and pass exams, and begin to Earn their way from school to work.
implementing_organisations: ;Forum for Awarness and Youth Activity Nepal (FAYA-Nepal);Mercy Corps Scotland

title: Educating Nigerian Girls in New Enterprises (ENGINE)
description: Gender dynamics in Northern Nigeria generally place significant economic decision-making into the hands of men regarding girlsâ€™ and womenâ€™s access to basic services (e.g. health and education). Many girls aged 15 to 19 are formally employed, with a higher percentage informally employed or underemployed, earning money on an ad-hoc basis. Adolescent girls in Northern Nigeria require vocational and skills-based training, along with direct access to assets, in order to increase their economic and social status and enhance their earning potential. ENGINE will equip marginalized girls/young women (ages 17 to 19) to successfully integrate into the Coca-Cola value chain by preparing and facilitating their transition to work. With skills obtained through training, girls who choose to become retailers within the Coca-Cola value chain will have the opportunity to increase their direct income and long-term assets. ENGINE will engage up to 10,500 girls in Abuja, Kaduna, Kano, Jigawa, and Katsina states. ENGINE will focus on marginalized girls/young women not in school and not currently reached through bilateral programmes. ENGINE is structured around the theory of change that if more marginalised Nigerian girls access demand-driven skills, then they will delay marriage, have lower fertility rates, increased earning power, and increased decision-making within the household.

title: Article 19 PPA 2011-2014
description: ARTICLE 19's PPA has four objectives designed to challenge threats to freedom of expression and increase the impact of highly innovative 'niche NGOs' delivering transparency initiatives. A19 will: 1 Defend Freedom of Expression (FoE) and transparency in a multi-polar world: contribute to halting democratic setbacks; re-enforce the regional and international policies for poverty alleviation through a focus on transparency and the free flow of information (MDG 8). 2 Enhance FoE and transparency in a networked world: harness the power of Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) and media to implement the MDGs by ensuring that FoE principles, including that of universal access, are fully integrated in legal regulations and policies. 3) Protect FoE and transparency against its aggressors: strengthen the role and effectiveness of institutions which are meant to safeguard accountability and ensure that State and Non-State Actors are held accountable for abusing FoE and transparency standards essential to the realisation of all MDGs. 4) Narrow the gaps between principles and practice to deliver real benefits for the poor: empower people living in poverty and their CSOs to access information they need to advocate for better services and tackle some of the causes and consequences of poverty (MDG 3, 5 and 7). To achieve these objectives, A19 will enable CSOs, CBOs, network and processes and strengthen their capacities to secure accountable institutions, through legal and policy support, skills transfer, trainings, and coalition building. We will work simultaneously at grassroots, national and international levels, to ensure that freedom of expression and information grows roots in institutions and society, and fulfils its potential as a mechanism for citizen empowerment and poverty alleviation.

title: Environmental Rehabilitation in Southern Ethiopia
description: The project will increase agricultural productivity and household incomes, while reversing processes of ecological degradation, by introducing Farmer-Led Integrated Watershed Management (FLIWM) in Lake Boyo catchment, SNNPR, Ethiopia.

title: Slovak-Kenyan Cooperation for Modern Schools
description: Slovak-Kenyan Cooperation for Modern Schools is a follow-up project targeting five schools in Voi District with an aim to provide digital technology, trainings of teachers, study exchange trips of teachers and starting a project-based learning where students help local communities utilizing their newly attained ICT skills.

title: Slovak - Balkan Public Policy Fund
description: The chief objective of the project is to utilise Slovak transition experiences and to subsequently contribute to the capacity building of the expert public of the Western Balkans and its engagement with the creation of public policy concerning EU integration. By the means of a grant mechanism the Slovak Balkan Public Policy Fund focuses on the young generations of analysts, civil society members, academics, journalists and engaged individuals who can apply through grant calls.

title: Strengthening the sectoral dialogue of Moldovan civil society organizations with the government
description: In September 2011 the Pontis Foundation launched a new project in Moldova, namely; Reinforcement of sectoral politics dialogue between NGOs and government in Moldova. This new project continues to work towards the goals that were set by the foundationâ€˜s first project in Moldova. However, while the first project mainly focused on increasing the organizational, human and expert capacities of the NGOs, the second project is concerned with putting these newly acquired skills to practical use. The main objective of this project is to reinforce the sectoral capacities of Moldovan NGOs and to offer guidance in defining their goals and the strategies they will use to achieve them. Through this we will help to establish these NGOs as an important part of the Moldovan decision-making process.

title: Slovak corporate responsibility experience for Belarus (higher education and grant programme for analysts)
description: The overall goal of the project is to educate business executives, managers and future business professionals how to incorporate best practices of corporate responsibility into their business models. The project builds on the Pontis Foundation's more than ten years of experience with developing the concept of corporate responsibility in Slovakia, Serbia, Macedonia, and Belarus. In Belarus, we relate and build on our project that aims to develop cross-sectoral partnerships between non-governmental organizations and the business sector. Consequently, the training series for MBA lecturers as a part of the project is as a way of combating this paucity of expertise.

title: Expert dialog on development (engagement of partners in development cooperation)
description: Presented project Expert dialog on development (engagement of partners in development cooperation) has the ambition to form Slovak expert public in long- term perspective, which will be sympathetic with developing countries and will understand global and development context of reducing their problems. The short- term and mid- term goal of the project is to focus on target groups (academics, university students, government representatives, members of parliament, media) and raise their awareness of necessity of development assistance provided by the Slovak Republic and consequently increase the activities of these groups in the field of development cooperation.

title: Building Partnerships for Democracy in Tunisia
description: The core of the project lies in the transfer of the experience, knowledge and best practices from the process of transition to democracy, process of building of a vibrant civil society and establishment of functioning mechanisms of consultation and cooperation between the state and the non-state actors in Slovakia and other countries with similar experience.

title: SLOVAKIA AND EUROPEAN FUTURE OF MOLDOVA
description: Aim of the project is to strenghten NPC, which covers communication of 30 NGOs with Moldovan government. Through training young leaders of NGOs, the project will help to increase their managerial and expert capacities, study visits to Bratislava and Brussels will help to transfer Slovak know-how from integration process and to link Moldovan NGOs with specialists from EU member states. Best ideas of training participants will be also financially supported in realization of advocacy campaigns, whose actors will have a chance to consult with experts from Slovakia.

title: SEPAD: Slovak-Egyptian Partnership for Democracy
description: The goal of the project is to support local non- governmental organizations (NGO) which actively contribute to development of local communities in the city of Asyut and its environment. At the same time the project wants to support the activities of analytical and academic community at local university with the aim to create a relevant voice in the process of political and social change of transforming Egypt. Project is focused on four NGOs- two operating in rural environment and two in urban. Their previous activities have been characterized mainly by development of local communities.

title: Knowledge makes change
description: In February 2010 the Pontis Foundation started to implement a new project Knowledge makes Change! that focuses on enforcing the topic of development in society. The project will support public discussion about topics of development aid in developing countries. The aim of the project is to build capacities of non-governmental organizations in Poland, Slovakia and Cyprus. Moreover, its goal is to increase the cooperation between non-governmental organizations, academic institutions, state representatives and the public. The project should resolve in an increased awareness of development cooperation in these three countries.;Three target groups are the main focus here: political representatives, non-governmental organisations and experts from the academic community.;This project is comprised of various activities. For example, a series of publications, analyses and manuals will be created as a part of it. Numerous internships, seminars, conferences and public discussions will also be realized. Equally important, a new working group will be set up with the aim to create a set of recommendations and standards for teaching at schools and in other educational institutions about the topic of development aid.

title: Slovak-Kenyan Cooperation for Modern Schools
description: These schools, plus schools provided with computers through the previous project, will then be able to set up Practice Enterprise Networks as part of the â€œEuropenâ€ù initiative. This will mean that pupils can set up Practice business firms and conduct simulated business in realistic conditions. Though this will initially take place only in the schools selected for this project, the practice enterprise network will be a national agreement, and eventually any Kenyan school, job centre or other educational establishment with ICT facilities will be able to take part. ;This hands-on business experience will dramatically improve the employability of young Kenyans who participate. As will be explained, the project contributes to gender equality and conservation issues and will increase the level of international cooperation between Kenya and Slovakia.;The project aims to improve standards of education in the Voi district of Kenya and at the same time improve employability of young Kenyan school leavers, contributing to reducing Kenyaâ€™s alarmingly high unemployment rate. This project will enlarge on a previous similar project run by The Applicant in Kenya from 2010-2012. High schools will be provided with internet-ready computer laboratories and training sessions will be provided for teachers on how to make use of ICT and project-based learning. The ability to utilize these computers has already had proven success in raising standards of education in Kenya

title: Global University II: Promoting discourse of development education at universities
description: The project focuses on issues of development education in Slovak Universities;The overall objective of the project is to improve the quality of development education at Slovak universities through capacity building of teachers and departments and by raising awareness among university students. The objective is is consistent with the National Strategy for Global Education as a framework document, as well as with the Action Plan for this year.

title: Slovak Balkan Public Policy Fund
description: The overall objective of the project is to strengthen the capacities of civil society in the Western Balkans (Macedonia, Serbia [including Kosovo*]) and its involvement in public policy connected to European integration through the transfer of Slovak experience;The project will work with the younger generation of Macedonian, Serbian and Kosovar analysts up to the age of 35,

title: Building partnerships for democracy in Tunisia II: Strengthening citizen participation in local development
description: The overall objective of the project is to empower the civil society organizations in Tunisia, strengthen their capacities for advocacy and public policy interventions, and assist in intensification of the dialogue between the civil society and the government institutions in Tunisia.

title: Indipendent government: the assumption of democratization at the local level in Moldova
description: Project aims to provide support in capacity building of local government and its key structures, to support communication with public and sensitization of public opinion, to support structural and multisectoral dialogue which aims to strengthen position and performance of local government in Moldova as the main premise of decentralization of power and building of stable democratic state.;Project aims to provide support in capacity building of local government and its key structures, to support communication with public and sensitization of public opinion, to support structural and multisectoral dialogue which aims to strengthen position and performance of local government in Moldova as the main premise of decentralization of power and building of stable democratic state.

title: Civil society capacity building in Northern Kosovo via Slovak Balkan Public Policy Fund
description: Project aims to support democratization processes in Northern Kosovo through sharing experiences of participatory democracy of Slovak civil society.

title: Building legal capacity to support the rights of forest communities in the Central African Republic and Gabon
description: The project will improve the capacities of law graduates and empower local CSOs and forest communities in CAR and Gabon to understand, analyse and use national laws related to forest management, land and resource rights, human rights and IP rights. As a result, selected IP groups and forest communities will be capable of devising and implementing legal and advocacy strategies and will have more secure land tenure arrangements, access to forest revenues, and will be consulted adequately on matters concerning them, exercising their right to FPIC. Local and national government officials will be aware of communitiesâ€™ challenges, and processes will be underway to review selected pieces of legislation that do not adequately protect community rights. Selected CLFWs paralegals and communities in CAR and Gabon will benefit directly from the project;Le projet amÃ©liorera les capacitÃ©s des diplÃ´mÃ©s en droit et soutiendra des organisations locales de la sociÃ©tÃ© civile et les communautÃ©s locales en RCA et au Gabon. Ces communautÃ©s, a la fin du projet, seront capables de comprendre, dâ€™analyser, et dâ€™utiliser les lois nationales en matiÃ¨re de gestion des forets, de droits aux terres et aux ressources, de droits de lâ€™homme et de droits des peuples autochtones. Comme rÃ©sultat, les peuples autochtones et les communautÃ©s forestiÃ¨res sÃ©lectionnÃ©es seront capables de deviser et de mettre en Å“uvre des stratÃ©gies juridiques et de plaidoyer. Ils auront des droits fonciers plus sÃ»rs, un accÃ¨s aux revenues forestiÃ¨res, et seront consultÃ©s de maniÃ¨re adÃ©quate sur les questions qui les concernent, en respect du droit au consentement libre, prÃ©alable et informÃ© (CLIP). Les reprÃ©sentants gouvernementaux au niveaux local et national seront informÃ©s des dÃ©fis auxquels les communautÃ©s font face, et des processus pour la rÃ©vision de certaines lÃ©gislations qui ne protÃ¨gent pas de maniÃ¨re adÃ©quate les droits des communautÃ©s seront en cours. Les juristes communautaires et les para juristes sÃ©lectionnÃ©s pour participer au projet seront les bÃ©nÃ©ficiaires directs, ainsi que les communautÃ©s soutenues.
implementing_organisations: ;Maison de lâ€™Enfant et de la Femme PygmÃ©es;Brainforest

title: Fairtrade Labelling Organizations International (FLO), Programme Partnership Agreement
description: The PPA intends to achieve: - a stronger and more effective, efficient and streamlined Fairtrade system, capable of delivering increased benefits to producers. - broader scope of Fairtrade, capable of facilitating more producers in more locations to access the benefits of Fairtrade. - deepened impacts of Fairtrade, capable of making significant contributions to achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
implementing_organisations: ;Fairtrade Foundation UK;Fairtrade Labelling Organizations International e.V.

title: Girls' Education Challenge Project
description: Improving Girl's enrolment, retention and learning in school - empowering marginalised and at risk girls, aged 11 - 14 to stay in school, return to school, and improve their literacy, numeracy and sexual and reproductive health.
sector-text: The project helps children in primary school to protect themselves from HIV/AIDS;The project empowers girls in primary schools to improve their literacy and numeracy, and their participation in class. It also builds the capacity and skills of selected female teachers.

title: Building Skills for Life, PPA2
description: Plan UKâ€™s Programme Partnership Arrangement (PPA) is a strategic funding arrangement, which Plan is using to fund two strategic objectives relating to â€œBuilding Skills for Lifeâ€ù and enhancing programme effectiveness. Building Skills for Life is our flagship programme promoting adolescent girlsâ€™ rights and gender equality. The PPA funds projects aimed at enhancing girlsâ€™ access to and completion of quality education in 9 countries.

title: Hygiene, Sanitation and Water Supply in Port Loko and Moyamba
description: Plan Sierra Leone and its local partners are implementing a five-year hygiene, sanitation and water supply project to cover Koya and TMS chiefdoms of Port Loko district and Kowa and Fakunya chiefdoms of Moyamba district. The project supports the Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) methodology, a participatory approach whereby community members analyse their own sanitation status and change their collective behaviour to bring about safe sanitation. Whilst supporting communities to become Open Defecation-Free, the project aims to increase access to water, increase adoption of key hygiene practices and strengthen the District Health Management Teams and District Councils to deliver their water and sanitation responsibilities. The project employs participatory methodologies that promote inclusion, community decision making and local ownership, and is building the capacity of community based organisations including Community Health Clubs and Water Committees. Water supply components are being implemented using the Community Management Approach, whereby communities select and manage appropriate water supply systems for their communities. Plan and its local partners are building dialogue between communities and local government in order to increase government support for and investment in hygiene, sanitation and water supply interventions.

title: Promoting Equal Education for Adolescent Girls
description: The project aims at empowering girls through education in Bondo, Kilifi, Machakos and Tharaka Program Units in Kenya. The project will contribute to this through: strengthened capacities of girls and boys, parents, community leaders and government officials on girlsâ€™ right to education; increased financing opportunities for girlsâ€™ education; strengthened capacity of service providers for addressing girlsâ€™ sexual and reproductive health needs; improved gender-responsive school environment for girls and boys; strengthened capacity of girls and boys relating to sexual reproductive health and self protection against violence. This project will directly impact over 15,000 girls and over 77,000 people over the three years.
sector-text: Awareness-raising on girls' rights;;;;

title: Promoting the Rights of Adolescent Girls to Quality Basic Education
description: The overarching goal of the project is gender equality and the realisation of girls? rights in Cambodia. The project purpose is to increase the number of adolescent girls completing Lower Secondary education by addressing some of the key economic, social, cultural, and political barriers. The project will directly benefit approximately 3,000 adolescent girls from 26 Secondary schools across six Districts in Cambodia.

title: Girls Empowerment Through Education in Mali
description: This project aims to increase the enrolment of girls and their successful completion of quality basic education in Kati and Kangaba cercle in region of Koulikoro in Mali by 2014. Within 3 years, key actors in girlâ€™s education (parents, School Management Committee, Pupilâ€™s Mothers Associations, School Government, teachers, commune leadersâ€_) will receive skills for improving girlâ€™s school enrolment rate and their retention in quality education in the districts of Kangaba in 25 schools and Kati in 25 schools.

title: Improved Access to & Quality Delivery of Education and Sexual & Reproductive Health
description: The overall aim of this project is to improve access to and quality delivery of education and Sexual Reproductive Health via Social Accountability. The purpose is to increase the number of adolescent girls enrolling and completing education as well as girls involved in decision making processes in the community and school management. The project also intends to change the attitudes and behaviour of girls, parents, communities and officials in relation to adolescent girlsâ€™ right to education, gender and sexual reproductive health .

title: Access to Post Primary and Life Skills Based Education
description: The project aims to create an â€œenablingâ€ù environment where adolescent girls are able to complete quality post primary education, and are in a position to fulfil their own aspirations. Plan and partners will advocate with government, communities, families and parents to realise the value of post primary and lifeskills-based education of girls, enabling them to make informed choices when it comes to their reproductive health and related utilization of services, and to contribute in the society as productive and empowered individuals.
sector-text: ;;;;Non-formal education provision for girls;Community-based child protection

title: Increasing Adolescent Girls Attainment of Basic Education
description: The project is contributing to achieve universal primary education (MDG 2) and promote gender equality and empower women (MDG 3) by increasing girls? attainment of quality, gender-responsive, basic education in targeted areas in Rwanda: (1). Through the Tuseme (Let us speak out) empowerment programme 600 girls are empowered with skills to address concerns that hinder girls? social and academic development. (2). Establishing a conducive environment for girls participation in decision-making at schools and community/sector/district level. (3). Reducing financial barriers for adolescent girls' access to education.
sector-text: ;;Remedial education;;

title: Equality through Adolescent Girls Education
description: This project will create the opportunity to engage with duty bearers and rights holders in addressing issues that hinder access to quality post primary education for adolescent girls, and aims to achieve: (1) Increased access to gender-sensitive, safe and quality basic education for girls and boys in targeted areas; and (2) Violence against girls and young women reduced as a result of strengthened and effective systems and civil society that promotes children?s rights to protection against all forms of violence.

title: Girls Empowerment through Education
description: The project aims to contribute towards gender equality in Zimbabwe, with a particular emphasis on girls? education. Thus, it intends to contribute to increased educational access, transition and successful completion of quality lower secondary education by girls in Chiredzi, Mwenezi and Chipinge districts in Zimbabwe by 2014. The project is expected to contribute to increased recognition by duty bearers of the value of girls? education so that gender disparity between completion of primary and lower secondary education by boys and girls is drastically reduced. Pass rates among girls are also expected to improve significantly following successful implementation and completion of this project.

title: Breaking Barriers for Development of Girls
description: This project seeks to contribute to the integral development of girls, adolescents and young women through the implementation of educational processes â€“ formal and informal â€“ that promote correct decision making for exercise of safe and healthy sexuality, prevention and protection against gender violence. That will be achieved with participation from the State as a guarantor, the community as correspondents, and the girls, boys, adolescents and youths as active subjects with rights.

title: Bringing Economic Empowerment for Street Children
description: This project aims to enable 2,500 street children in Dhaka city expand their income-generating capacity, and generate assets to sustainably lift themselves out of extreme poverty by 2013. The main activities include (1) skills-transfer training, internships and vocational training, designed to prioritise achievement of core-competencies, and respond to learning capacity and training needs of participants. (2) Supporting participants to access an innovative savings product that provides them with a flexible, child-friendly, secure and mobile form of asset generation. (3) An outreach campaign for the implementation of Child Safeguarding Standards in workplaces that is monitored through follow-up activities.

title: PPA Exploratory Programs July-Sept 2011
description: The Asia Foundation PPA with DFID CHASE is helping to address common challenges to peaceful state-society relations in fragile states, subnational conflict and post-conflict areas and transitional states at risk of renewed conflict. This activity represents Exploratory Programs under the PPA during the period July-Sept 2011. Exploratory Programs are small-scale, analytical efforts to identify opportunities for future programs. These activities are regional in nature.
recipient-region: South and Southeast Asia, regions affected by armed conflict
sector-text: Conflict prevention and resolution, peace and security, combinations of activities

title: PPA Thailand Programs July-Sept 2011
description: The Asia Foundation's PPA with DFID CHASE is helping to address common challenges to peaceful state-society relations in fragile states, subnational conflict and post-conflict areas and transitional states at risk of renewed conflict. This activity represents programs in Southern Thailand under the PPA during the period July-Sept 2011. These activities have the following objectives: 1) Governance reforms implemented to reduce grievances of conflict-affected populations in subnational conflict areas; 2) Expanded community-level efforts to improve local security and relations with security forces (police, military).

This activity represents a range of regional programs during the period July-Sept 2011.

These activities have the following objectives: 1) Governance reforms implemented to reduce grievances of conflict-affected populations in subnational conflict areas; 2) Expanded community-level efforts to improve local security and relations with security forces (police, military).
