title: GPAF IMP-005: Phuhlisanani Poverty Alleviation in South Africa
description: The Phuhlisanani Agricultural Development Project aims to achieve food and income security of 883 project members and their families through improved agricultural production interventions. The project will work with 13 poverty stricken villages, targeting women, youth and HIV and AIDS affected households, in the Amatole Basin in Eastern Cape, South Africa. Project members commit to Pass on the Gift of livestock, agricultural inputs and training to others in need.
funding_organisations: ;Wesbank;National Lottery Distribution Trust Fund ;UK Department for International Development

title: Helping poor farmers in Tanzania to increase productivity
description: The project will raise the skills, capacities, productivity and incomes of small and marginal farmers (<1 acre of land), with a special focus on women. The project will provide comprehensive support including high quality inputs, capacity building and technology transfer. These interventions will improve agricultural productivity by 25% and increase the income of farming families by 30% within 3 years. Direct beneficiaries will be more than 70,000 small and marginal farmers (84% women).
sector-text: Agriculture

title: Reducing hunger and poverty in Sierra Leone and Liberia
description: This project will train and equip poor landless women in food insecure rural areas of Sierra Leone and Liberia to establish kitchen gardens and small scale poultry farms in their homesteads and increase their familiesâ€™ food intake and improve their childrenâ€™s nutritional status and general health. The farmers will receive on-going training and inputs from community promoters. The project will conduct a village awareness campaign and establish village nutrition committees for wider impact.
sector-text: Agriculture and livestock

title: Providing early childhood education
sector-text: Education

title: Provision of quality primary education for 9,000 out of school children in South Sudan
description: This project will provide three years covering four years of quality primary education to 9,000 out-of-school children aged 8-11 (60% girls) from poor and marginalised families, enabling them to then access government schools and further livelihood opportunities, supported by their families and communities. The project will also train and build the capacity of 330 women as teachers and community organisers, providing them with improved skills and sustainable livelihood opportunities.
sector-text: Education

title: Targeting the Ultra-Poor (TUP): to support 250 ultra-poor women in South Sudan to develop sustainable livelihoods and food security so that they and their families move out of extreme poverty and hunger
description: This project will provide targeted support to 250 ultra-poor women and their households to move out of extreme poverty and vulnerability to more secure and sustainable livelihoods. Each will receive regular tailored support including initial food stipends, livelihood skills training and assets, plus financial training and support with savings. This approach is itself innovative (being piloted in eight other countries) and is innovative in the Republic of South Sudan where it has not been piloted to date.
sector-text: Livelihoods and food security

title: Community Based Education for marginalised Girls
description: This project targets marginalised girls who have never been to school or dropped out of primary/lower secondary school; and teachers and students in all-girl government schools in ten provinces.

title: GEC Tanzania Community Based Education for marginalised Girls GEC 6957
description: Girls Education Community Based Education for marginalised Girls in Tanzania

title: Community Based Education for marginalised Girls in Sierra Leone
description: Community Based Education for marginalised Girls in Sierra Leone

title: Improving the reproductive, maternal, newborn and child (under 5) health of adolescent girls and women inLiberia
description: Improving the reproductive, maternal, newborn and child (under 5) health of adolescent girls and women inLiberia)

title: Promoting the provision of inclusive primary education for children with disabilities in Mashonaland West Province, Zimbabwe
description: This project will work in 1 province in Zimbabwe to demonstrate to the government the viability and impact of LCDIsâ€™ inclusive education (IE) model on providing education for disabled girls and boys in mainstream primary schools, contributing to MDG2. The project will enrol and retain 2241 disabled children. The project will embed policy change in the MoE, and IE approaches in schools and local communities to ensure sustainable outcomes.

title: Pioneering inclusive education strategies for disabled girls in Kenya.
description: This project will work in Nyanza, Kenya addressing the physical and social barriers to education that are experienced by girls with disabilities. The project will adopt an inclusive education approach to ensure that 2,050 disabled girls in 50 primary schools in Nyanza receive a full, quality and inclusive primary education.
sector-text: Primary education for girls with disabilities;Education for girls with disabilities

title: Red Nose Day 2011 - UK Aid Match - Health and Education
description: Education: Our goal is to enable left out and marginalised children and young people to get into, stay in and attain good quality, relevant basic education. Also where appropriate, we want to help communities improve the uptake and quality of education in their local area, thereby empowering the community and strengthening childrenâ€™s learning. Health: Our goal is to contribute to increasing access to primary health care for disadvantaged communities.

title: Sport Relief 2012 - UK Aid Match - Slums
description: Our goal is to help slum dwellers in Africa drive programmes that lead to improvements in their communities, including securing the legal right to occupy viable land (as tenants or owners), improved access to basic services, better living conditions, and the opportunity for slum dwellers to improve their economic prospects.
funding_organisations: ;DFID;DFID;DFID;Charity Projects Ltd (Comic Relief);DFID;Charity Projects Ltd (Comic Relief)

title: Red Nose Day 2013 - UK Aid Match- Women and Girls
description: The aim of the programme is to contribute to a transformation in the status and lives of women and girls in Africa so that they can realise their rights and their full potential, and become equal and respected members of families, communities and society. We want Comic Reliefâ€™s funding to address changes at both the practical and structural levels and to bring about positive and enduring changes for women and girls in Africa.
funding_organisations: ;DFID;DFID;Charity Projects Ltd (Comic Relief);DFID;Charity Projects Ltd (Comic Relief)

title: GPAF - PEDER
description: To provide training and capacity building initiatives to 100 street workers and 156 key community stakeholders including the police and government officials, so they can protect the rights of street children and provide appropriate support to 5,000 street children in the Eastern Congo
implementing_organisations: ;Programme Diocesain D'Encradrement des Enfants de la Rue (Diocesan street child support programme, Archdiocese of Bukavu)

title: Protecting the rights of 5,000 street children in Eastern Congo
Protecting the rights of 5000 street children in Eastern Congo
Technology Enabled Education & Training reaching 2,682 rural primary teachers, principals and students in Sindh and KPK provinces, Pakistan
description: This project is designed to achieve rapid growth of students entering and completing primary education in Pakistan. It creates a technology and internet enabled environment to cost-efficiently multiply opportunities for delivering quality education to rural primary level students and teachers, especially women. The project also acts as an incubator for other basic and modern services to reach areas previously inaccessible.
sector-text: Technology for Education, teacher training, student project based learning

title: Programme Partnership Agreement
description: DFID Programme Partnership

title: Governance and Transparency Fund
description: Governancy & Transparency Fund (CN003) : Increasing government accountability in conflict zones through public participation in policymaking

title: Nationwide primary eye care training of Health Centre nurses in Rwanda to provide free vision assessments to an estimated 425,000 people and 30,000 eyeglasses to those in need.
description: Nationwide primary eye care training of Health Centre nurses in Rwanda to provide free vision assessments to an estimated 425,000 people and 30,000 eyeglasses to those in need.

title: Enhanced Participation in Primary Education (EPPE)
description: The project will contribute to poverty reduction, sustainable development, and the improved well being of 16,800 children in Somalia through enhanced access to quality and protective education, with particular focus on girls. This will be achieved by (i) increasing access to universal primary education, (ii) improving the quality of education and retention rates; and (iii) building the capacity of local partners to equitably deliver primary educational services into the future.

title: Disability Rights Fund
description: With an impact of equal rights and opportunities and full participation in society for PWDs in the Global South, MENA, and Eastern Europe, the outcome of the present request is advancement of rights of persons with disabilities through the enhanced participation of the disability movement. Expected outputs of funding in target countries over the three-year period are 1) greater DPO participation in legislative, policy and program changes in accordance with the CRPD; 2) greater DPO participation in human rights monitoring at national and international levels; 3) a more diverse and representative disability movement, which includes the most marginalized; and 4) grantees resourced and capacitated to advocate for and monitor implementation of rights â€“ ultimately contributing to a society that fully includes all PWDs in every aspect of life, as envisioned by the CRPD, and thereby, enhances their quality of life. ;A marginalized minority, persons with disabilities (PWDs) make up a disproportionate percentage of the poor in the developing world (80% of all people with disabilities live in the developing world and there, make up 20% of the worldâ€™s poorest people). Still, disability has not yet been widely recognized as important to many national or international poverty reduction strategies (e.g., disability is not mentioned in many PRSPs or in the Millennium Development Goals). Because human rights and poverty are deeply connected , and â€œaddressing exclusion in all its aspects is key to eliminating poverty,â€ù enhancing the participation of representative organizations of persons with disabilities in the realization of rights can have both a direct and indirect impact on poverty within this community. ;DRF is a pooled fund, which combines the resources of multiple governmental and private donors, and in doing so, enables these donors to harmonize their efforts and provides them with an efficient way to reach organizations of marginalized populations outside their normal purview. DRF operates under common control with the Disability Rights Advocacy Fund, Inc. (DRAF) .

title: Fresh Start: Re-entry to education and entrepreneurial skills training for vulnerable youth in Zambia
description: This project offers a fresh start to highly vulnerable and orphaned Zambian youth, helping them to return to school and learn how to generate a sustainable income so that they have the opportunity to escape poverty. Emerging entrepreneurs will compete for start-up capital to realise their role in the development of Zambia.
implementing_organisations: ;Afya Mzuri;BISO (Bwafwano Integrated Services Organisation);CHEP (Copperbelt Health Education Project);JAZ (Junior Achievement Zambia);Cecily's Fund

org-name: The Leprosy Mission England and Wales
reporting-organisation: The Leprosy Mission England and Wales
title: Reducing the physical and social barriers faced by 2,000 people with disabilities in seven States and Regions in Myanmar and improving their livelihood opportunities
description: This initiative, taking place in 7 States and Regions in Myanmar (Burma), will lead to a reduction in the physical and social barriers faced by PwD, particularly those faced by women with disabilities. This will enable them to access livelihood opportunities, providing them with dignified work and an income of more than US$1 a day. By the end of the project 2,000 persons (65% women) with disabilities will increase earnings to >US$1 per day equivalent through safe, dignified work.
sector-text: Access to livelihood opportunities for people with disabilities, providing them with dignified work and an income of more than US$1 a day. By the end of the project 2,000 persons (65% women) with disabilities will increase earnings to >US$1 per day equivalent through safe, dignified work.

title: Provision of support, reintegration and referral services for 1,020 children and youth on the Streets of Mwanza, Tanzania
description: This project will significantly reduce the number of children and youths sleeping on the streets of Mwanza. Youths will be enabled to engage constructively within society and to sustain their future livelihoods. Children will be reintegrated with their families in a safe environment where educational and basic needs are met as families are enabled to lift themselves out of poverty. An integrated cross-agency response will be in place to meet needs of vulnerable children beyond the project life. ;Umuhimu wa Mradi huu ni kupunguza kwa hali ya juu idadi ya watoto na Vijana wanaoishi na kulala mitaani jijini Mwanza. Vijana watawezeshwa kujumuika katika jamii kwa ajili ya manufaa ya maisha yao ya baadaye. Watoto watarejeshwa kwenye mazingira salama ya wazazi wao: Mahali ambapo watapata elimu na mahitaji muhimu kutokana na wazazi kuwezeshwa kuboresha kipato chao na kujiondoa katika umasikini. Nguvu ya pamoja ya mashirika inahitaji kukabili mahitaji ya watoto wanaoishi katika mazingira hatarishi hata baada ya mradi kuisha.

title: Improved Livelihoods for Kitale Children
description: The project aims to improve primary education for disadvantaged children and youth living alone on the streets of Kitale, thereby reducing the number of children coming to the streets and economically empowering them and their families, ensuring improved livelihoods;Mradi una lengo la kuboresha elimu ya msingi kwa watoto wasiojiweza na vijana wanaoishi peke yake katika mitaa ya Kitale, na hivyo kupunguza idadi ya watoto kuja mitaani na uwezo kiuchumi yao na familia zao, kuhakikisha maisha bora

title: Transforming Young Peoples Lives and Rebuilding Families
description: This programme seeks to improve the lives of young people in Nairobi and Kisumu through the Association Model and to build relationships in families through an intensive therapeutic response.

title: Test
Open Development Camp 2013
description: On the 7th & 8th of November the global leading event on Open Development will take place in Amsterdam. Building on the success of the Open Data for Development Camps (120 participants at ODDC Amsterdam 2011 and 400 for ODDC Amsterdam / Nairobi 2012), we will now bring together a broader movement around open data, open knowledge, open organizations, open government and social enterprises to jointly shape the future of development cooperation.;We expect a mix of people from different background with different levels of experience (designers, change makers, business people, hackers, development workers, social entrepreneurs, policy makers and researchers) but they all have one thing in common: they all love Open Development.
funding_organisations: ;Ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken;Partos;Text to Change;Akvo;1%CLUB;Oxfam Novib;NCDO;Cordaid

title: Integrated community livelihood support and care systems for 6,960 vulnerable rural families in Amuria District, Uganda
description: The people of Amuria district in Northern Uganda are recovering from prolonged conflict and insecurity. The project will support 6,960 vulnerable smallholder families, particularly those affected by HIV/AIDS to reduce the chronic poverty within their communities. It will do this by providing inputs and training to improve the productivity of their farms, incomes and access to effective HIV/AIDS services
sector-text: Includes livelihood imptovements through agricultural production, food security, and enterprise;

title: Food security for 16,990 men, women and children living with HIV/AIDS and improved livelihoods for 5,100 adults living with HIV/AIDS in western Kenya
description: This project will improve food security and livelihoods for 17,000 women, men, orphans and vulnerable children affected by HIV/AIDS in western Kenya and reduce discrimination and rights abuse. 5,740 households will be food secure, eating more nutritious food that reduces opportunistic infections and delays the onset of AIDS. 5,100 adults living with HIV/AIDS will establish or upgrade their own businesses, 60% of which deliver an increased annual income of at least 20%
recipient-country: Matayos, Matungu, Samia and Nambale Districts, Western Province, Kenya

title: Supporting the survival and inclusion of 2,000 disabled children in Uganda
description: Disabled people are the poorest of the poor. Their rights and needs are invariably ignored and they are not specifically included in the MDG targets. This project will empower mothers and caregivers of children with cerebral palsy to impact their childâ€™s health and survival, and their access to education and inclusion in society. It will seek to improve maternal health practice, establish professional wheelchair services, and provide access to economic empowerment opportunities.
funding_organisations: ;Department for International Development ;Various donors;Various donors;Various donors
implementing_organisations: ;Motivation Charitable Trust;Local partner organisations in Uganda

title: Increasing survival and reducing poverty of disabled children and adults in Malawi
description: Disabled children and adults have improved health, mobility and knowledge about the prevention of HIV/AIDS, enabling them to survive longer and be included in education and employment activities, thereby reducing their poverty and contributing to the MDGs in Malawi.

title: Pathways from Poverty (Southern Malawi)
description: Providing 6,300 women in Southern Malawi with financial services and support for small business development

title: Paths to School Success: adapting the Child-to-Child approach to increase on-time enrolment, retention and performance of children in post-disaster & emergency situations
description: Paths to School Success will increase on-time enrolment, retention and performance of pre- and primary school age boys and girls in disaster affected communities in Haiti and Pakistan. The project toolkit will use Child-to-Child approaches to develop childrenâ€™s academic and non-academic competencies focusing on disaster risk reduction, social emotional learning and trauma recovery to promote psychosocial wellbeing, thus providing critical foundations for school success.

description: Grow Movement empowers African entrepreneurs with business skills by phone, Skype and email. This is done by a global team of volunteer business professionals who commit 40 hours of their time across a 6 month period to share skills on marketing, finance and strategy.

title: Developing and supporting family care for the most vulnerable babies in nine states of Sudan and reforming the childcare system for Orphans and Vulnerable Children.
description: Working with the most vulnerable and socially excluded Sudanese women and babies, this project will develop a functional childcare system in nine of Sudanâ€™s 14 states. This will enable 3,421 babies to grow up in families, either their own (due to decreased social exclusion) or culturally appropriate foster or adoptive families. The project will work with 633 government staff and social workers to develop a childcare system that will endure post-project.

title: Prevention of sexual exploitation of children and young people in Bogota, Colombia
description: BogotÃ¡ YMCA provides psychological support to young people who have experienced commercial sexual exploitation and helps them access local services and support so they can learn about their legal rights and responsibilities. Teachers are also supported so they can raise awareness about sexual exploitation in their schools and families are supported to help with child protection and reduce domestic violence

title: Regional Multi-Country Health Programme for Young People, Africa
description: In 2012 Y Care International partnered with a YWCA and YMCAs in Liberia, Madagascar, Senegal, Togo, Zambia, Zimbabwe, the African Alliance of YMCAs and Sweden YWCA-YMCA to ensure that relevant and quality health information and services respond to the needs of hard to reach young people in six sub Saharan African countries.â€ù

title: Sierra Leone & Liberia: Supporting Youth Livelihoods
description: The main purpose of the project is to reduce poverty levels; social exclusion; improve governance around the issue of employment creation and vocational training and strengthen capacity of civil society to respond to the needs of young people at risk.

title: Sierra Leone; Slum Settlements
description: This project aims to transform the lives of vulnerable young people and their communities in two of the most deprived slums of Freetown, Sierra Leone. This will be achieved by providing appropriate vocational skills training, post-training support and educational and recreational activities to particularly disadvantaged young people, to help them earn an income, reduce social exclusion and participate in civic decision making. The project will also address the broader needs and rights of people living in urban slums through targeted community based activities led by young people, as well as by strengthening the capacity of community based structures to negotiate for better access to services for people living in slums.

title: Socio-economic empowerment of vulnerable young people - Madagascar
description: The project aims to improve the social and economic well-being of vulnerable YP in the Analamanga and Alaotra Mangoro regions of Madagascar. This is a four year programme (2012 - 2016) which will enable Madagascar YMCA to scale-up their work with YP. The project sites of Ankazomanga and Carion are in Analamanga, whilst Morarano is in Alaotra Mangoro. Using a combination of service delivery, capacity building and advocacy activities to ensure a sustainable impact on beneficiaries' lives, YCI will provide life skills and vocational training in trades professionally assessed to be in-demand; support training graduates to start new businesses with finances, materials and mentoring; and provide help to secure suitable work placements or employment. YCI will reduce YP's vulnerability to diseases by training peer educators to disseminate health education to their peers and facilitate access to services. We will work with local clinics to improve services for YP and set up medical dispensaries and health savings schemes. We will also provide civic education and training to enable YP to actively participate in and influence local decision-making processes. Madagascar YMCA and 4 youth-focused CSOs will benefit from technical and organisational capacity building and will in turn train 15 other CSOs in areas such as financial management and M&E. All will become members of a national Youth Watchdog, which will coordinate efforts and monitor progress on youth issues, as well as engage in research and advocacy to improve policy and programming for young people nationwide

title: Justice and Rehabilitation for young people in conflict with the law
description: To protect and promote the rights of 2,500 children and young people in conflict with the law and/ or at-risk in two urban sites in Togo (LomÃ©, the capital and AtakpamÃ©), through targeted service delivery in and out of prison, capacity building for government and civil society actors, and youth-led advocacy for change in policy and practice

title: Casamance: Post Conflict Transitional Support to War Affected Children and Young People.
description: YCI work with Senegal YMCA to support rural development in the conflict-affected region of Casamance, Senegal. This is achieved through an integrated programme of youth livelihoods, environmental sustainability and peace promotion work targeting disadvantaged young people. The project supports the creation of secure and sustainable livelihood opportunities through a combination of technical training, enterprise development and the promotion of cooperative working. Another key objective is to support local youth-led peace building initiatives to improve the prospects for a sustainable peace and development in the region.

title: Kroo Bay Grant - Sierra Leone
description: Following a Comic Relief filming visit to Freetown in January 2012, a grant was secured to provide additional support to the young girl featured in the filming (Kadiatu), her family and her neighbours for a two year period from August 2012 to July 2014. Support will be provided to improve local housing and sanitation, ensure Kadiatu and other children from surrounding households are able to attend school, as well as providing livelihoods support to women in the immediate community.

title: Madurai YMCA After School Support and Vocational Training
description: The project aims to support disadvantaged children and young people from Muthupatty Village, to ensure that they attain the education and skills required to secure a sustainable income and livelihood. The Evening Study Centre will facilitate school going poor children to excel in their studies by providing evening coaching classes under the supervision of qualified tutors. They will also take part in supervised recreational activities and enjoy nutritious refreshments to improve their health and well-being. In addition, mothers of disadvantaged children will be supported to develop skills and savings schemes through Self-Help Groups, helping to reduce the pressure on the young people in their care to drop out of school. Therefore, this project will benefit young school going children, disadvantaged young people and their parents and guardians.

title: Salem YWCA: Livelihood support for HIV affected young people
description: The Radiance project will support HIV/AIDS infected and/or affected young people to improve their work and life prospects through vocational training and job-related support. The project will benefit over 1,000 disadvantaged young people in the Salem district of India over its 2 year lifetime. The vocational training will take place in Salem City, Attur, Valapady and Omular districts in Salem. A flexible schedule of training including evenings and weekends will be initiated to ensure that young people are able to attend without missing work and family commitments. The key beneficiaries will include: Unemployed youth? School Dropouts? young people on low incomes The young people who participate in vocational training will also be trained to have greater awareness of HIV/AIDS and other Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs). They will also be supported to improve their leadership and life skills. Youth groups will be formed in each target area and they will actively participate in events such as blood drives, AIDS rallies and other community development activities. The project also aims to support young people into employment through job fairs, referral to microloan opportunities and business skill training.

title: Cambodia YMCA - Informal Education and Vocational Training for Street Children
description: We work with Cambodia YMCA to help street children get the knowledge and skills to improve their lives. By providing a safe space to learn and play, young people get a chance to improve their skills and gain confidence to get back into school.

title: Pakistan: Nowshera (KPK Province); Livelihood Development Project for Youth in flood hit areas
description: 1. To provide opportunities to 150 youth to start and effectively run their businesses/means of livelihoods in 14 months duration of the project; 2. To enable the selected youth (both male and female) to perform their roles as peace makers by arranging orientation sessions and other sharing forums; 3. To provide platform in the form of business forums for sharing of best practices related to upgrading of businesses and to facilitate other youth and local business community for livelihood development.

title: Beit Sahour; Empowering Disabled Young People in the West Bank
description: By the close of the project, East Jerusalem YMCA and Y Care International intend to support 480 disabled young people through individual and family counselling, at least 350 to have increased educational and employment opportunities, and at least 640 disabled young people to be better able to tackle stigma and discrimination and demand their rights.

title: Zambia Support to Street Children and Young People
description: We support street children and young people in Lusaka, providing them with a safe place to meet and play, healthy meals and youth workers who can support them with healthcare and education.

title: Pakistan: Punjab & Khyber Pakhtoonkhaw (KPK); Engaging youth in policy advocacy in flood affected areas
East Jerusalem Womenâ€™s Training Programme (EJWTP)
description: Activating the role of young females and increase their ability to promote women participation in the labor market in Palestine.

title: Myanmar; Empowering civil society to promote the enhanced socio-economic wellbeing of vulnerable young people
description: Young people in Myanmar (Burma) will develop and lead disaster risk reduction activities in their local communities to mitigate the impacts of natural hazards. YMCA Pathein and their volunteers will train young people in disaster preparedness and disaster risk reduction so they can raise awareness amongst their peers, families and communities.

title: Nicaragua: Feeding the Next Generation: Supporting Young Nicaraguans to BecomeÂ  Productive, Sustainable Farmers
description: This project aims to strengthen and increase the sustainability of the livelihoods of 980 vulnerable young people (between 15 and 30 years of age) and their families in 4 rural areas of Nicaragua. This will be achieved by working with young people living on small hold farms, their parents, community members, local civil society organisations, and peers. The project outcomes are all focussed on young people who will be the primary beneficiaries of all changes this project will bring about.

title: Inclusion of marginalized youth in Guatemalan society
description: YCI supports a sports and arts project which reaches young people in schools and communities and teaches young people how to reduce conflict without using violence or joining gangs. We help educate young people on drug use and support those facing violence to find ways out of it and to be heard. We also help young people influence people in power to improve their rights.

Securing Healthy Lives and Sustainable Livelihoods for 10,000 Vulnerable Youth in Rural Liberia
description: Project intended impact: Livelihoods and health of vulnerable young people in 4 countries (Nimba, Bong, Lofa and Grand Gedeh) in Liberia are improved.

title: Increasing household incomes and financial resilience for 5,180 extremely disadvantaged people in 22 rural villages in Pakistan
description: This project will contribute towards reducing poverty and gender inequality for 5,180 young women and household members in 22 rural villages in Umerkot district, Sindh province, Pakistan. Disadvantaged young women will benefit from income generation in traditional embroidery and textile products, much demanded in high-end urban markets, combined with a community-wide strategy to improve women's empowerment and decision-making capabilities in their communities.

title: DISABILITY & LIVELIHOOD SERVICESâ€™ ACCESS CAMBODIA
description: This initiative intends to achieve change both at individual and community level. At individual level, the project will give the opportunity to 1520 vulnerable men and women with disabilities and/or members of families living with disability (M:760, F:760, 70% men and women with disabilities, 30% families) to access socioeconomic opportunities and to develop their skills. The development of income generating activities will not only contribute to alleviate poverty (household budget increase), but it will also lead to individual empowerment. Indeed, in a country where productivity is considered as a crucial factor of social recognition, the project will help women and men with disabilities and/or their families, through economic activity, to take control over their life, to gain self confidence and to get a chance to actively participate into both family and community life and decision making. At community level, the project intends to change perceptions on the socioeconomic potential of persons with disabilities and to support disability inclusion into both service provision and local government management (24 communes). In line with legal provisions and policies promoting equal access and representation, existing both in Cambodia (Law on the Protection and Promotion of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities adopted in July 2009 and National Plan of Actions for Persons with Disabilities adopted in November 2008) and at international level (UNCRPD signed by the Royal Government of Cambodia in 2007, ratification actions currently in process) Support to 18 local service providers will permit to remove existing barriers for long term-benefit and to provide, on a short-term basis, services to 400 men and women with disabilities and/or families living with disability (M:200, F:200) as described in 3.4. Intervention at local government level, through the existing planning process (CIP), with strong involvement from local authorities and local Disabled Peopleâ€™s Organizations (2 DPOs), will ensure long term sustainable changes
implementing_organisations: ;Operation Enfants du Cambodge ;Cambodian Disabled People's Organisation;Nak Akphivath Sahakum (NAS)

title: Inclusive futures in Rwanda: establishing and applying a set of national standards and norms in inclusive education
description: This project will focus on increasing the capacity of national institutions (Rwanda Education Board (REB), Kigali Institute of Education (KIE) and the Task Force for the Development of Inclusive Education in Rwanda (TFDIER)) in the development of a model (norms, standards and tools) to reinforce the quality of education for CWDs and other SENs.;The innovation will increase access to quality education, participation and retention of CWDs and other SEN in Rwanda. It will do this through: the development of norms and standards on inclusive education & special needs education; strengthening the capacity of the Rwanda Education Board (REB), the Task Force for the Development of Inclusive Education in Rwanda (TFDIER), local authorities, special centres and other local and community stakeholders to apply, monitor and enforce these standards; and so improving learning outcomes.
sector-text: Inclusive Education for children with disabilities

title: Nehemiah
description: Improve overall living standard of the communities in Narok in a holistic community-based program. This will include increasing food security and enhancing livelihood alternatives of 500 households, enhancing community governance in six communities, enhancing spiritual formation and spiritual growth and incorporating cross-cutting activities.
sector-text: 1) Train on pasture management; 2) Train on animal health in collaboration with the ministry of livestock and other animal health providers; 3) Assess the potential of beekeeping in the Mara; 4) Create awareness on the need to factor in environmental conservation activities as integral activites in water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) and food security; 5) Integrate conflict resolution and mitigation in all project trainings; 6) Mainstream gender in all trainings; 7) Carry out trainings on disaster preparedness and mitigation by incorporating appropriate early warning systems in programming; 8) Create awareness on policy issues (livestock, water, resource mobilization, and infrastructure); 9) Training on accountability, transparency, and feedback mechanisms; 10) Revise the current community development committees training curriculum; 11) Hold two workshops for evangelists and pastors; 12) Hold 7 day evangelistic mission in one community (last six months of FY12); 13) Distribute bibles to the churches in the communities; and 14) Train church elders, lay leaders, Sunday school teachers and pastors on discipleship skills

title: Technical Assistance for the Implementation Expansion of Blood Safety Activities
description: '''The goal of the Technical Assistance for the Implementation and Expansion of Blood Safety Activities in Kenya program is to ensure Kenyan health facilities have a safe and sufficient blood supply. By building on current policies and procedures, while strengthening local actors, CHFâ€™s integrated, participatory, multi-sectoral approach is designed to strengthen the Kenya National Blood Transfusion Service (KNBTS) system and reinforce the capacity of indigenous organizations to provide quality sustainable services. This is done by targeting technical assistance (TA) to the Ministry of Medical Services, KNBTS and its affiliates as well as its partner organization, the Africa Society for Blood Transfusion Kenya (AfSBTK). Program Goal: To ensure the provision of a safe and sufficient blood supply to health facilities in Kenya through the provision of expert guidance and targeted TA to NBTS and affiliates. Objective 1: Establish and assist a Technical Working Group (TWG) to guide the implementation of policies and guidelines that are in line with national and international standards. Objective 2: Use the RBTC and satellites as a platform for delivery of TA and ensuring that the NBTS is strengthened at all levels. Objective 3: Strengthen the organizational capacity of AfSBT-K to serve as an expert advisor and technical counterpart to NBTS in the field of blood transfusion services.'' '

title: Improving income, assets and food security of 3,200 women affected by conflict and poverty in South Kivu, DRC and Ruhango District, Rwanda

In support of these aims the project includes a complementary health and justice component.

title: Malaria Consortium Programme Partnership Arrangement
description: Malaria Consortium's Programme Partnership Arrangement with the UK Department for International Development is for Â£2.6million each year for three years from April 2011 to March 2014. PPA is one of DFID's main support mechnaisms for civil society enabling them to plan and deliver programmes inlcuding in more difficult, higher risk environments. PPAs are aimed at civil society organisations with a global reach and who are leaders in their field. Malaria Consortium uses this flexible strategic funding to drive forward its Mission to bring to poor people relief from and protection against communicable diseases , especially malaria, by being a leading organisation combining cutting edge tehnical ability and operational excellence.
implementing_organisations: ;Malaria Consortium;London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

title: Reflecting on Peace Practice Program
description: CDAâ€™s Reflecting on Peace Practice program (RPP) aims to strengthen the way organizations wage peace. The programâ€™s current focus is on how peacebuilding programs can â€œadd upâ€ù to societal-level peace, as well as how to strengthen peace program design and evaluation. Detailed in the book, Confronting War: Critical Lessons for Peace Practitioners, RPPâ€™s core insights and contributions to the field include RPPâ€™s Building Blocks Toward Peace and the RPP Matrix, both of which help practitioners design programs to contribute to what RPP calls Peace Writ Large. Further tools and exercises include the RPP Program Reflection Exercise, created to review and improve program logic and planning, including theories of change. The RPP Participant Training Manual, elucidates key RPP findings across program phases, from analysis to implementation and review. Various RPP issue papers explore special topics, from strategies for handling key actors who are â€œhard to reach,â€ù to the contribution of civil society to peacebuilding processes. Recent working papers explore RPPâ€™s contribution to the evaluation of peacebuilding programs. These materials are available at www.cdacollaborative.org.
recipient-country: Program is based in the US, but works globally, with particular focus in Africa, Asia, Middle East and Latin America,
sector-text: This program addresses multiple dimensions of peacebuilding and conflict prevention at all stages, including activities of multilateral agencies, international NGOs and local organizations.

title: Corporate Engagement Program
description: The Corporate Engagement Program (CEP) promotes the development of positive, constructive relationships between companies and the local communities where corporate operations take place. The book Getting it Right: Making Corporate-Community Relations Work (published April 2009) encapsulates lessons learned during the first nine years of the program and draws on the experience of companies and local stakeholders in over 40 operating sites of international companies working under difficult circumstances. It presents a framework for company managers to analyze the consequences of their decisions for communities and practical management options for improving corporate impacts. The evidence gathering that led to Getting it Right is the foundation of CEPâ€™s ongoing work to help companies sustain and improve social performance. CEP engages individual corporations as partners, advising them about social responsibility strategy and incorporating conflict sensitivity and human rights considerations into their community relations approaches. In this respect, we work with - rather than for - companies in the spirit of collaborative learning. CEP participates in global initiatives to establish and implement standards for responsible business and develops tools and guidance to help companies improve their relationships with their external stakeholders. To broaden the impact of our knowledge, we also engage with a broad range of other actors, including civil society organizati0ns, multi-lateral institutions, and industry associations.
sector-text: This program addresses the impacts of corporate operations on communities and conflicts.

title: Listening Program
description: The Listening Program (LP) believes that the people best situated to evaluate the impacts and effectiveness of international aid are those who receive it. Yet, despite the best intentions of international actors, the voices of aid recipients too often remained unheard when aid decisions are made that affect their lives. From late 2005 through 2009, LP organized 21 Listening Exercises across 20 countries to ask international aid recipients: â€œWhat has been your personal experience with international assistance?â€ù â€œWhat approaches did you find useful or effectiveâ€”and which not?â€ù Through these Listening Exercises, we gathered the thoughts, opinions and ideas of nearly 6,000 people around the world who have received assistance or observed its effects. This evidence was compiled and distilled into the book, Time to Listen: Hearing People on the Receiving End of International Aid. This book describes why the cumulative impacts of international aid efforts have not met expectations. It describes a way forward to make changes that, according to those on the receiving end, will lead to more effective and lasting results. (Available in pdf format on www.cdacollaborative.org ) The LP is continuing its efforts to improve the practice and effectiveness of international aid efforts by engaging with donors, aid agencies, and others through other projects that also focus on gathering, listening to, and responding to the feedback and priorities of the people we seek to support.
sector-text: This program addresses key issues regarding AID EFFECTIVENESS--from the point of view of people at the receiving end.

title: Do No Harm Program
description: Aid agencies work in complex and uncertain environments. The Do No Harm Program (DNH) provides well-tested and rigorous analysis frameworks for reducing complexity and managing uncertainty. The aim of DNH is to help assistance workers understand and deal with the complexities of providing assistance with better outcomes for the societies where assistance is provided. Why â€œConflict Sensitivityâ€ù and Do No Harm? First, it is our responsibility. If our aim is to help people, then we must avoid causing harm to them. Second, it leads to more effective programming. Having a better understanding of and relationship with a community makes everything better and easier, from planning and design through implementation, monitoring, and evaluation. Third, it is cheaper. It is far less costly to prevent or avoid conflict than to deal with its impacts later. Conflict destroys what we have built physically and socially and sets back the communities and our efforts. Do No Harm Analysis. Do No Harmâ€™s analytical frameworks perform two complementary functions: highlighting the information necessary to work in uncertain environments while also, and importantly, filtering out the unnecessary. Used by thousands of people around the world, DNH provides valuable insights that lead to developing better options and improved decision making.
sector-text: The program addresses the conflict sensitivity of all sectors of assistance to fragile states and conflict affected areas.

title: Increasing access, enrolment and retention in primary education, through increased birth and death registration, for children in Bulawayo and Matabeleland Provinces, Zimbabwe.
description: Working in the Bulawayo and Matabeleland provinces of Zimbabwe, in association with our project delivery partner Trinity Project Trust, the project will engage communities in a dialogue about the ways in which the non-registration of births and parental deaths can hinder a childâ€™s access to education and other services. By increasing awareness of these issues, and through the provision free legal services and advice, it will help orphans and other vulnerable children access these important documents. This will enable children to enrol in education and improve their access to inheritance and government support, which will allow them to finance their education and bring them out of poverty.

title: Improving Maternal and Child Health and Access to Safe Water and Sanitation Facilities for 71,954 Beneficiaries in River Gee County, Liberia
description: This project will improve the health of 14,103 children under five and 15,669 women and their communities (71,954 total) in River Gee County, Liberia. Through training and equipping 670 mothers to provide lessons on childhood nutrition, diarrhoea control and maternal/infant care, improving WASH facilities and outreaching to men, local leaders and health volunteers will promote behaviours that empower women, leading to better maternal and child health and saving 336 lives.
sector-text: Maternal and Child Health

title: Karamoja Integrated Maternal Child Health Project in Napak District, Uganda
description: The purpose of this project is to increase access to and take up of essential Maternal child health services and encourage positive behaviour change and integrated management of newborn and child illnesses in the Napak district of Karamoja sub region of Uganda, thereby contributing to a reduction in the high maternal and under five mortality rates in these district. The project takes a three-pronged approach: 1. It empowers women with the knowledge, skills and attitudes they need to improve maternal child health and access locally available services. 2. It addresses cultural barriers and engages the wider community to ensure a supportive environment in which women are able to take charge of their health and the health of their family. 3. It supports health personnel to practice Integrated Management of newborn and childhood illnesses and lobbies ministry of Health for improved service provision where it is lacking.
sector-text: Maternal and Child Health

title: Provision of innovative microfinance for very poor and marginalised people in India
description: This activity supports the work of Centre for Promoting Sustainable Livelihood (CPSL), Patna, Bihar, India, a NGO registered in Bihar State under the Societies Act of 1860. CPSL uses a low-cost approach to provide microfinance to rural women who are much poorer and more socially excluded than existing clients of most microfinance programmes. This innovative method of delivering microfinance for the poor is based on research that demonstrates it significantly reduces vulnerability, increases asset ownership, improves access to primary education and reduces domestic violence.

title: Improving livelihoods for 6,000 marginalised women in DRC and supporting their access to land
description: This project will provide 6,000 socially-excluded women in South Kivu, DRC with a holistic training programme that will enable them to understand their rights; gain agricultural skills; access land and credit; and increase incomes. It will contribute to creating an enabling environment for women by training 1,500 male leaders on womenâ€™s rights and strategies to facilitate these rights; and by placing womenâ€™s right to access land on DRCâ€™s development agenda via research and advocacy.
extending_organisations: ;Women for Women International (UK);Women for Women International

title: Improving Livelihoods and Rights Awareness for Socially-Excluded Nigerian Women through Vocational Training and Menâ€™s Engagement
description: The project will provide 4,500 disadvantaged women in rural Enugu, Nigeria, with a holistic programme of support that will enable them to build agribusiness skills; boost incomes; know their rights; and improve participation in household and community decision making. The project will also contribute to creating a local environment that supports women's leadership and economic contribution through the training of 150 male leaders on womenâ€™s rights who will, in turn, engage 1,500 male community and family members to increase awareness.

reporting-organisation: World Wide Fund for Nature - Pakistan
title: Improving Livelihood of Fisher Communities in Central Indus Wetlands Complex
description: Ecologically, Central Indus Wetlands Complex (CIWC) is one of the most significant stretchesof wetlands in the country. It includes braided, and meandering river channels, islands, dhands or oxbow lakes and seasonally flooded depressions in the floodplain. This region covers three wetlands protected areas under the provincial wildlife legislations: i) Chashma Barrage Wildlife Sanctuary, ii) Taunsa Barrage Wildlife Sanctuary, and iii) Indus Dolphin Reserve. The first two are located in Punjab Province and the third in Sindh Province. Because of their socio-ecological significance, these protected areas are also designated as Ramsar Sites.Part of the CIWC is included in the Indus Eco-region, a Global 200 Eco-region that serves as an important migratory route, the famous Indus Flyway, and also the habitat for several threatened bird and animal species. Majority of the people living in CIWC are below the poverty line without any basic facilities. Further, low development in the area perpetuate a variety of socio-economic problems such as poverty, limited income earning opportunities, income disparity, and dependence on agriculture, fishing and other natural resource based income sources. Fishermen residing along the banks of the River Indus have a key stake in the sustainable use of these wetlands and associated biodiversity resources. With the financial support of Department for International Development (DFID) under its Global Poverty Action Fund (GPAF), WWF - Pakistanis implementing a project titled â€œImproving Livelihoods of Fisher Communities in Central Indus, Pakistanâ€ù. The project spans over a period of three years for the entire 780 km long stretch of Central Indus focussing at improving the livelihoods of at least 1,700 households of fishermen with an average size of 10 person per household. The project plans to support poverty-environment nexus.

reporting-organisation: World Wide Fund for Nature - Pakistan
title: Improving Chilghoza Forest and Livelihood, Sulaiman Range

title: Improving maternal, reproductive and child health services for 285,760 people in Southern Ethiopia
description: This project will contribute to the reduction of poverty through improved maternal health and reduced child mortality in Ethiopia. It will specifically increase the utilization of maternal and child health services in Segen and South Omo. The project will work to raise community awareness, train community and mid level health workers, and strengthen the district health system. The project will benefit 157,033 women of reproductive age; 105,138 children under 5 and 23,589 children under 1.
recipient-country: Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples Region: South Omo and Segen Zones

This will be achieved through improving the production, quality, management and marketing of sesame and building support services and institutions which have the capacity to advocate for improved agricultural policy on sesame and the oil crops subsector.

description: To mutually and sustainably enhance the unique biodiversity and vital ecological processes of the Bale Mountains Eco-region, and the social and economic well-being of communities dependent on the eco-system's natural resources. Activities include community-based natural resource management; development of diversified and sustainable livelihoods so as to decrease pressure on natural resources: development of sustainable natural resource-based enterprises and the facilitation of an enabling environment through capacity building of government services and community institution building.

description: Securing sustainable management of Ethiopia's forests and reduce environmental degradation. The project will also further contribute to the long-term conservation and improvement of the forest condition in Ethiopia through adoption, expansion and implementation of Participatory Forest Management (PFM) in four regions. Further intervention will increase the contribution to poverty reduction and improvement of livelihoods through identification of and development of viable non-timber forest product enterprises.
funding_organisations: ;European Union;Efico;The Big Give;Dulverton Trust;Vitol Charitable Foundation;Mitsubishi Corp Fund;International Institute for Environment & Development

title: Afar Emergency Drought Response
description: Farm Africa will support 7,252 households to withstand and recover from drought by immediately improving food security through improving livestock productivity and milk supply and protecting their major livelihood assets (livestock) through timely provision of animal feed and veterinary services; support 4,144 households to cope with current drought conditions and improve their capacity to cope in the future through immediate provision of water and repair and rehabilitation of dysfunctional water points; enhance the capacity of 300 vulnerable pastoralist households to prepare for and withstand drought through training in alternative livelihood activities, early warning and emergency preparedness; and training of government extension staff enabling them to better support vulnerable households.
funding_organisations: ;Cordaid;Christadelphian Meal-a-Day ;Buckingham Rotary Club ;The Peter Stebbings Memorial Trust

title: Testing Participatory Rangeland Management in Bale District
description: Farm Africa will thoroughly test and develop an effective approach to improving rangeland resource management, thus enhancing pastoral livelihoods and pastoralistsâ€™ resilience. The project comprises a one-year pilot phase in one pastoralist location, followed by a five-year programme to roll the approach out to other locations in Bale and three other pastoralist regions for further testing, development and refining. The objectives of the initial pilot project are to develop and test Participatory Rangeland Management (PRM) as a land use planning and management system in Ethiopiaâ€™s lowlands; improve the productive capacity of rangelands in one district of Bale Zone, Oromiya; enhance community/state and community/investor engagement in managing rangelands in the target district; and document the approach for use in scaling out, through the production of a PRM implementation manual.

title: Afar Prosopis Management Project Phase II
description: This project will enhance food security through natural resources management for communities in the Afar region. The main activities will include diversifying and improving pastoral and agro-pastoral livelihoods through improving environmental management; and enhancing the competence and capacity of the community, CSOs/CBOs, partners and local government structures.

title: Increase Micro Finance and enhance agricultural productivity in SNNPR
description: This project will use market driven approaches and microfinance to stimulate wealth-generating activities to improve food security and pathways to graduation for the GoE Productive Safety Net Programme (PSNP) and Household Asset Building Programme (HABP). The areas of implementation include value chain devlopment in high potential, low risk cash crops (ginger and pepper) for chronically food insecure households, promotion of rural saving and credit facilities to support income generating activities and household asset building and building the technical capacity of Woreda administration offices and ATVET colleges.

title: Enhancing Food Security, Stability & Resilience
description: To improve the productivity of crop-livestock production system in the Bale highlands of Oromiya region by integrating pulses in the mixed farming systems. Accelerating the adoption rate of improved varieties of faba bean, field pea, lentil, and chickpea along with the recommended production technologies through knowledge empowerment, technology intervention and input supply.

title: Barley Pilot & Pulses Pilot
description: Farm Africa will support unions and farmers to deliver 1,000 metric tonnes of barley suitable for malting.

title: Sustainable Agriculture for Improved Food Security in Tigray
description: Aims to contribute to economic empowerment and better nutrition for poor women and landless youth by increasing their annual income through a number of activities which utilise rehabilitated lands. Particularly by developing fruit and vegetable value chains and developing forage supply.

title: Participatory Rangeland Management in Afar
description: Drawing on lessons from Farm Africaâ€™s Participatory Rangeland Management pilot in Bale and the Afar Prosopis Management Programme, Participatory Rangeland Management in Afar will cover parts of the Aledeghi natural reserve. The project aims to restore the Aledeghi rangeland through participatory approaches for better livelihoods and more productive livestock. Specific aims are to increase the numbers of hectares of rangeland under management to 20,000 by 2016 and increase the income of 6,000 pastoralists by 2016 via livestock and alternative rangeland-based livelihoods.

title: Bale Phase II
description: Farm Africa will become the first to introduce a REDD+ project to Ethiopia. The Bale Eco-Region is distinctly rich in biodiversity, forming one of the 34 Global Biodiversity Hotspots. The forest also protects the headwaters of many major rivers in the southeastern drainage basin, affecting the livelihoods of some 12 million pastoral and agro-pastoral people in Ethiopia, Somalia and Kenya. The project will implement activities in three key areas: community mobilisation and sustaining community support for REDD+; enhancing the organisational and managerial capacity of Community Organizations (CBOs); and business development amongst forest communities.

title: Western Kenya Community Livelihoods Project (WEKLEP)
description: To contribute towards improved livelihoods through participatory community driven development in Vihiga District. The action envisages to promote community rooted democracy, good governance, balanced gender relations and development. FARM-Africa will carry out CAHW and dairy goat management training. Shamilah from Uganda TAU will do this.

title: Youth Empowerment through Sustainable Agriculture (YESA)
description: This project aims to increase food security and enable young people to create viable livelihood opportunities and take measures to improve their sexual and reproductive health.
funding_organisations: ;Vitol Charitable Foundation ;Medicor;Blandford Lake Trust ;Isle of Man ;Dulverton Trust;Austin Bailey Foundation ;Grimmitt Trust

title: Aqua Shops

The Aqua Shop works as a hub to provide a range of products and services including fish feed, fingerlings, fish seed, nets, water testing kits, water pumps and most crucially, technical advice and published information to out-grower groups.

title: Livestock Surveillance, Reporting and Information Management
description: This project is a pilot scheme trialling innovative approaches to surveying livestock diseases in Kenya. If left undetected diseases spread quickly through livestock, ravaging the livelihoods of farmers. Keeping accurate records of the spread of livestock disease provides key information for vets and farmers, enabling them to prevent and contain the spread of disease amongst their livestock. FARM-Africa is answerable to DFID however the Dept. of Veterinary Services, Kenya, is responsible for overall technical direction of the grant and will receive payment from FARM-Africa in instalments.

title: Moyale Drought Response Project
description: The three main objectives of the project are to support pastoralist communities in meeting their immediate needs, strengthen the capacity of pastoralists to withstand drought and improve the capacity of pastoralists to recover from drought. Activities will include distribution of animal feed, emergency water supply, rehabilitation of boreholes and shallow wells, maintenance of other water services and rehabilitation of water pans and dams.

title: Kitui Conservation Agriculture
description: This project is being implemented in consortium with AMREF as the lead partner. The purpose of the project is to reduce poverty and improve health and food security by increasing poor communities' access to sustainable, safe and adequate water and sanitation whilst also improving food production using conservation agriculture and the cultivation of drought tolerant crops. Farm Africa will be implementing the conservation agriculture and cultivation of drought tolerant crops element of the project, building on our work in Kitui on the Dryland Farming Project.

title: Development Grant Poultry Production & Marketing Project
description: Supporting poultry farmers to learn and practise improved poultry husbandry techniques and increase poultry productivity to a commercial level. It will also support the formation of farmersâ€™ groups and a Producer and Marketing Association to establish strong and profitable market links.

description: Supporting poultry farmers to learn and practise improved poultry husbandry techniques and increase poultry productivity to a commercial level. It will also support the formation of farmersâ€™ groups and a Producer and Marketing Association to establish strong and profitable market links.

The Aqua Shop works as a hub to provide a range of products and services including fish feed, fingerlings, fish seed, nets, water testing kits, water pumps and most crucially, technical advice and published information to out-grower groups.

description: This project aims to increase food security and enable young people to create viable livelihood opportunities and take measures to improve their sexual and reproductive health.

title: Sustainable Nou Forest Ecosystem Management Programme
description: To alleviate poverty of forest-dependent communities in Babati and Mbulu districts, Manyara region. Specifically, the action will empower forest-dependent communities as co-managers of the Nou Forest ecosystem through sustainable land use planning, participatory forest management and implementing livelihood activities.

title: Maendeleo Agricultural Enterprise Fund (MAEF)
description: MAEF builds on the success of its predecessor, the Maendeleo Agriculture Technology Fund (MATF). The project's aim is to sustainably improve the livelihoods of smallholder farmers in Eastern Africa through investing in agricultural technologies on value addition and entrepreneurship for output markets. MAEF will expand on the geographical remit of MATF and and has new and more flexible funding mechanisms to embrace a wider range of both applicants and donor investors.

title: Tanzania Participatory Forest Management Project (TPFMP)
description: This project aims to promote sustainable forest management through improved participatory forest management systems and tangible forest-based livelihoods, to meet local and national needs.

title: Cassava Scale-Out Project
description: To develop community based seed multiplication systems of CMD resistant cassava varieties to supply to smallholder farmers. In addition, the project will provide credit facilities to farmers for the timely purchase of inputs such as planting materials and fertiliser through private micro-finance organisations and agro-chemical dealers. The project will also facilitate the formation of efficient production and marketing farmer groups. Smallholder farmers will produce enough cassava for home consumption and processing. The project will establish processing plants to facilitate the production of dried chips and high quality flour.

title: Upland Rice, Legumes and Maize Project
description: The project aims is to reduce poverty and improve food security for smallholder rice, legumes and maize farmers by supporting farmers to implement technology in the production of rice and legumes. Through improved production farmers and their families will have enough nutritious food to eat with surplus to sell to local and regional markets. Support will also be provided with managing the crops, pre and post harvest, so that crop quality is improved and better prices can be achieved. The project will also work to strengthen the capacity of famer groups, enabling them to link in more effectively with markets and engage with stakeholders to improve the policy environment for smallholder farmers.

title: Programme Partnership Agreement

title: Supporting Uptake of Time and Energy Saving Technologies for Women
description: This project, aims to support smallholder women farmers in Ethiopia by providing basic technology to increase efficiency and reduce workloads. Examples of technology include: manual seed drills, long handle weeders, medium-sized hand operated shellers for maize and sorghum threshers.

title: The Climate Smart Initiative
description: Climate Smart Initiative (CSI)

title: Scaling up of Community based Seed Production and Multiplication
description: To build and strengthen the farmers cooperatives and Farmers Training Centers support mechanisms and processes aimed at increasing access to agricultural technologies such as improved quality seeds information. The project approach is to build and strengthen the farmers cooperatives and Farmers Training Centres ( FTC) support mechanisms and processes aimed at increasing access to agricultural technologies such as improved quality seeds information. The goal is to increase food security and economic growth for women and men smallholder farmers in SNNPR. Project outputs: 1) Increased and diversified crop productivity for male and female producers (establish seed producing groups/cooperatives, provision of improved seeds...) 2) Improved natural resource management (establish nursery and seedling production..) 3) Improved institutional and community capacity to support the availability, dissemination and use of agricultural technologies and information (support seed producer farmers cooperatives with seed stores and office construction...)

title: SHARE - Conservation of Biodiversity and Ecosystems Functions within Bale Eco Region
description: To enhance drought resilience, food and nutrition security of vulnerable populations in Southern and Eastern Ethiopia. Specific objective: Conserve biodiversity /ecosystems functions/services in Bale Eco-Region BER and increase resilience and well-being of highland/lowland communities
implementing_organisations: ;SOS Sahel;Frankfurt Zoological Society ;International Water Management Institute

title: BRACED (Building Resilience & Adaptation to Climate Extremes & Disasters)
description: This project will reduce vulnerability amongst pastoralist, agropastoralist and peri-urban populations in lowland areas of Ethiopia by promoting more resilient social and economic systems that are better able to adapt to increasing climate-related shocks. Through modelling and partnership it will enhance institutional knowledge and learning within the public and private sector, of how â€˜greenâ€™ growth approaches can support strengthened climate resilience. Engagement with public and private sector enterprise will lead to examples of successful market-based approaches for resilience-building, which will in turn inform development policy, planning and practice, as well as enabling environment for business in the lowlands.

title: Livelihood Diversification through Sorghum and Green Gram Value Chain Development
description: To promote and develop sorghum and green gram value chains in order to strengthen the capacity of communities to mitigate the impact of and ability to recover from recurrent droughts through sustainable income generation.

title: Improving Smallholder Livelihoods through the Sesame Value Chain (Phase iii)
description: The project will use best practice approaches developed by FA/Inades/MVIWATA to address barriers which prevent poor smallholders from benefiting from the sesame value chain. Identified constraints include: poor access to quality seed/agro inputs, good agricultural practices(GAP) training, pests, high prices for seed, aggregation by weight instead of volume, high transport costs, lack of knowledge of marketing principles, low take up of micro credit, lack of access to agro inputs, storage materials and poor links between smallholders and buyers. Men can hinder womenâ€™s access to farming resources and youth remain disinterested in agricultural livelihoods. The project will adopt a holistic approach to address barriers stopping smallholders from increasing their yields and receiving a fair price for their produce.

title: Nutrition and Food Security for Himalayan Children
description: Tribal communities in the Indian Himalayas are very poor and lack access to healthcare and sufficient food, which has brutal effects on children & women. The project aims to improve food security & dietary status in Himalayan families, reduce hunger among children and improve child & maternal health. It will help women to grow nutritive food and manage family diet and village water/sanitation facilities, train health workers, and assist Himalayan families with food stores.

title: Community Centred Prevention of Malnutrition (CCPM) Community-based Growth Promotion Programme
description: GOALâ€™s Community Centred Prevention of Malnutrition aims to improve the nutritional security of households either affected by malnutrition or at risk of suffering from malnutrition through participatory nutrition/health education and diet diversity promotion. The three main components of the intervention are 1) Behaviour Change Communication and Counselling; 2) Micro-gardens for food-nutrition security and 3) Positive Deviance cooking & food demonstrations.

title: Renforcement des mÃ©canismes de protection des enfants dans le contexte marquÃ© par le mouvement des populations a Bangui et Bossangoa.
description: Fourteen Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) were set up in Bangui and Bossangoa. Protection, education and livelihoods activities were run as alternative to schools (whilst these remained closed in 2014).;(1) To ensure that at least 20% of children from IDP have access to and attend the 10 CFS by through psychosocial educative and recreative activities. (2) 500 children affected by the crisis benefit from a proper referring. (3) 3000 children/adolescents participate in group discussions and awareness-raising sessions around child protection, GBV, HIV and Aids (4) 12,500 members of CBOs will be trained to cope with threats posed by current context in interventions zones. (5) To reinforce War Child staff\\\'s capacity in providing psychosocial support to community volunteers and networks. (6) A regular monitoring of the activities and a final evaluation has been planned.

title: Lost Generation Initiative - [204007-146]
