title: Emergency psychosocial support and education for internally displaced children in Bangui, CAR.
description: (1) 3 CFS are established and operational in 3 IDP camps providing psychosocial support to 5000. (2) 150 children and adolescents affected by the crisis to benefit form community-based support. (3) 700 children participate in group discussions and awareness sessions to promote equality. (4) 700 members of the local CBOs are informed and trained to increase their resilience mechanisms. (5) Monitoring, reporting and referral system for cases in place and functional providing rapid response and support to victims. (6) Capacity-building of local organisations.;Three CFS were set up to provide a safe space for children in the IDP camps of Bangui. Activities included psychosocial counselling, education and vocational training.;Direct Beneficiaries: 5000 children and adolescents displaced or returned to Bangui communities in 3 CFS, 150 children affected by crisis to receive community-based case management services, 700 people to benefit from capacity-building to manage CFSs and children in emergencies. Indirect Beneficiaries: 7000 parents, community members and youth will benefit directly from awareness resources/sessions.

title: Protecting children through strengthening schools, families and communities in Bangui, CAR.
description: Supporting the enrolment and attendance of 1000 vulnerable children around 20 schools in Bangui as well as improve teaching and the environment.;(1) Quality of and access to primary/secondary education for children is improved in Bangui. (2) Children feel safer and are better protected at school, in the home, and in the community. (3) Vulnerable women have the skills to initiate profitable small businesses. (4) Two local partner CSOs have increased capacity.;(1) Quality of and access to primary/secondary education for children is improved in Bangui. (2) Children feel safer and are better protected at school, in the home, and in the community. (3) Vulnerable women have the skills to initiate profitable small businesses. (4) Two local partner CSOs have increased capacity.;Direct Beneficiaries: 1900 (very vulnerable children (6-16), women, teachers, CRC members). Frontline Workers: 370 PTA members, local partner staff, CPC members). Others: 11080 students in 20 target schools, religious and community leaders.

title: Supporting Vulnerable Young People Affected by the Crisis in CAR.
description: A hundred vulnerable youth and women for vocational training and business training. ;(1) 80 vulnerable young people (40m and 40f) in Bangui completed a vocational training and technical training course by the end of the project. (2) 100 vulnerable young people (40m and 60f) have acquired business management skills and prepared to start and run small businesses by the end of the project. (3) Local partner, FHAP, have strengthened capacity to deliver quality child protection and livelihoods interventions.;Direct Beneficiaries: 2575 children and youth in Bangui (100 selected vulnerable youth and women for vocational training and business skills training), 1475 children, youth and women from training workshops, 1000 to receive therapies. Indirect Beneficiaries: 80000 (10% of bangui population) through awareness-raising on Radio NDeke Luka.
implementing_organisations: ;Femmes Hommes Action Plus;Femmes Hommes Action Plus

title: Support and Protection of Vulnerable Girls and Young Women living and working on the streets of Tshangu District, in Kinshasa
description: The project will result in increased support and protection for the vulnerable girls and young women (VGYW) working and living on the streets of Tshangu District by generating evidence base for scaled up intervention aimed at socio-economic empowerment of adolescent girls.;* Child Protection â€“ VGYW access to medical care (night ambulance, 24h drop-in centre for girls, referral & accompaniment, psychosocial support and counselling) * VGWYâ€™s skills & basic social / human capital (life-skills courses, literacy and numeracy courses, reproductive and sexual health and family planning, re-enrolment into formal school or vocational training courses) *socioeconomic reintegration opportunities (family tracing& reintegration, financial literacy courses, development of business plans & start-up kits, M&E business activities);The project will target 1,740 vulnerable girls and young women living and working on the streets of Tshangu District. This will include 1,680 girls and women accessing services and support through the night ambulance and 60 girls (between 5 and 20 years old) using the transit centre. In addition, 728 men and boys will also benefit from the services of the night ambulance, and 12 families will receive livelihoods support to enable the sustainable reintegration of girls.;* Child Protection â€“ VGYW access to medical care (night ambulance, 24h drop-in centre for girls, referral & accompaniment, psychosocial support and counselling) * VGWYâ€™s skills & basic social / human capital (life-skills courses, literacy and numeracy courses, reproductive and sexual health and family planning, re-enrolment into formal school or vocational training courses) *socioeconomic reintegration opportunities (family tracing& reintegration, financial literacy courses, development of business plans & start-up kits, M&E business activities);The project will target 1,740 vulnerable girls and young women living and working on the streets of Tshangu District. This will include 1,680 girls and women accessing services and support through the night ambulance and 60 girls (between 5 and 20 years old) using the transit centre. In addition, 728 men and boys will also benefit from the services of the night ambulance, and 12 families will receive livelihoods support to enable the sustainable reintegration of girls.
implementing_organisations: ;Å’uvre de Suivi, Education, Protection des Enfants de la Rue (OSEPER)

title: Ending violence against children: child protection and reintegration of children in conflict with the law in Kinshasa and Goma.
description: Despite the fact that the LCP is considered as a model for its comprehensivenessm the Congolese population is barely aware of its content, and children have no one to go to when they are victims of violence. DIVAS, the ministry in charge of CP, does not have the capacities nor the resources for its implementation.;(1) With the helpline, children will be provided with advice from trained \'listeners\' (social workers, members of child parliament). State agents (DIVAS, police, CT, etc.) will have their capacities strengthened through training and provision of equipments. (2) Prevention and sensitisation activities will be undertaken through multi-media campaigns. A participative research activity will be undertaken through multimedia campaigns.

title: Educating and empowering women in Afghanistan
description: Thousands of Afghan women are denied access to education, skills training and work opportunities. The project will empower approximately 450 marginalised women and their daughters by providing literacy and business training.

title: Maternal health education for women and men in order to reduce maternal mortality ratio and achieve access to reproductive health for 2,000 women in rural Afghanistan.
description: The project will improve maternal health for over 2,000 women in a remote province of Afghanistan. Both women and men from over 100 local communities will receive Birth and Life Saving Skills (BLiSS) training, which teaches basic lessons on how to improve the health and survival of mothers and babies. By the end of the project we expect to see 27% more women accessing antenatal care and other health services, hygienic births with 15% more births attended by skilled health personnel, better postnatal practices such as breastfeeding within the first hour, and 45% more men positively engaging with maternal health issues.

title: Ghana Transition and Persistence Program (TAP)
description: The TAP program aims to help Ghana as it strives to meet â€œEducation for Allâ€ù goals on universal primary completion and address key transition point between primary and junior high schools (JHS). Plan has collaborated with GES to finalize and incorporate the School Improvement Plan (SIP) approach pioneered by Plan in Ghana into the country-wide school improvement process to ensure an effective scale up of this approach. Under the Ghana TAP program, Plan implements the SIP approach in 156 schools in 4 regions in Ghana. The SIP approach strengthens community ownership of the teaching and learning process and increases the accountability of schools to communities and District Assemblies (DAs). Through our comprehensive approach, communities will lead the school improvement process including improvements of the school physical space and eliminating barriers to school attendance. TAP aims to increase the number of students enrolled in TAP schools, increase the number of students completing JHS in TAP schools, and provide over 18,000 improved spaces in TAP schools.

title: Protecting Human Rights (PHR) - Bangladesh
description: The objective of the Protecting Human Rights project is to reduce the prevalence of domestic violence (DV), primarily focusing on the divisions of Barisal, Khulna, Rajshahi, Rangpur, Sylhet and Chittagong. The program focuses on capacity building of key Government of Bangladesh (GOB) officials on gender-based violence prevention and protection of human rights, thereby creating a resource pool of master trainers within the GOB. The program also trains key GOB front-line personnel including police, prosecutors and judges as well as religious leaders, community police and Social Protection Groups. Program activities include: ? Direct legal support to victims of DV, including services such as door step legal counseling delivered by project-trained legal counselors. ? Provision of survivor services by creating a comprehensive referral system at the upazila level. ? Provision and expansion of legal services, psychosocial counseling, shelter, medical care, and economic empowerment programs to victims of DV. ? Mass awareness and educational campaign to reduce the incidence of domestic violence, engaging not only women, but also boys and men to consider their role in addressing DV.

title: Niger Education and Community Strengthening (NECS) Program
description: The Niger Education and Community Strengthening (NECS) project represents the follow-on to the IMAGINE project. Its goal is to improve educational opportunities available to children while strengthening links of schools with community and state structures. To achieve this, the project tackles obstacles to education resulting from poverty, poor health, and gender inequities with activities that raise learning outcomes, engage the community and encourage families to keep their children in school with a special emphasis on their daughters. Its multiple and multifaceted components, such as teacher training, borehole and hand pump construction and maintenance training, adult literacy, student leadership, and proactive community engagement are carefully linked and designed to promote the projectâ€˜s overall success and long-term sustainability, as well as create a culture of reading within families and communities and produce local language materials to increase reading in primary grades.

title: Northern Uganda â€“ Health Integration to Enhance Services (NU-HITES)
description: Through USAID funding of $50 million over five years, Plan International is implementing the Northern Uganda â€“ Health Integration to Enhance Services (NU-HITES) project in fifteen (15) districts of Northern Uganda, along with consortium members Intra Health, Tulane University, Uganda Health Marketing Group (UHMG), Communications for Development Foundation Uganda (CDFU), and The AIDS Support Organization (TASO). The project will invest heavily in community-owned health services and systems, creating sustainable positive momentum that will ultimately result in improved well-being of the populations of Northern Uganda for years to come, in some of the most remote and hard-to-reach communities in the region. The projectâ€™s goal is to improve and sustain the health and nutrition status of the targeted population through a district-based integrated package of quality health services, with two main strategic objectives: Strategic Objective 1: Increase the use of people-centered integrated health services at facility and community level; Strategic Objective 2: Strengthen systems for effective and sustainable delivery of quality health services at different levels and sites of care within the health system of the region The Plan-led project team brings a wealth of expertise in essential high impact health services delivery, technical innovations, and best practices in health systems strengthening. Together with established proven approaches in community engagement and mobilization, this partnership will help to create a dynamic community-owned health system. Operationally, NU-HITES will be a regionally-based project with three sub-regional offices (Lira, Kitgum and Gulu) under the management of sub-regional coordinators. A central project office located in Gulu will house the Program Leadership Team (PLT) and the main cadre of technical advisors. The project will embed technical specialists in the disciplines of health and nutrition; community advocacy and accountability; HIV coordination; training, monitoring and evaluation; and finance. A Plan USA team in Washington D.C. will provide program management support. A team of Plan technical experts based in Africa and the U.S. will provide short-term technical assistance to NU-HITES.

title: Combating Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting (FGM/C)
description: This project aims to address the on-going problem of Female Genital Mutilation and Cutting in White Nile State, Sudan. The country has made notable progress over the last ten years, but there remains a need to engage communities in the eradication of this harmful practice. Plan International Sudan will conduct a series of trainings and awareness-raising sessions targeting community leaders and family members. These trainings will strengthen the knowledge of religious leaders, community leaders, grandparents, and health workers in the benefits of eliminating the practice of FGM/C at a local level. Communities will draw upon pre-existing social structures to engage with the wider community, building community ownership around this issue. Communities will build greater capacity in advocacy, calling on the government to take action on policy, leading to greater protection of young girls. These activities will contribute to overcoming traditional misconceptions about FGM/C and creating an environment that supports the rights of girls and children.

title: Building Child-Centered Disaster Resilient Communities in Kon Tum Province, Central Highlands, Vietnam
description: In its current phase, the project is increasing the resilience and capacities of vulnerable populations (especially children and ethnic minorities) and relevant institutions to better prepare for, mitigate the effects of, and respond to natural disasters. The current phase of the project is targeting 10 communes in 2 districts (Kon Ray and Kon Plong) of Kon Tum Province, in the Central Highlands of Vietnam. By supporting more effective participation of local communities in planning and monitoring processes, the project is facilitating improved engagement between citizens and local authorities that will support a drive for more effective and improved local governance and ensure those local communitiesâ€™ experiences and concerns are reflected in Vietnamâ€™s National CBDRM Program.

title: Sanitation and Hygiene Programme in Cambodia
description: The Cambodia Rural Sanitation and Hygiene Improvement Program (CR-SHIP), targets 5,600 villages in provinces where current sanitation coverage is below 50% to increase sustained access to improved sanitation and promote proper hygiene practices. The program will directly benefit more than 400,000 households in rural areas of Cambodia, indirectly reaching more than a million households. Its primary objectives are to promote the sustainable practices of consistent use of latrines, hand-washing with soap, and drinking only safe water in rural communities; and to develop and strengthen capacity in government, local authorities, and local NGOs in promoting improved sanitation and hygiene. To achieve the two objectives, the program will pursue four specific outcomes: 1. People achieve better hygiene outcomes through changed sanitation behaviors; 2. Capacity is created for the sustainable spread of improved sanitation and hygiene; 3. Government agencies allocate increased resources for sanitation and hygiene; and 4. Successful and innovative approaches in sanitation and hygiene are identified, evaluated and scaled up. The program utilizes and delivers its services through non-hardware subsidized approaches â€“ Community-led Total Sanitation (CLTS); School and Community WASH (SC-WASH); Sanitation Marketing; information, education, and communication (IEC) and behavior change communication (BCC) campaigns - that have been proven successful in increasing sanitation access, particularly among poor households and communities in the country. In addition to sanitation and hygiene promotion, the program will also include components on capacity building, advocacy, documentation, evaluation, and dissemination, and coordination.

title: Scaling-up Malaria Control for Impact in Cameroon/Round 9 (Malaria) - Phase I&II
description: â€œScaling up malaria control for impact 2010-2014â€ù Round 9 has 4 objectives: 1. Increase to at least 80 %, LLINs use in the general population and particularly among pregnant women and children under five by the end of 2015; 2. Raise to at least 80 % the proportion of pregnant women receiving IPT2 by the end of 2015; 3. Treat at least 80 % of malaria cases according to national guidelines by the end of 2015; 4. Reinforce the management capacity of the National Malaria Control Program by the end of 2015.
funding_organisations: ;The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

title: Community-based management for Malaria Control in Togo/Phase I and Phase II
description: The project has four specific objectives: 1/ Increase the utilization Treated Nets Long Term Action (LLINs) by the population to 80% in 2010 and 90% in 2014 through the distribution of LLINs during a national campaign, continued routine distribution and mobilization of community relays proximity to enhance the use of LLINs. 2/ Increase the protection of pregnant women IPT2 to 80% in 2010 and 90% in 2014: mobilizing community relays proximity will be used to bring pregnant women to make better use of antenatal and hence TPI. 3/ Ensure the proper management of malaria cases and 80% in 2010 and 90% in 2014 through the adaptation of the technical modules of training, the training / upgrading of health care providers, the capacity of malaria diagnosis and acquisition of antimalarial drugs. 4/ Strengthen the capacity of management, coordination and monitoring / evaluation of the program with an emphasis on strengthening management capacity and Secondary Principal Recipients, strengthening the partnership with the private sector, NGOs / Associations through contracts of service delivery and monitoring / evaluation of interventions against malaria.
funding_organisations: ;Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

title: Acceleration of access to services for the prevention of HIV infection, of care and treatment and for community support/Round 9 (HIV) - Phase I&II
description: Benin is a country with a general HIV epidemic. At the end of 2007, UNAIDS estimated HIV prevalence in adult population at 1.2 percent with a significant gender disparity of 1.5 percent among women and 0.8 among men. These estimates did not consider the appearance of new determinants which favor the propagation of infection such as sex workers and their clients, men who have sex with men (MSM) and injecting drug users (IDUs). The Program was developed based on the lessons learned from Round 2 and Round 5 of Global Fund grants and aims to ensure that objectives of the National Strategic Framework for the fight against AIDS are met by 2015. It encompasses achieving universal access to the prevention, treatment, care and support of persons infected and affected by HIV, through strengthening health and community systems. The Program consolidates Round 5 and Round 9 HIV grants and is implemented by three Principal Recipients.
funding_organisations: ;The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

title: Scaling-up Malaria Control Interventions (MEILUP-BF)/Round 8 (Malaria) - Phase I&II
description: This Program supplements the program funded under the seventh round of Global Fund funding that mainly focuses on pregnant women and children under five years by emphasizing through public health services a) the routine distribution of Long-lasting insecticide-treated nets (LLITNs), b) the confirmation of diagnosis, and c) the treatment of simple malaria cases. The Program places emphasis on universal home coverage and treatment of simple malaria cases by particularly relying on civil society and other community-based organizations. Goal: To contribute to the reduction by 50% malaria-related morbidity and mortality in Burkina Faso Target Group/Beneficiaries: â€¢ All population with universal ITNs Insecticide treated nets coverage; and â€¢ Pregnant women and children under five.
funding_organisations: ;The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

title: Testing Modified CLTS for Scalability
description: The project aims to advance global rural sanitation efforts by improving the cost-effectiveness and scalability of the CLTS approach through increased engagement of local actors. This goal will be achieved by collecting, critically evaluating, and disseminating practical lessons learned about overcoming common challenges to implementing CLTS at scale, based on applied research from pilot interventions in Kenya, Ghana, and Ethiopia that are embedded in broader knowledge generation activities. In line with the CLTS approach, the proposed project applies community-led solutions to address both demand for and supply of sanitation, to help communities eliminate open defecation and maintain and improve sanitation status over time.

title: Expanding Community Led ECCD
description: Using a community-led model of Early Childhood Care and Development (ECCD), the project aims to ensure that children aged 0-5 living in areas highly affected by HIV/AIDS achieve well-being and fulfill their potential through the following components: 1) Community-based care for children, 2) Parent and caregiver education, 3) Local stakeholder capacity building, and 4) Knowledge generation to develop best practices and share them between countries and around the region.

title: Exchanges, Ambulances & ICPD Advocacy for Maternal Health
description: The project will support Nigerian stakeholders to improve maternal health outcomes in their country by increasing knowledge of best practices, improving coordination of emergency medical transport and services, promoting mechanisms and strategies to hold their government accountable, and engagement in national and international forums to improve maternal health.
funding_organisations: ;John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation

title: Combating Ebola Outbreak in Guinea through Intensified Social Mobilization and Improved Contact Tracing
description: Plan International is implementing a 6-month project to support the ongoing effort to combat Ebola transmission in Guinea through intensified social mobilization and improved contact tracing in four Regions, covering the cities of Conakry, Nzerekore, Gueckedou, Macenta, Yomou, Kissidougou, Coyah, Forecariah, Dubreka, and Telimele. Reaching a total of over one million Guineans in ten key prefectures through increased inter-personal and media messaging and improved contact tracing, the project will support the Government of Guineaâ€™s ongoing effort to break the cycle of Ebola transmission and prevent new infections.;Ebola

title: Building Back Better in Tacloban: Post Haiyan Community Rehabilitation
description: The project will provide transitional shelter assistance to 1,289 households, whose houses were officially listed as damaged or partially damaged. In addition, the project will also rehabilitate household-level toilets, hand washing facilities, septic systems, drinking water points, and improvement of safe sources of water. Community mechanisms to address gender-based violence (GBV), disaster risk reduction (DRR) training, and child-friendly spaces and services will also be established.

title: Increasing Community Preparedness in Davao Oriental
description: In its current phase, the project is increasing the disaster preparedness and response capability of 12 vulnerable barangays in Typhoon Bopha-affected coastal municipalities of Baganga, Cateel and Boston municipalities of Davao Oriental. By focusing on enhancing the disaster risk reduction and management (DRRM) capacities of local government units (LGUs) at the barangay and municipal levels, the current project is enhancing the resilience of the target barangays through community and school-based DRRM interventions. Now on its second phase, the project is employing similar approaches and have expanded the geographic scope, impact, and achievement of the project's objectives to 16 new barangays, including a new municipality Caraga. As in the projectâ€™s first phase, the targeted barangays are still recovering from the impacts of Typhoon Bopha, remain highly vulnerable to the impacts of natural disasters (as the effects of the recent Tropical Depression â€œAgatonâ€ù demonstrated), and do not have functioning Barangay Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Councils (BDRRMC). The expansion phase will enable the project to nearly double the preparedness and response capacities among localities and their vulnerable groups, introducing these benefits to an expansion municipality (Caraga), and strengthen partnerships with local government units and community organizations in Davao Oriental.

title: Addressing Children's Basic Rights in Senegal/(ABRIS) JTIP
description: Child protection program to combat human trafficking and provide basic education to children.

title: Pregnant Womenâ€™s Groups: An integrated approach to reduce maternal and neonatal deaths in Nepal
description: The overall goal of the project is to decrease maternal, perinatal and neonatal (newborn) mortality in Nepal. The objective of the project is to improve access to and utilization of community-based maternal and child health services by disadvantaged pregnant women through Pregnant Womenâ€™s Groups. The project will form 3,300 PWGs, reaching 394,080 direct beneficiaries (mothers and newborns) and 732,600 indirect beneficiaries.

title: GPAF-IMP-072 Improving mother and child health services for 42,000 beneficiaries in three districts of Sierra Leone
description: The 'Improving mother and child health services for 42,000 beneficiaries in three districts of Sierra Leone' project aims to provide effective maternal and child health care at all health care levels in the targeted areas of Bo, Tonkolili and Bombali Districts through skilled attendance, increased community participation and ownership and improve quantity and quality of human resources for health, especially midwives. The project is located in 33 MRC supported rural government clinics and in the midwifery school in Makeni and has 42,000 direct and 733,000 indirect beneficiaries.

title: Fourniture d'un accÃ¨s durable Ã  l'eau potable et Ã  l'assainissement de base pour 139.000 personnes dans la province de Bujumbura Rural, Burundi

title: Project Start-up Workshop
description: The project start-up meeting was conducted from 9th to 12th of September 2012 at the conference hall of Summit Villas Suites, Abuja, Nigeria. This activity marked formal take-off of project implementation. The main purpose of the workshop was to provide space for deepening understanding of project amongst project staff, in terms of design, key outputs, strategies, scope and expected roles of each partner organization. A total of 24 staff of the implementing partners participated in the 4-days workshop.

description: This activity was designed with the key objective of mobilizing the target communities for acceptance and participation in the project. Target groups included: community leaders, leaders of youth groups and key gatekeepers. State Project staff organized series of meetings at the community/ward level in all the selected project states. The meetings provided space for introducing the project to the communities, as well as interaction between project staff and community.

org-name: Association for Reproductive and Family Health (ARFH)
reporting-organisation: Association for Reproductive and Family Health
title: Youth-Led Quality Assessment of Service Delivery Points
description: A participatory and inclusive assessment of health service points in project communities. 160 youth assessors in 16 LGAs across the four project states had their capacity built by project staff to lead 'Focused Group Discussions'. The young persons in turn facilitated FGDs amongst their peers at the community level. A total of 2480 females and 2480 males participated in the FGDs. The purpose of the exercise was to identify, rank and select health facilities that are youth friendly from the perspective of the young people themselves. The output of the exercise served as a basis for selecting health care providers to be trained in Youth-friendly Service Delivery.

title: Freed Kamaiyas Livelihood Development Project
description: Approximately 7.500 freed Kamaiya families have, after they left the land of their landlords, resettled in Bardiya district in the western Terai (lowlands). Typically, their major source of income consists of a small piece of land, which often is put to poor use because of low organisational capacity in the villages, no or little access to input and output markets, absent financial - and extension services, and lack of essential production facilities such as for irrigation. Moreover, the majority of freed Kamaiyaâ€™s are illiterate and possess, because of their socio-economic history, few livelihood skills and economic knowledge. In fact many freed Kamaiyaâ€™s, particularly men, see no other way to make a living in freedom than by selling their unskilled labour in away-from-home places, supporting their left-behind families through financial transmittances whenever possible. Despite good intentions these transmittances are generally too low for a family to sustain, and many heads of households, mostly women, have assumed the responsibility to make a living on their own. This action focuses on particularly the capacity of female headed freed Kamaiyaâ€™s households in Bardiya district to establish a decent standard of living for their families, particularly children. It is anticipated that an improved livelihood capacity will lead to reduced poverty in families and bring children in a better position to realise their full potential.

title: DWP Contribution to Overseas Development Assistance 2011-2014
description: This page provides details of the DWP\\\\\\\'s contribution to UK government Overseas Development Assistance between 2011-2014, through its annual payments to the International Labour Organization (ILO). The DWP was set an annual target of Â£4m spending on ODA for each year between 2011 and 2014. This target was exceeded for each year because the OECD classifies 60% of ILO spending as ODA. Therefore the ODA spend recorded here represents 60% of annual DWP payments to the ILO between 2011-2014.

org-name: Development Aid from People to People (DAPP) Malawi
reporting-organisation: Development Aid from People to People
title: Women Empowerment via Farmers Club
description: Chikhwawa district is one of the poorest districts in Malawi (76% of its population living below a dollar a day). The district recieves less rainfall but also is prone to floods during the rainy season hence the area is characterized among others by food insecurity, environmental degradation, and low household income. Women in the district are often marginalized in social and economic spheres despite that they play a key role in securing food and are in general the backbone of socio-economic activities. The project is addressing challenges of food insecurity, high illiteracy rates, environmental degradation, low household income levels to reduce vulnerability of people. For example Mrs Donata Jenifa Light of Mtondo club in Mwasiya II Village from Traditional Authority Maseya in Chikhwawa District said the project has brought viable solutions to their socio-economic problems .' 'We were experiencing a lot of problems before the project including poor harvest, but now we have learnt conservation farming which has improved the crop production. We have learnt conservation agriculture, construction of firewood stoves, group management and dynamics and business management.' The training has also improved the self-esteem among the women farmers who have acquired knowledge in how to increase their production and income. ;This project is fundamentally about capacity building and empowerment. The project is building capacity of women farmers which is contributing to the achievement of purpose and outputs in the following ways: 1) The women groups will be trained in improved agriculture techniques. This will be conducted by the Farming Instructors through out the project period. The Farming Instructors have all been part of similar program and are well trained in the subject matter. The training will both give the women farmers solid back ground knowledge and hands on training in the demonstration gardens . Included in the training will be courses in basic business management. Each beneficiary will be encouraged to start a small business to supplement family income. 2) The women farmers will also be trained in what it means to be food secured and the concept of a balanced diet. 3) The capacity to work together as a group to achieve one goal will also be built among the target beneficiaries via organizational structure, In the 2nd project year min 2 cooperatives will be established and run by the women farmers them selves. Around 50% of the women farmers will be in each. In each cooperative processing plants for soy beans, ground nuts and pulses, vegetables and fruits will be established to increase the value for crops they will be growing. 4) The women farmers will be in installing sealed rope and washer pumps to increase access to drinking water and water for irrigation. The women farmers will also be trained in irrigation and they will establish each an irrigated garden for vegetable production not depending on the rains. This production will both increase the cash income and the nutrition level of the household .5) the participating women farmers will furthermore advocate for the applicability of other project activities to other members who are their neighbours. For example the use of potholing method for planting maize which is more essential in areas with low rainfall which will advocated for in the target area. Campaigns on healing the environment will be introduced in the entire community and programs will be ongoing to ensure that everyone take part and contribute. ;The project main target are 5250 women in Chikhwawa district, Malawi. The project is promoting equity and empowerment because they underpin poverty reduction and are also important in creating enabling environments for poverty reduction among female farmers to increase their access to opportunities for sustainable livelihood. The project has established women farmers clubs through which necessary skills are being imparted to women in leadership and agriculture production to empower them to take leading role in their households as well as community level. There also interaction activities between direct and indirect beneficiaries so that community members should visualize the potentials of women in leading development at household level which has enabled community members to appreciate the need to involve women in various activities at household and community level in order to improve their livelihoods. Women are also participating in agriculture marketing and income generation activities to foster pro-poor growth because economic empowerment of women is critical in empowerment of marginalized groups in the district as women are often denied opportunities due to social and cultural norms. The project also continued providing production resources to women to increase productivity and profitability of farm business.
sector-text: The project is implementing capacity building project in agriculture through this project

org-name: Development Aid from People to People (DAPP) Malawi
reporting-organisation: Development Aid from People to People
title: Women Empowerment Via Farmers Club Project
description: The project focuses on fostering a long term and sustainable impact to the community reducing extreme poverty. The impact of the project will be to see a community which is food secured and which is capable to creating wealth through empowering women to take leading roles in the fight against poverty and hunger. This will be through intensive training leading to: increased food production for own consumption as well for sales increased engagement in animal husbandry, increased level of literacy, of capacity to plan and budget for the agriculture production and the family economy, improved health and greater gender equality at household level and in the wider community.;Overall the fundamental approach of the project is to train and equip the participating farmers to be able to carry on and further what they have achieved during the project period within the framework of the structures & organisation of the Clubs, cooperatives and associations - as well as the government structures of extension services. The project fosters: 1) sustainable empowerment of women which remains with each individual and enable each individual and the Clubs to excel and develop further - which after completion of the project will be hand in hand with existing structures. 2) Institutional sustainability by organizing the women farmers and creating ownership of these structures amongst the farmers them selves. 3) Financial sustainability: The farmers will learn how to multiply seeds and cuttings and how to make natural fertilizers to ensure that they have access to these inputs from their own resources. The farmers will learn planning and budgeting to cater for their ongoing production. A part of the Exit Strategy will be that beneficiaries under supervision of Farming Instructors will find their own inputs for the last growing season in the project. The exposure of the results achieved using this program model via field visits by current and potential donors, via the public statements from MoAFS on the its potential attention is drawn to this program which will result in funding towards upscale in the areas of most need. ;The primary target groups is 5250 women farmers. Women were selected as a group because of the disproportionate impact that poverty has on women in all its forms, whether social, political, physical or economic. Women work longer hours, earn less, receive less education, are subject to high levels of domestic violence, are more at risk from HIV and have limited access to resources and decision making. They face discrimination in inheritance and divorce settlements â€“ a cause of increased vulnerability of women headed households. In terms of employment men have the advantage to go anywhere and work while women are predesigned by culture that they are to remain at home and take care of children. To achieving MDG 3 requires a change for women. Gender disparities among in the target communities is still rampant The Sena tribe always put a man first in everything and it is one of the culture barriers which we seek to address in this project. From the Chikhwawa Social economic profile other examples supports this: In 2007 twice as many men applied fertilizer than women apparently due to easier access to markets and centers of distribution.* and subsequently got a better yield. From the same source 3 to 4 times as many males hold paid work as compared to women. The project will both empower the women farmers via the program as well as include men in the process for them both to appreciate and respect the potential of the women and for both parties work together towards the needed changes in traditions and behaviors leading to the gender inequalities.
implementing_organisations: ;Development Aid from People to People (DAPP) Malawi

title: Aspire Rutunga: Increasing income and food security through education and vocational training for 450 women and their families living in extreme poverty in rural Rwanda
description: Our three year programme trains 450 poor, rural women to increase their income through improved farming techniques, becoming self-sufficient. A sustainable cooperative will support the empowerment of women and girls through education, by sensitising men about womenâ€™s rights, by providing child care, and access to water and fuel-efficient stoves.
sector-text: agricultural education and training

title: Improving access to maternal and infant health care and education, through increased community services, support and education, for the reduction of infant and maternal mortality in Haiti
description: This initiative will improve access to maternal and neonatal health care for the most marginalised pregnant women and newborns in targeted areas in Cap-Haitien and Quartier Morin, North Haiti. This will be achieved by improving access to trained community health actors and emergency obstetric / neonatal care, and increasing community capacity to address maternal / neonatal health needs.

title: Kenya Equity in Education Project (KEEP)
description: The Kenya Equity in Education Project aims to improve the life chances of marginalized girls and boys in northern Kenya by improving the access and quality of education in four target communities in and around Dadaab and Kakuma.
implementing_organisations: ;Windle Trust Kenya;World University Service of Canada

title: mMitra Arogya Sakhis: Mobile phone enabled improved maternal and child health information access (voice messages and animations) and home based care for 2000 poor pregnant women and infants in India.
description: mMitra is a mobile phone voice messaging and animation service to improve MCH information access in rural India. One phone will be entrusted with Arogya Sakhis (health friends) who will ensure access to the animations for all women and the messages for the women without phones. They will also provide home-based after work-hours care and investigations for a nominal fee and serve as the maternal and child health advocates of the village, thus empowering themselves and reducing maternal and child mortality
sector-text: Maternal and neonatal health and women as health entreprenuers

title: Malaria Khanh Phu Research
description: The aim of this project is to further the understanding of the epidemiology of forest malaria and how to prevent it, with the ultimate aim to develop new methods that could lead to the elimination of malaria in Vietnam.
implementing_organisations: ;District Health Center of Khanh Vinh (preventive medicine group);Khanh Phu Malaria Research Unit ;Research Institute of Humanity and Nature, Kyoto University

title: Disability Program
description: To ensure that people with disabilities receive comprehensive support to develop their potential and to create an enabling environment for their inclusion in the community.
accountable_organisations: ;Provincial Health Department of Cao Bang Province;Provincial Health Department of Dien Bien Province;Women Union of Cao Bang Province;Women Union of Dak Lak Province;Department of Education Cao Bang Province;Department of Education Phu Yen Province
implementing_organisations: ;Rehabilitation Hospital of Phu Yen;Rehabilitation Hospital of Phu Yen

title: Human Resources for Health
description: To aim of this project is to improve the quality of training of health professionals in order to provide better health care, through better training methods and materials and increased relevance of the training to the needs of society, filling gaps in the existing curricula at medical and public health universities and at provincial secondary medrical schools and colleges.
implementing_organisations: ;Global Initiative on Psychiatry;WorldGranny;Medical School of Quang Tri;Medical School of Cao Bang

title: Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights
description: The aim of this project is to protect the rights and promote the sexual and reproductive health of all including those who are underserved or marginalised, such as ethnic minorities, sexual minorities, the disabled, and the young and the old, partly by providing access to up-to-date information and services.

title: Improving Maternal Health in the 6 states of India
description: The project is about improving maternal health. The Government of India, inspite of having elaborate maternal and nutritional delivery mechanisms & structure in place, like the National Health Mission, ICDS and PDS; the maternal mortality and malnutrition rate, especially amongst marginalized community, is still very high. Both social structural system and poor delivery mechanisms play a contributory role to this abysmal situation. Hence the project seeks to bring change in the lives of the people by advocating for transformation in the social structural system and maternal health & public food delivery mechanism, in 420 villages of 18 districts spread over the six poorest states of India. It is expected that 1,86,000 women/pregnant women will be directly benefitted from this program through a multipronged approach (1) by increasing awareness and capacity of the community to demand for quality & affordable maternal health services and entitlements related to nutrition like ICDS,PDS etc.(2) empowering community to participate actively in planning and distribution of resources at village level; ensuring that there are mechanisms in place to promote greater transperency and accountability (3) working with communities closely to ensure that traditional practices and age old belief that contribute to maternal death and malnutrition are eliminated.
sector-text: The project seeks to bring change in the lives of the people by advocating for transformation in the social structural system and maternal health & public food delivery mechanism, in 420 villages of 18 districts spread over the six poorest states of India. It is expected that 1,86,000 women/pregnant women will be directly benefited from this project.

title: 'Enabling access to improved mother and child health services for 101,632 women and newborn children in two districts of Tanzaniaâ€ù
description: Expected Outcome: Increased access to quality obstetric and neonatal health service in the districts, particularly among the most vulnerable groups (HIV positive, hard to reach and poorest pregnant women). Related indicators are: - Intrapartum and very early neonatal death rate at Emonc facilities - Percentage of births assisted by a skilled attendant - Percentage of HIV infected pregnant women who receive antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of MTCT Expected Outputs: - Iringa District Council Designated Hospital carries out quality and comprehensive emergency and obstetric and neonatal care with service available daily on a 24 hours basis - Six health centers in Iringa District and two in Mufindi District are upgraded to offerbasic Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care - Improved availability of quality health services for HIV positive mothers and exposed newborns at Iringa DC hospital and eight health centers into two districts - A functional emergency referral system 24 hours a day, seven days a week is available within involved districts referring patients to Iringa DC Hospital - Forty rural villages in Iringa District and twenty in Mufindi District are reache dby the network of Community Health Workers for community mobilization, awareness creation and behavioral change promotion - Equity in access to emergency obstetric and newborn care in Iringa DC and Mufindi is improved to through reduction of barries to access Direct Beneficiaries: - Women in childberaring age (65640 in Iringa DC and 35992 in two divisions of Mufindi District) and particularly women with complicated deliveries (1300 in IDC and 700 in Mufindi) - Newborns 8564 in IDC and 4760 in Mufindi District with special attentio to complicated deliveries - Health staff trained and re-trained (82) - Community Health Workers (102) and CHWs Supervisors (18) - Number of women groups (20) Indirect Beneficiaries: - The total population of Iringa DC and 2 divisions of Mufindi District (272707 and 128000 respectively). Subgropus: Households of involved villages (25000) - Staff of the Hcs involved (180 in Iringa, 60 in Mufindi District) - District Health Authorities: Council Health Management Team members (40), RHC members (10)
sector-text: MCH - Local Health System Strengthening â€“ Public Health â€“ Community Health

title: Improved school attendance and learning of vulnerable Kenyan girls through an integrated intervention
description: 1.To empower communities to encourage girls to attend and stay in school 2.To strengthen schools (teaching environment, management and policies) 3.To improve physical infrastructure of schools 4. To encourage schools to implement Ministry of Education existing pro-girl policies to keep girls in school 5.To ensure girls receive positive portrayal of women in schools to ensure girls stay in school and learn in addition to rolling out a comprehensive school health program

title: Improving access to HIV prevention and support services for 243,949 women and children in five countries of East and Southern Africa
description: By employing, training, and empowering mothers and pregnant women living with HIV, mothers2mothers will partner with national governments to improve access to and uptake of HIV prevention and support services for women and children and their families to prevent vertical HIV transmission and keep mothers and children alive in Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, South Africa and Uganda

title: Department of Health Overseas Development Assistance spend - World Health Organisation UK annual assessed contribution 2013 - 2015
description: Department of Health Overseas Development Assistance spend - World Health Organisation UK annual assessed contribution 2013 - 2015

title: Including the poorest: a new approach to honey trade development in Mozambique
description: This project will enable at least 500 of the poorest most vulnerable women, including female-headed households, in Manica Province, Mozambique, to participate in commercial beekeeping and earn significant new income and develop skills, knowledge and confidence to sustain their livelihood. The project will educate the public in Manica Province on the benefits of honey as a valuable nutritional supplement and will mobilize unemployed youth to help promote and sell honey in rural areas.

title: Youth Bank Chimoio: enabling 2,500 young women and men to improve their livelihoods and pioneering a new movement for social and economic entrepreneurship in Mozambique
description: This project takes the Youth Bank methodology first developed in Northern Ireland and adapts it to Mozambique. In various countries of the world YouthBank organizations have succeeded in mobilizing young people from different backgrounds and forging collaboration and joint action, usually involving local grantmaking. Youth Bank Chimoio (YBC) is the first attempt to launch a youth-led grant making programme in Mozambique. YBC is run by young people, for young people. The grants component will stimulate social and economic entrepreneurship and local resource mobilisation (volunteering and financial) that could be a basis for establishing a form of community foundation. The project aims to enable more than 2,500 young men and women to plot their own paths out of poverty and through the project we will establish a model that in principle can be widely replicated in Mozambique.

title: Empowering 2000 women and men to fight poverty through impartial advice at citizens' advice centres.
description: Citizen's advice centres will provide free, impartial, confidential advice on a wide range of issues and services identified by vulnerable groups as impacting poverty in Kabul and Baghlan province. 2000 people will receive advice that has a direct and measurable impact on their livelihoods (eg access to a benefit or service they were unaware of)
sector-text: Promoting citizens' rights in Afghanistan

title: Contributing to consolidation of the rule of law in the DRC by combating mass illegal pre-trial detentions
description: A punitive measure permitted by legislation throughout the world, recourse to pre-trial detention (PD) within the framework of a criminal investigation is not in itself a questionable practice, provided that PD remains a judicial course of action which is used exceptionally and with respect for the conditions imposed by the law, as required in a state governed by the rule of law. However in the DRC, the vast majority of those accused are placed in pre-trial detention, they do not regularly appear before a judge, and they do not have access to a lawyer. Moreover, their humanitarian situation while in prison is appalling, principally as a result of extreme prison overcrowding and the almost total absence of any commitment on the part of the Congolese government to providing basic services (food and sanitation). Very often, prison conditions constitute â€œinhumane and degrading treatmentâ€ù. The overcrowding in Congolese prisons is, in large part, due to the high number of illegal pre-trial detentions. ASFâ€™s experience of the Congolese justice system over more than 10 years confirms that there is a correlation between the massive scale of illegal pre-trial detentions and the absence of systematic, quality legal aid. The issue, therefore, is to offer a lasting, structural response to the issue of mass illegal pretrial detentions, which is symbolic of all the problems of the Congolese justice system. This response would be introduced alongside existing programmes supporting justice reform in the DRC. ASFâ€™s intervention strategy involves firstly implementing a human rights approach based on the principle of the interdependence of human rights as a precondition of their effectiveness. To reinforce the classic approach of arranging quality legal aid for the highest number of pretrial detainees (right to a fair trial, access to a judge), this pilot project, for the first time in the DRC, allows the principle of the interdependence of human rights to be put into action by incorporating violations of detaineesâ€™ economic and social rights and a new aspect â€“ access to justice as a factor in reducing poverty â€“ to be promoted. In fact, the social and economic impact of depriving individuals of their liberty is often underestimated. The detainees and their families often live in extreme poverty and thus for them, access to a quality justice system is not a priority. This is a vicious circle, reinforcing the dynamics of impoverishment. Access to justice therefore becomes even more difficult. And the situation is clearly even worse in cases where the detention is illegal. Therefore, it is imperative that the individual and also the collective consequences of PD are taken into account, not only by political decision makers, but also by all of those responsible for individual legal proceedings (lawyers and magistrates). ASFâ€™s project aims to raise awareness, provide information and take action alongside numerous local, national and international players from the legal and university sectors, as well as the anti-poverty sector, to highlight the consequences, both individual and collective, of pre-trial detention and to develop effective long- and short-term strategies to reduce its most harmful effects. In order to make a contribution to strengthening the rule of law in the DRC through combating mass illegal pre-trial detentions, ASFâ€™s intervention strategy involves guaranteeing access to systematic and quality justice for vulnerable individuals held in pre-trial detention in the three provinces covered by the project (Kinshasa, Equateur and Bas Congo), as well as developing a national strategy coordinated by the National Order of Lawyers of the DRC (ONARDC). The aim is to achieve the following results: - Result 1: Pre-trial detainees are made aware and informed of their right to a fair trial and their right to food, and of the mechanisms of recourse available to obtain them. - Result 2: Pre-trial detainees benefit in the long term from quality, systematic and ongoing legal aid. - Result 3: Those involved in providing access to justice are aware of detaineesâ€™ right to food and the corollary between A2J and poverty reduction In order to achieve these results, a series of initiatives will be implemented: - awareness raising and information for detainees, an essential step in the change process so that detainees can decide to take legal action to contest the legality of their situation - awareness raising and information for those working in the justice sector (magistrates, lawyers, civil society, the Ministry), the university sector and the development sector on the individual and collective consequences of PD and on the â€˜legalâ€™ actions which can be taken to reduce the most harmful effects - providing quality legal assistance to hundreds of pre-trial detainees, with priority given to women and minors - building the internal capacity of the ONARDC and the four relevant bar associations (Kinshasa Gombe; Kinshasa Matete; Matadi; Mbandaka) to put in place and manage a systematic and quality legal aid service for pre-trial detainees, notably through the establishment of a Pre-Trial Detention National Commission for Legal Assistance - improving the technical skills of lawyers to take responsibility for this legal aid, through training, coaching sessions and the publication of teaching materials - strategic litigation to support â€˜high value addedâ€™ judicial proceedings, establishing through the legal process the responsibility of the Congolese state with respect to international law on human rights and the rights of detainees. Expected Impact This two-year project paves the way for a multi-year strategy aimed at gradual disengagement from the provision of direct services in favour of the local bar associations, acting under the aegis of the National Order of Lawyers of DRC (ONARDC) and recognition of this organisation, at a national level, as the primary interlocutor with the state in the legal aid sector benefitting, firstly, those who have been deprived of their liberty. At a local level, the project will help lawyers to specialise and give responsibility to the authorities of each bar association for putting in place lasting local mechanisms for providing legal aid to detainees. In addition, the project will mobilise new players â€“ the University of Kinshasa and some of its law students â€“ to set up a legal clinic in the capitalâ€™s prison. This work has a long-term aspect to the extent that these students are aspiring to commence their professional lives in the â€˜legal services marketâ€™ and, in the near future, to get involved in developing national policies, in other words in the administration of justice within their country. Thus, they will receive training on the issue of access to justice for the most vulnerable and on the tools which can be used to protect the rights of individuals, which they will then be able to continue to promote and implement.;The direct beneficiaries of the project are the pre-trial detainees incarcerated in the three prisons in the project areas (Kinshasa, Matadi and Mbandaka) and also, given the synergies between programmes at a national level, prisons in the East, where ASF is implementing a similar approach as part of the Uhaki Safi project. The indirect beneficiaries of the project are, firstly, lawyers: the National Order of Lawyers of the DRC (ONARDC) and their respective bar associations (Matete and Gombe of Kinshasa; Matete and Mbandaka). For the first time as part of this type of approach, the project will also involve students from the University of Kinshasa who will be trained and supervised to run legal clinics at Makala prison. Finally, the Congolese population as a whole will benefit from the impact of a project which will contribute to establishing the rule of law in the DRC as part of an approach where access to fair, quality justice can also make a significant contribution to fighting poverty.;General objective: to contribute to consolidating the rule of law in the DRC through combating mass illegal pre-trial detentions. Specific objective: to guarantee access to systematic, quality justice for vulnerable individuals held in pre-trial detention in the project areas
funding_organisations: ;Belgian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Development Cooperation
implementing_organisations: ;Avocats Sans FrontiÃ¨res;National Order of Lawyers of the DRC (ONARDC);Barreau de La Gombe (Kinshasa);Barreau de Matete (Kinshasa);Barreau de Mbandaka;Barreau du Bas-Congo

title: Legal and judicial assistance for asylum seekers
description: Since the nineteen sixties Burundi has been confronted to important migration flows linked to constant instability in the Great Lakes region. At the end of last June, there were 6,397 asylum seekers and 44,034 refugees in the country. Although the capacity of the authorities to protect these populations remains limited, the protective environment itself is rather favourable to such protection. First of all, the legislative framework guarantees a process of admission observing certain security conditions, the prohibition of forcible returns and that the norms regulating their treatment are respectful of the rights of refugees. Burundi has ratified the instruments that are central to the regime of international protection of refugees: the Geneva Convention 1951 and its Additional Protocol from 1967, as well as the OAU Convention regulating aspects that are specific to the problems of refugees in Africa and which the asylum seekers can rely on to claim a wider definition of International Protection. As an exceptional regional measure, the protection instruments have been integrated into national legislation. The Burundian judicial arsenal has established the principle of non-refoulement and guarantees the application of the rights to work and education, and access to identity documents. The law establishes ONPRA (National Office for the Protection of Refugees and Stateless Persons) as the current body to manage asylum, to elaborate new plans of action, to liaise with the HCR, the border police and provincial authorities and to coordinate the aid and protection interventions in the camps. Finally it guarantees the right to legal counsel for asylum seekers during the refugee status determination procedure and organises legal representation in case of refusal at first instance. Despite this legal arsenal, asylum seekers have limited access to asylum procedures, due to the unavailability of free assistance services and a lack of knowledge of the law and procedures. Confronted to linguistic, bureaucratic and procedural barriers they do not benefit of any support in obtaining individual documents and civil status documents, which are precisely required to prove their nationality and access the personal status of refugee. Some are denied the status at first instance because of a lack of legal support. In the absence of available or adequate legal representation, their requests for appeal fail before the appeals committee. Also the insufficient protection and lack of legal assistance for refugees shows that obtaining the refugee status does not automatically allow for the enjoyment of the rights guaranteed by the Geneva Convention or national legislation. Active in Burundi since 1999, ASF is implementing since January 2012 a project of international protection of the rights of asylum seekers and refugees (PIDDAR), with the objective of Â« reinforcing the measures of protection and assistance for refugees and asylum seekers and to promote asylum and the international protection of refugees in Burundi Â». The intervention strategy focuses on the respect of equitable procedures for the determination of the refugee status but also on improving legal aid and advice for refugees and asylum seekers, as well as individuals amongst that group who are victims of sexual violence. The project comes to support the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (HCR) and the National Office for the Protection of Refugees and Stateless Persons (ONPRA), a technical structure set up by the Burundian Minister of State to determine the refugee status. Activities: 1. Reception, guidance and legal assistance - The PIDDAR project provides legal advice for asylum seekers throughout all phases of the procedure. The advice is given in any area related to asylum law, procedure and refugees rights. The centres will provide various services such as greeting, informing and guiding asylum seekers or refugees confronted to problems of law (violations of the right to health, etc.). Questions that do not concern the areas of intervention mentioned above are referred to the available services (IRC, HI, etc.) - The legal services of the project will greet refugees and asylum seekers who need legal assistance for any question related to the asylum procedure, protection documents, civil status documents, etc. The project systematically assists asylum seekers whose demands have been dismissed in the first instance and provides for their legal representation before the appeals committee. 2. Judicial assistance Judicial assistance is offered to vulnerable individuals in areas of gross violation of fundamental rights, sexual violence, illegal pre-trial detention, incarceration of women and minors and torture. 3. Actions of reinforcement of local competences. The PIDDAR project looks to emancipate both the rights holders by promoting their access to simplified legal information and their aptitude to claim them, and the people carrying obligations and providing services by reinforcing their knowledge of their responsibilities and their capacities to honour them by respecting, promoting and simplifying the efficient exercise of the rights of asylum seekers and refugees. 4. Raising awareness and pleading Awareness will be raised amongst refugees and asylum seekers as to the rights and obligations of refugees. The procedures and the process undergone by the asylum applications from the moment they are submitted up to the definitive decision of recognition of the status or rejection of the application for asylum, will be supported during those sessions, in a participatory manner.;Through the PIDDAR project ASF wishes to contribute to the reinforcement of the international protection of refugees. The purpose is specifically to support the HCRâ€™s efforts in promoting procedures of equitable protection and protection against violence and exploitation by improving the legal security of asylum seekers and refugees in Burundi. Expected impact: - Result nÂ°1: A group of specialised lawyers is available and capable of providing legal and judicial services adapted to the beneficiaries; - Result nÂ°2: Asylum seekers and refugees in Burundi benefit from greeting, guidance, legal advice and free legal assistance; - Result nÂ°3: Law, asylum procedures and the rights of refugees are known, respected and disseminated by local authorities, police authorities and by the civil society; - Result nÂ°4: Good practice and the lessons learnt in the area of the execution of asylum procedure are identified and communicated to be capitalised by Burundese asylum authorities.;1. The final beneficiaries consist of: - Refugees present in the Burundian territory in a camp or in urban environments who encounter a problem of a legal and/or judicial nature - Asylum seekers, i.e. people asking Burundese authorities for international protection At least 1800 asylum seekers and refugees will benefit from a consultation before the end of the project (600 per year). At least 1,500 asylum seekers whose demands will have been rejected at first instance will benefit from legal assistance and representation before the appeals committee. At least 250 refugees and asylum seekers will benefit from legal aid by a competent lawyer. Awareness will be raised amongst at least 3,400 asylum seekers and refugees as to the rights and obligations of refugees and the legal undertaking of sexual assaults. Representatives from refugees and asylum seekers committees will be trained on the rights of refugees and the asylum procedure. 2. National asylum authorities: the National Office for the Protection of Refugees and Stateless Persons (ONPRA) and the Police of Air, Frontiers, and Foreigners (PAFE) will benefit from reinforcements of their competence in asylum rights. 3. Civil society organisations operating in the refugee and asylum seeker sector will also benefit from reinforcements of their competence in asylum rights and the international protection of refugees. 4. Project lawyers will benefit from regular training and coaching through the presence of an international coach and expert in asylum law.
