title: Improving the livelihoods of people in five districts of southern Ethiopia by increasing access to primary eye care, spectacles and treatment for eye diseases.
description: Local health workers will be trained in eye care. Eye care services will be provided in five districts in southern Ethiopia. Remote and poor regions will be specifically targeted.

title: Improved Food Security for women, men and children in Makueni County, Kenya, through increased access to water and food production
description: This project will improve food security for people in Makueni County, Kenya through increased access to water and food production. With community SHGs who have identified their own priorities driving change, this project will enable men, women and children from rural farming HHs to reduce time and distance to collect water, improve food production and improve health and nutrition. 22,000 members of the wider community will also benefit from improved water access.
sector-text: Improved access to water;Increased food production and environmental sustainability

title: Creating alternative income opportunities from natural species and high value crops for smallholder households in Zimbabwe
description: The project aims at commercializing indigenous species such as baobab or marula fruit as well as herbs, spices and herbal teas as a means to increase household incomes of 4,000 smallholder farmers in dryland areas in Zimbabwe. Activities include research on the under-utilized species, product and market development both locally and internationally, training the farmers and ensuring knowledge dissemination, as well as achieving fair trade and other organic certification.; 4,000 wild collectors and/or smallholder farmers in NR 4/5 with a focus on women (up to 80%), must be labour endowed + economically active poor
sector-text: Rural Developement, Agriculture;

title: Street Child Protection Network Sierra Leone
description: Creating a street child protection network in 5 towns in Sierra Leone to protect the rights of 3200 street children, including increasing access to education and strengthening family relationships.

title: Sustainable Schools in Tambakha
description: Safeguarding 4,000 children in primary education in remote communities in Tambakha Chiefdom in the Bombali district of Sierra Leone. Improving net enrolment and completion rates through sustainability initiatives, including training 100 teachers.

title: Every Child in School
description: Increasing access to quality primary education in Sierra Leone and Liberia.

title: Wasichana Wote Wasome - (Let All Girls Learn)
Wasichana Wote Wasome
description: WasichanaWoteWasome (WWW â€“ â€˜Let All Girls Learnâ€™) is a project funded by DfID (UK)aiming to improve school enrolment, retention, attendance and learning outcomes for 81,000 marginalised girls in Kenya. The project will work in 500 primary schools and the communities they serve in two contexts: Arid and Semi Arid Lands (ASALs) and urban slums.

title: Silk weaving
Rain fed agriculture â€“ phase two: improve and increase grain
description: â€¢ Build capacities in the field of grain production, market control, determine a policy to encourage the expansion in rain fed fields areas and enhance grain storage capacities â€¢ Improve the economic and social conditions of farmers through increasing the production of cereals and improving productivity to improve their livelihoods â€¢ Reduce the severity of poverty through improving the productivity of farmers
sector-text: Agriculture and Irrigation

title: Building the IATI transparancy portal for UN-Habitat phase I.
description: UN-Habitat expects to deliver their first internal XML within the next two weeks. From there on we can kick-start the project, which is aimed towards integrating the IATI XML provided by UN-HABITAT into a web-interface. The data that will be used for the website will be stored and called upon using the OIPA storage and API. This will be done using REST calls which produce JSON as output. Working together with a local company in Nairobi Verviant who will provide the interface. Verviant has developed the necessary and HTML5 and CSS mockups. The project has been powered the OIPA network, which contains the IATI compliant data and search. The content management system will be powered by Wordpress. This will be hosted by the OIPA network.

title: Building a web-prototype openaidNL: platform for IATI transparency.
description: Building an opensource framework that provides a rich and usable API for parsing, ingesting, storing and searching IATI standard compliant datasets. Providing a webinterface for the IATI activities published by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign affairs. The interface connects to the open-source framework OIPA. ;OIPA is a framework that provides a rich and usable API for parsing, ingesting, storing and searching IATI standard compliant datasets. OIPA stands for: Open IATI Parser and API. It picks up any IATI file from the IATI registry using a Django (Python) driven back-end. Once the IATI files have been collected by the system and normalised into the MySQL database, the API is used to making calls. Currently OIPA uses Wordpress as a frontend, which is fully detached from the back-end. It picks up relevant resources and provides a rich set of filters to which the end-users can manipulate and aggregate data.;Decisionmakers, NGO's, academia, media, civil society.
sector-text: ICT

title: WASHCost Calculator prototype
description: The WASHCost Calculator prototype was developed to prepare for sustainable, long-lasting water and sanitation services.

title: Creative Learning Centres for girls aged 7-18 in Greater Kampala, Uganda
description: The aim is to re-integrate vulnerable girls into upper primary and lower secondary school by offering non-formal education through a wide range of subjects. More than 1,900 girls being educated in the centres will graduate after one or two terms and then return to some form of appropriate education. A further 2,300 girls will be impacted through teacher training and family mentoring, and the project will also establish educational working groups to share good practice. - See more at: http://blog.viva.org/index.php/2014/01/09/dream-be-teacher/#sthash.UwatctjE.dpuf

title: Entreprenariat Rural Agricole
description: To promote the Family Farm Advisory Service (FFAS). FFAS is an approach to help farmers to manage strategically and financially their farm. Working with farmer-based organisations in Burkina Faso to design and implement a FFAS service that bring value to farmers while developing organisational systems and processes for the organisation overall. Developing several workshops, tools and a design process that allow our partners to develop a performing FFAS system.

title: Food Assistance and Education Incentive for Afghan and Iraqi Refugees in the Islamic Republic of Iran
description: Afghan and Iraqi refugees living in settlements have no access to land for farming or to keep livestock and are therefore dependent on market purchases and WFP assistance. There are limited job opportunities for refugees within and around the settlements as formal sector employment is not permitted.

title: Promotion of Sustainable School Feeding
description: Launched in July 2010,WFP's school feeding project was designed to build on the achievements of the previous education development project and to support the Government of Benin in its policy of achieving universal primary education by 2015. The main objectives of this project are to increase access to education and human capital development,enhance capacities to sustain a national school feeding programme and stimulate agricultural and economic development by linking school feeding with local production. The programme aimed to increase enrolment and attendance rates and to reduce the dropout rates in the schools in the targeted districts,as well as improve the girl to boy ratio. The project has been extended for one year until 30 June 2014. Aligned with WFP Strategic Objectives 4 and 5 'to reduce chronic hunger and under nutrition' and 'to strengthen the capacities of countries to reduce hunger',including through hand-over strategies and local purchase,this project aimed to complement the government school feeding activities overseen by the Directorate of School Feeding (DSF) within the Ministry of Education,a body effectively put in place in 2013. The government's programme operated in schools where WFP was not providing food. However,the government indicated it needed additional time to further build on its institutional and policy capacity towards a nationally-owned school feeding programme. WFP's continued assistance was recommended to improve educational performance and enable the government to consolidate its capacity for managing an expanded programme.

title: Strengthening the participation of Somali Non-State Actors in decision-making on peace, security and development (Phase 3)
description: The overall objective of the action is â€œto contribute to deepening peace, improving security and establishing democratic governance through the effective participation of Non-State Actors in peace-building and state-building.â€ù The specific objective of the action is that â€œthe Non-State Actor Platformsâ€™ contribution to policy making in Somalia and Somaliland is relevant and representative of the views of their members.â€ù The action has two planned outputs (expected results): 1. The NSA Platforms have responsible and effective governance that enables them to be relevant and responsive to views and needs of their members 2. Saferworld and the NSA Platforms influence policy change at the local, national and international levels

title: Programme Partnership Agreement Extension
description: This proposal covers the Horn and Great Lakes regions of Africa (regionally and in Kenya, Somalia/Somaliland, Sudan and Uganda); South Asia (regionally and in Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka); Central Asia (Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan); the Caucasus (regionally and in Georgia/South Ossetia/Abkhazia); Balkans (regionally and in Bosnia, Kosovo and Moldova); and the Middle East (Yemen). Saferworld proposes four specific objectives for the PPA, derived from the four categories of outcomes contained within our results framework .

Conflict Prevention Partnerships for the 21st Century: China and the UK
Preventing and reducing violent conflict and promoting cooperative approaches to security building
description: General support to Saferworld's work to prevent and reduce violent conflict and promote cooperative approaches to Security Building.

title: Advisory Consortium on Conflict Sensitivity
description: Saferworld is a member of the Advisory Consortium on Conflict Sensitivity, a consortium supported by the UK Department for International Development to ensure that development interventions in northern Uganda effectively address the drivers of conflict and contribute to building peace. Our role in the consortium is to deliver evidence-based advocacy and provide conflict sensitivity advice and training to stakeholders involved in development initiatives in northern Uganda.

title: Programmatic Partnership Agreement
description: This proposal covers the Horn and Great Lakes regions of Africa (regionally and in Kenya, Somalia/Somaliland, Sudan and Uganda); South Asia (regionally and in Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka); Central Asia (Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan); the Caucasus (regionally and in Georgia/South Ossetia/Abkhazia); Balkans (regionally and in Bosnia, Kosovo and Moldova); and the Middle East (Yemen). Saferworld proposes four specific objectives for the PPA, derived from the four categories of outcomes contained within our results framework .

title: Enabling Civil Society to contribute to Public Security Policy and Programming in Nepal
description: We are supporting local people to engage with the police and local authorities so they tackle their security concerns together; and with civil society to advocate for more gender-responsive safety provision. We use the findings from these projects to influence district and national level policy and practice.
implementing_organisations: ;Informal Sector Service Center (INSEC);Saferworld;Institute for Human Rights and Communication Nepal (IHRICON)

title: Gender-sensitive community security and conflict prevention in the Ferghana Valley
description: Saferworld has been supporting civil society organisations in southern Kyrgyzstan and northern Tajikistan to put conflict and gender-sensitive approaches into practice in their work since 2010. We provide training, consultancy and mentoring on conflict sensitivity, conflict analysis and security sector reform, building the capacity of local civil society within Central Asia.
implementing_organisations: ;Foundation for Tolerance International (FTI) ;Association for Scientific and Technological Intelligentsia (ASTI) ;Saferworld

title: Promoting participatory approaches to peacebuilding in KP and FATA of Pakistan
description: This is a three year programme to promote and develop participatory peacebuilding initiatives in KP and FATA. We are supporting civil society organisations in the region to gain the skills and confidence needed to ensure that decision-makers understand and act on local security needs and that communities and marginalised groups are consulted in national and international peace efforts. We deliver trainings for CSOs aimed at developing practical skills and theoretical knowledge of peacebuilding on the following issues: participatory conflict analysis; conflict sensitivity; mediation, dialogue, negotiation and peacebuilding; advocacy for conflict transformation; understanding and measuring change; and community-driven initiatives for peace.

title: Towards Peaceful and Secure 2012 Presidential Elections in Kenya
description: Ahead of the March 2013 elections, Saferworld worked with key peace, security and election management actors across Kenya to strengthen preparedness and coordination in support of peaceful, free and fair national polls. We are also continuing to work with grassroots peace actors in six potential hotspots to build resilience to conflict, promote peacebuilding and strengthen the capacity of community members to hold their leaders to account, including on issues of governance, security and service delivery.
implementing_organisations: ;Saferworld;The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) ;National Steering Committee on Peace Building and Conflict Management (NSC);National Cohesion and Integration Commission;Kenya Partnership for Peace and Security ;Uwiano Platform for Peace

title: Institutionalising Comprehensive Police Reform in Kenya
description: This project aims to ensure that broader reforms within the security sector in general, and within the National Police Service in particular, lead to improved service delivery; professionalism; accountability; and ability to address the security needs of Kenyans. We are working in and among 13 communities in Kenya across seven counties. The focus of this work is at the national as well as local level. We are working to ensure that the National Police Service Standing Orders and Regulations, currently being developed by the Inspector Generalâ€™s Office, include key guidelines on accountability and professionalism among police officers. This includes the use of force and firearms, community policing implementation, and human rights â€“ feeding in key technical expertise to those drafting the regulations.

title: Empowering young people to advocate for inclusive transitional and political processes in Yemen
description: This project aimed to give voice and agency to young women and men involved in conflict transformation and peacebuilding, and to ensure a more inclusive transition process in Yemen that is responsive to the needs and concerns of young people. We provided research and advocacy trainings to youth activists to strengthen their capacities to engage with decision makers and international actors. We also developed stronger, more encompassing and inclusive informal youth networks across Yemen and increased youthâ€™s access to and influence on Yemeni policy makers and international actors.

title: Empowering civil society actors in Kyrgyzstan to contribute to policing and other security issues
description: In Kyrgyzstan, we are working to call for changes in the way that security is provided. We have established the â€˜Civic Union for Reform and Resultsâ€™ (CURR), a coalition of 24 civil society organisations, former police officers, journalists and researchers on police reform from all regions of Kyrgyzstan. Its priority is to focus on progressive changes in the law enforcement system through promoting the ideas of the civil union and the views of the population through reform of the Interior Ministry of Kyrgyzstan. Through CURRâ€™s campaigning, government agencies have started to consider the views of civil society on police reform. CURR has assessed the needs and problems related to policing identified by local people during consultations, and is now working with local people and authorities to promote progressive changes in the law enforcement system.
implementing_organisations: ;Saferworld;Free Generationâ€™ â€“ the Liberal Youth Alliance (LYA)

title: Community security and conflict prevention in the Ferghana Valley Phase III
description: We are developing inclusive approaches to community security in the Ferghana Valley. We work in two contexts: with communities living in the border areas between Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan; and with Kyrgyz and Uzbek communities in the Osh and Jalalabad areas. Our work brings together communities from different ethnicities encouraging constructive co-operation on local security issues between residents, authorities and law enforcement agencies. From this experience we are developing practical, evidence-based policy recommendations to feed into wider debates on community security effectiveness, linking our community work with national policy changes.
implementing_organisations: ;Youth Development Initiatives (MIR) ;Saferworld;Association for Scientific and Technological Intelligentsia (ASTI);Foundation for Tolerance International (FTI)

title: Community-based approaches to security in conflict-prone areas of the Caucasus
description: In this project we have established community-safety networks in very different contexts â€“ along the divide between Shida Kartli and South Ossetia, within South Ossetia itself and in the eastern part of Abkhazia. In each context, we map community security needs, identify priorities and plan solutions together with members of the community. We have established community-led mechanisms to map trends in perceptions of security and to provide early warning of likely increases in tensions. In the latest phase of our project we have also focussed on bringing together community representatives with government representatives and local authorities, giving people a voice to air their problems and building relationships.

title: Strengthening the participation of Somali NSAs in decision making on peace, security and development Phase II - Towards Sustainability
description: Saferworld has been working since 2004 to strengthen the participation and influence of Somali NSAs in key decision-making processes on peace, security, and development. This phase of the project aims to support the platforms to independently engage in policy dialogue with Somali authorities and the international community on a range of issues, and also to influence key policy and decision-making processes.

title: Council decision 2012/121/CFSP in support of activities to promote EU-China-Africa dialogue and co-operation on conventional arms control
description: The primary aim of the project is to facilitate dialogue that contributes to meaningful EU-China-Africa co-operative actions that address the threats associated with the proliferation of conventional arms, focusing on SALW controls and the UN ATT process. Working with China Arms Control and Disarmament Association (CACDA), China Institutes of Contemporary China Studies (CICIR), Chinese Peopleâ€™s Association on Peace and Disarmament (CPAPD), Tsinghua University (Beijing), Tongji University (Shanghai), Africa Peace Forum (APFO â€“ Nairobi) , the project is creating sustainable networks and forums, increasing awareness and engagement by the policy community, and supporting joint research.
funding_organisations: ;European Commission - Service for Foreign Policy Instrument
implementing_organisations: ;Saferworld;China Arms Control and Disarmament Association (CACDA);Africa Peace Forum (APFO)

title: Strengthening women's public voice in Egypt, Libya and Yemen
description: In 2012 Saferworld began a regional project looking at how safety and security concerns in Egypt, Libya and Yemen impact womenâ€™s public participation. In the first phase of the project, we have conducted research with women activists with diverse backgrounds in each country to better understand the threats to their safety, how insecurity is preventing them from participating in decision-making, and how women are responding to these problems. Our work also seeks to support women from across the region to engage in policy dialogue on security issues, participate in political processes and form initiatives to address local security and safety concerns. We have formed a regional network of women activists called â€˜Sawtana Kawatunaâ€™ in order to facilitate dialogue and lesson-sharing between Egypt, Libya, Yemen and other MENA countries.
implementing_organisations: ;Saferworld;Nazra for Feminist Studies ;Voices for Libyan Women

title: Improving conditions for reconstruction and development in Bangladesh, South Sudan and Yemen
description: The aim of the project is to contribute to an improved environment for reconstruction and development in Bangladesh, South Sudan and Yemen. It sets out to do this by creating more active, informed and inclusive societies, and more effective and accountable institutions â€“ in turn increasing public safety and security.
implementing_organisations: ;The Organisation for Children Harmony (TOCH);The Kuac Area Development Agency (KUADA);BRAC International;National Organisation for Development of Society (NODS)

title: Conflict sensitive engagement in South Sudan: China's role
description: This project aimed to encourage Chinese policy and engagement in South Sudan to be more conflict-sensitive and open to dialogue with civil society. It delivered a series of meetings and workshops in Beijing and Juba that introduce the concept of conflict sensitivity to a broad range of Chinese actors, including officials, state-owned banks, state-owned and private commercial actors, academics and researchers. The project will also promote people-centred approaches to security through facilitating dialogue between the above-mentioned Chinese actors and South Sudanese civil society. Furthermore, the project will create forums to bring together Chinese policy makers and researchers, South Sudanese officials and civil society, officials from regional and Western governments and international NGOs. Lastly, the project will support field research in South Sudan by the Chinese researchers.

title: Conflict sensitive engagement in South Sudan: China's role
description: At a policy level we are bringing together high-level Chinese and South Sudanese stakeholders in government, the corporate sector, and civil society, to promote conflict sensitive approaches to China-South Sudan engagement. Key areas of discussion include small arms control, improving community security and maximising the positive impact of aid on peacebuilding. We are facilitating on-going discussions between high level policymakers in both Beijing and Juba.

title: Support to South Sudan programme 2012 - 2014
description: With this project Saferworld wants to contribute to an improved environment for reconstruction and development by increasing public safety and security through more active, informed and inclusive societies and more effective and accountable state institutions, and by ensuring that national and international development actors working in these contexts incorporate conflict-sensitive approaches into their policy and practice.
implementing_organisations: ;Saferworld;The Organisation for Children Harmony (TOCH);The Kuac Area Development Agency (KUADA)

title: Empowering CSOs in Kosovo to become effective contributors to security policy and decision making processes.
description: Our 18-month joint project with Saferworld, Forum for Civic Initiatives (FIQ), and AKTIV, financed by the European Union, is focussed on â€œEmpowering CSOs in Kosovo to become effective contributors to security policy and decision making.â€ù We are building the research and advocacy capacities of local CSOs in Kosovo, so that they can work in municipalities to undertake high quality research, with the intention of influencing security policies to respond to the concerns of local people on key peace, security, and conflict related issues.

title: Amplifying Youth Voices in Yemen's Transition
description: In this project we supported young women and men in Yemen to ensure their voices were heard by policy makers during the transition period. The project had three main components: research into young peopleâ€™s perceptions and priorities for Yemenâ€™s political transition, which informed evidence-based advocacy; strengthening the advocacy skills of select youth leaders and helping them develop stronger, more inclusive networks across Yemen; and building constructive relationships between youth leaders and Yemeni decision-makers so that young people could bring their concerns, insight and experiences to bear on political decisions.
implementing_organisations: ;Saferworld;Riwaa Youth Development Foundation;Youth Development Organisation;Resonate Yemen

title: Preventing Radicalization and Violent Extremism Leading to Terrorism through Cross-Border Community Policing in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan
description: Together with our local partner, the Foundation for Tolerance International (FTI), we have been working on the project, â€œPreventing radicalism and violent extremism through community policing in Kyrgyzstan.â€ù We are bringing together communities from different ethnicities and encouraging constructive co-operation on local security issues between residents, authorities and law enforcement agencies. From this experience we are developing practical, evidence-based policy recommendations to feed into wider debates on community security effectiveness, linking our community work with national policy changes.

title: Partnerships for Local Development, 'Sajhedari Bikass'
description: The goal of this project is to ensure that targeted communities better direct local development. In order to achieve this objective the targeted communities will have the knowledge, skills and abilities to identify and access financial resources to fund local development activities that the communities themselves have identified in an inclusive and participatory manner. Further, the targeted communities will have the knowledge, skills and abilities to manage, implement, and provide for operations and maintenance of small-scale development activities. The targeted communities will also have access to appropriate community stabilization initiatives, which will focus on addressing drivers of conflict and establishing an enabling environment for community development. Finally, new local government units in the targeted communities will possess the KSAs to function effectively.

title: Community initiatives for common understanding in Nepal
description: The program will bring together conflicting groups within communities, including male and female former combatants, through a people-to-people (P2P) approach to local development and community peacebuilding linked to existing dispute resolution mechanisms. By creating opportunities for structured interaction between conflicting groups around shared local concerns, the program will support the building of trust and more resilient social ties across divided communities.
implementing_organisations: ;Child Workers in Nepal Concerned Centre (CWIN);Informal Sector Service Center (INSEC)

title: The inclusion of conflict and violence issues in the post-2015 development framework
description: This project will support research and dialogue activities engaging a range of policy communities and actors, including rising powers and traditional donor countries, multilateral actors and other global stakeholders both at the country level and among decision makers in New York.

title: Conflict, Crime and Violence Results Initiative (CCVRI) Helpdesk
description: Saferworld is proposing to provide written advice to DfID as a new member of the Conflict, Crime and Violence Results Initiative (CCVRI). Over the period September 2013 to May 2014, Saferworld will provide DfID with high quality, bespoke written advice from our leading international expert staff and associates in response to requests from DfID country offices on themes related to conflict, crime and violence results. Saferworld will also provide written reports in areas of potential interest to DfID drawn from a menu of supply-side tasks. This proposal would enable Saferworld indicatively to respond to ten on-demand requests and complete four supply side products for DfID in the project period.

title: The inclusion of conflict and violence issues in the post-2015 development framework
description: The purpose of this project is to conduct research and support dialogue on the inclusion of conflict and violence issues in the post-2015 development framework, engaging a range of policy communities and actors, including rising powers and traditional donor countries, multilateral actors and other global stakeholders both at the country level and among decision makers in New York.

title: Contribution to Community Policing and Community Security Programme in South Sudan
description: Through this programme contribution, Saferworld seeks to work alongside and add value to the Safety and Access to Justice Programme (SAJP) police service delivery work. This programme will contributes to the programme goal of â€œEnabling communities, Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) and other actors to engage more effectively with the South Sudan National Police Service (SSNPS) and other authorities to improve safety and security and experience a reduction in threats.â€ù
implementing_organisations: ;The Organisation for Children Harmony (TOCH);The Kuac Area Development Agency (KUADA)

title: Capacities for Peace
description: In contexts where overall in-country analytical capacity is lower, the project will focus on building the in-country skills base and creating opportunities for in-country and/or regional engagement between civil society and other relevant stakeholders, including EU Delegation(s). This will include identifying key gaps in existing analysis, seeking out under-represented perspectives and innovative approaches at local, national and regional levels and tailoring the actions to take advantage of opportunities to engage in the most strategic way.

title: Building Responsive Institutions through Conflict Sensitive Approaches to Development

title: Promoting community focused responses to conflict in Armenia and Azerbaijan
description: The proposed project aims to raise awareness, both nationally and internationally, of the security concerns of communities living in frontline areas along the Armenia-Azerbaijan border and around Nagorny Karabakh, as well as empowering communities to add their voices to security provision and peace-building processes.
funding_organisations: ;Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation SDC

title: Rising Powers and Conflict Management in Central Asia.
description: This project seeks to develop a more global perspective in conflict prevention and peacebuilding work by examining the implications of rising powers in conflicted and fragile countries.

Supporting momentum for gender-sensitive security sector reform in Yemen

title: Preventing and reducing violent conflict and promoting cooperative approaches to security building
description: Core support to Saferworld\'s work to prevent and reduce violent conflict and promote cooperative approaches to Security Building.

title: Improving maternal and newborn health for women and newborns in Nkhotakota District, Malawi
description: Empowering rural women to access quality maternal and newborn health services in Nkhotakota, Malawi. Direct beneficiaries are 52,976 women and 11,517 newborns. Our innovation is to combine evidence that mobilising communities reduces maternal and newborn mortality with MaiKhandaâ€™s experience that facilitating community/facility dialogue and communities and holding healthcare providers accountable can improve maternal and newborn health services.

title: Improving maternal and newborn health in Bogra District, Bangladesh
description: This project seeks to improve maternal and newborn health in Bogra District, Bangladesh. A total 22,307 women of reproductive age (aged 15-44), 5,819 girls aged 10-14 and 5,019 newborns will benefit directly from the project. These benefits will be achieved through three complementary approaches â€“ facilitating womenâ€™s groups; establishing referral and communication systems between communities and health facilities; and supporting advocacy with decision-makers. These approaches will improve maternal and newborn health by enabling community members, health workers and policy-makers to take action to improve maternal and newborn health care and care-seeking behaviour, service quality and accessibility and policy.

title: Farmer Households Empowered through Women (FHEW)
description: The purpose of the project is 1,300 poor and vulnerable households with balanced nutrition, access to safe water, income and improved environment by 2017. This will be achieved by empowering women to adopt sustainable practices that diversify and intensify crop and livestock production integrating existing livelihood systems with new income generating opportunities. Through self-help groups (SHGs), women will enhance self-reliant development and integration into local market systems in a sustainable and gender-sensitive manner.;1300 households;- 65 SHGs (1,000 women and 300 men) initiate and lead sustainable family and community development and promote gender equity/equality - 1,040 households have sufficient nutritious food throughout the year - 1,460 farmer households have access to improved water and use simple and appropriate sanitation and hygiene practices - 1,040 households have increased their income by 75% through produce, marketing and self-employment - 1,040 households manage their natural resources in a productive and sustainable way

title: Madagascar Hotspot
description: Madagascar is the major producer and exporter of vanilla in the world. Although its vanilla is highly sought after over the world, the majority of the 80,000 small-scale farmers who produce the vanilla experience food insecurity. This is caused by the fact they do not earn sufficient income to adequately provide food for themselves and their families throughout the year. About 75% of the small farmers in Madagascarâ€™s SAVA region â€“ the main vanilla producing region â€“ live below US$1 a day. Fairfood works on having solid methodologies in place for assessing a fair price. Furthermore we engage with multinational brands and flavour houses sourcing vanilla from Madagascar to increase their awareness on the issues farmers face, and to ensure that these small farmers receive a fair income. These companies can and should help farmers to break out of the cycle of poverty by ensuring that these smallholder farmers are paid a fair price for their vanilla. A fair price covers, amongst other things, a living wage for farmers, any other labour either from family members or hired labourers, plus all costs and risks involved in the production, and ensures a certain degree of stability over time.

title: Campaigning against grabbing community land in Kalangala
description: FoE Uganda will use the funds to improve the ability of communities to prevent land-grabbing from palm oil company (BIDCO) and reinforce the regulation. The main initiative were campaigns against land-grabbing in Kalangala district, Uganda. The local communities under threat were Mugoye, Kasekulo, Kyamuswa and Bwendero on Bugala Island. Kagonya, on Bunyama Island. The activities planned were: community trainings on basic community land-rights and entitlements, engagement with local government and company representatives, exchange visit between the people of Bugala and Bunyama where BIDCO is intending to expand palm oil, Developing and printing advocacy materials such as t-shirts and brochures, sharing experience on land grabbing with other partners in the international meetings Network with a district NGO umbrella called KADINGO, so we were working with almost all the CBOS and CSOs in the district. This was a great opportunity because women groups, youth groups and the drama groups would never missed-out in our engagement meetings. Largely the role of KADINGO was mobilizing and networking with the groups for effective advocacy. The results were: Local communities have been made aware their status of tenures to prevent reckless evictions as the preventing measures to land-grabbing by government and the developers. Those who were on any land for 12 years before the coming into force of the 1995 Uganda constitution are the rightful bonefide occupants. Campaign materials developed (t-shits, video documentary, and brochures) and were used at local national and international levels. Brochures and t-shirts were used during COP 17 in South Africa and CBD11 in India. Series of meetings conducted with senior government officials, company reps etc to advocate to stop land-grabbing by BIDCO.

title: Rwandan Girls' Education and Advancement Programme
description: Rwanda Girls Education Advancement Project - In Nyaruguru, Rwanda, many girls are excluded from education for financial and socio-cultural reasons. Lack of education is a root cause of poverty and ill health, so TAMTF is working with the community to effect long-lasting change for girls in this area with funding from the DFID-Girls Education Challenge. The impact of this project will be to improve the life chances of marginalised girls in Rwanda, supporting them to complete a full cycle of education and demonstrate learning as a direct outcome of the project. In particular, TAMTF is responsible for helping to develop and support school businesses, generating income which the schools can use to keep girls in school, and help to provide students with the entrepreneurial skills they need to reach their potential in life.

title: Improving early years education & health for 3700 deprived children and empowering 600 vulnerable caregivers in rural Uganda through community-run Play Centres.
description: We will improve the educational attainment of 3,700 deprived rural children by setting up high quality educational Play Centres in 20 deprived rural communities. We will train 30 individuals from each community, targeting marginalised women, to run the Centres themselves as Volunteers. This is a cheap, scalable and sustainable way to improve the cognitive skills, school preparedness and health of children, whilst simultaneously building the capacities of caregivers and improving their wellbeing.

title: Organisational Budget 2013-14
Planned Organisational Budget for 2014/15
Business Development Services
description: Business Development Services aligns enterprises, impact investors, and business consultants to drive sustainable change across Africa, believing that through the growth of socially conscious businesses, impact on small-holder farmers and front line employees can be both substantial and sustainable. By providing professional business development and capacity building services, BDS enables enterprises to scale up and improve their operations, ultimately preparing them for investment.

title: MGCubed - Making Ghanaian Girls Great!
description: MGCubed is a two and a half year project which delivers lessons. It is being delivered by GEMS Education Solutions in Ghana alongside key partners Aleutia, Everonn, Gem Technologies, and our independent evaluator, Innovations for Poverty Action. It will target 6,000 marginalised elementary school girls in the Volta Region (Nkwanta and Kadjebi districts) and in the Greater Accra Region (Ada West, Ada East, Shai Osudoku and Ningo Prampram districts). The pioneering first-of-its-kind project focuses on â€˜interactive distance learningâ€™ providing classrooms in seventy schools with solar-powered computers and projectors to broadcast live sessions from teaching studios in Accra.

title: Farmers Club â€“ Bengo Province
description: Summary: â€œFarmers Clubâ€ù is an agricultural training programme, where farmers are trained for 3 years in low cost, low tech methods to improve their production. Training involves basic farming, farm management and entrepreneurship. The focus is on improved methods, increased diversity, higher productivity, access to markets and protecting the environment;Target Group: for 750 subsistence farmers and their families in Bengo province. The 750 farmers will be organized in 15 clubs of 50 members. Women will be encouraged to become members and participate in the project activities on an equal footing with men.;Goal:to enable the farmers to become food secure and produce a surplus to market during the three project years. After this period, the farmers are equipped with the skills, knowledge, experience and income generating capacity to continue expanding their production.;Background: Most families live from subsistence agriculture and food insecurity is an issue at certain times of year. Few The farmers received no training and there is little evidence of any kind of organization or cooperative farming, both of which could lead to improved circumstances. Traditionally women in Angola carry out much of the family-level subsistence agricultural production, which also is the situation in Bengo province. However the women are not normally involved in determining the planning of what and how much to grow, much less in how to use the surplus production. Nambuangongo is one of the areas in Bengo province with a relatively high population density, making it possible to organize the farmers. ;Project Plan: The 750 farmers will be organized in 15 clubs of 50 members. The Club project leaders will be trained in all aspects of project implementation. Women will be encouraged to become members and participate in the project activities on an equal footing with men. As soon the members have joined the club, Farmersâ€™ Club Committees are elected and start their training. The Farmers Club project aims at improving the general standard of living for the farmer and his or her family through increased knowledge and skills in taking care of the health, education and wellbeing of the whole family. By creating viable structures for the farmers in the project area they become organised and productive. Access to markets will be facilitated and/or strengthened. During the programme
sector-text: Agricultural Development

title: Women economic development through vocational training
description: Summary:improve economy, social integration and living conditions for women in Kingabwa, Kinshasa, DR Congo by strengthening their capacity to improve their economy. The programs will train 600 women in entrepreneurship, teach 600 illiterate women and young girls to read, write and do elementary calculation and discuss sensitive social topics (gender equality, violence against women, reproductive health etcâ€_) and train the same 600 young women in skills (sewing, beautician/hairdresser, patisserie/bakery and urban gardening). ;Goal Overview: to teach and capacitate women to improve their economy and living conditions thus the livelihoods of children and the development of the community./ to contribute to the promotion of womenâ€™s entrepreneurship and social & economic empowerment and rights.;Target Groups: directly 200 women in entrepreneurship, 200 women in skills training, 300 illiterate women and 80 preschool pupils. The indirect beneficiaries are the entire population of the Child Aid project area in Kingabwa.;Background: Humana People to People Congo (HPP-Congo) was created in September 2006 as a national nonprofit association. HPP-Congo works with communities to build their capacity to improve living conditions, especially for the most vulnerable members of society.;Project Plan: To contribute to the promotion of womenâ€™s entrepreneurship and social & economic empowerment and rights training programs are developed and training centers are set up. 600 Women will be trained in entrepreneurship, skills and 600 community members will be educated in reading, writing and elementary calculations. To make this possible for women, 2 preschools are established for the their children.
sector-text: Vocational training

title: Education Opportunities for Women (TTC Chilangoma)
description: Goal Overview: Educate 60 female primary school teachers for rural areas during 3 years at the TTC Chilangoma in Malawi with the final goal to increase participation of girls in primary school education ;Summary: Malawi suffers from an acute lack of female teachers, meaning those girls who are able to get to school lack the role models to help encourage them to stay. Development Aid from People to People (DAPP) Malawi has a unique teacher training program which promotes gender equity and women's empowerment. DAPP does not only train young people to become qualified primary school teachers, addressing the urgent need for quality teachers, but the education also provides young women and men with sustainable career training and job placement.;Target Groups: 60 young women from poor rural backgrounds;Project Plan: DAPP hereby invited Humana Holland to support 60 young women to be trained as primary school teachers and thereby become role models and support the education of more girls in primary schools. Throughout the 3 year teacher training female and male student are given equal opportunities and challenges and at the same time the female student teachers are encouraged to take up bigger responsibilities and be in the forefront of tasks.
sector-text: Teacher Training

title: Farmers Club Equateur
description: Goal Overview: The project will empower the farmers to become active and contribute efficiently to the development of their communities. It is the aim of the Farmersâ€™ Club project to assure food security in farmersâ€™ households by improving their production and to significantly increase their incomes with the organization of sales committees and cooperatives.;Summary: The project has organized 1,000 Farmers in 20 clubs of 50 members/farmers with the aim to assist them improving their agricultural practices, economy and living conditions, which is a direct response to the Millennium Development Goals: â€œEliminate extreme poverty and hungerâ€ù and â€œensure a sustainable environmentâ€ù. The project is organized in 4 units of 250 farmers in 5 clubs led by a farming instructor.;Target Groups: The project has organized 1,000 Farmers in 20 clubs of 50 members/farmers with the aim to assist them improving their agricultural practices, economy and living conditions. The project will empower the farmers to become active and contribute efficiently to the development of their communities. Illiterate farmers are encouraged to register for the literacy courses.;Project Plan: The project will be led by a Project Leader who will be responsible of the overall activities of the project and he will report to the National Country Office of HPP-Congo. 4 Farmers Instructors at 1/unit will be responsible each of 250 farmers organized in 5 clubs, educating and assisting them technically for a better agricultural production. The Farming Instructors will report to the Project Leader. The project will have 20 Sales Committees and 20 Farmersâ€™ Club committee s with a total of 100 members who will be responsible for coordinating activities in the Farmersâ€™ Clubs with the assistance of Farming Instructors.
sector-text: Agricultural Development

title: Farmers Club Madimba
description: Goal Overview: To increase food security and reduce poverty of 750 subsistence farmers and their families in Madimba territory in Bas Congo province by assisting vulnerable communities to improve their agricultural practices and living conditions.;Summary: Humana People to People Congo (HPP-Congo) started up a farmerâ€™s club program in Bas Congo province in the R.D.DR Congo. The actions of this program will result in food self-sufficiency and, production of marketable surplus to improve family economy. Living conditions will also be improved through lessons on hygiene, using clean safe water, nutrition, disease prevention etc. Campaigns and open days will be part of the program on quarterly and annual bases.;Target Groups: The direct beneficiaries are 750 farmers and their families in the territory of Madimba. The indirect beneficiaries are the community of Madimba benefitting from increased production, better health and nutrition and an increase of local economy as well as the population of Kinshasa that will buy products from farmers.;Project Plan: 750 farmers are trained infor a 3 years Farmers Club programme in the territory of Madimba in the Province of Bas-Congo. The identified villages are Mfuma, Ngufu and Kintanu. 3 units of 250 farmers each will be organized in the villages. One unit is made of 5 clubs of 50 farmers each. The project will organize a total of 15 farmers clubs of 50 farmers each totalizing 750 farmers. Each unit will be led by a farming instructor. Each club will elect among its members a committee of 5 literate members to organize and coordinate the activities of the club.
sector-text: Agricultural development

title: Young male economic development through vocational training
description: Goal Overview: Create self-reliance of 400 male adolescents in Kingabwa, Kinshasa, DR Congo through 12 month vocational training.;Summary: Despite weak government structures, DR Congo is going through a period of economic growth (expected 8.2% in 2013) and Kinshasa experiences a relative building boom with establishment of hotels, conference - and shopping centers, and the demand for competent construction workers is growing. In response to this situation, HPP-Congo establishes a training programme with relevant construction skills for young boys. The project will target unemployed boys in general, who can document that they have at least completed 6 years of primary education.;Target Groups: unemployed young men between 15 and 22 years who have at least completed primary school (grade 6). These will primarily be found among the active families in the HPP Congo programme Child Aid Kingabwa project in order to have a good support from the family. Indirect beneficiaries are 2.400 family members who benefit from the boysâ€™ increased earnings.;Project Plan: By extending the existing (female) skills training program in Kingabwa to include male adolecents, some of these young men may be able to create an income in the wake of the building boom when equipped with relevant experience. The skills training will be half time theoretical and half time practical.
recipient-country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo
sector-text: Vocational training

title: Plumbing and Wash course Mikolongwe VTC
description: Goal Overview: to offer a quality WASH and Plumbing Technician course to young Malawians between 17 and 28 years old in a more conducive environment.;Summary:This project will benefit youth at the school to acquire new skills and knowledge in WASH and Plumbing techniques. The students/youth will also learn to establish and run successful WASH and Plumbing trade after graduating from the school. They can also get employed in the construction industry. These Technicians will be filling a niche in the technical requirements of the Construction and WASH industries in Malawi. We envisage that the short courses will entice a significant number of practicing Plumbers who may want to upgrade their knowhow in water and borehole maintenance, apart from installation of domestic water systems. The students will also learn new techniques in the Sanitation field, such as different aspects of Pit- Latrine Construction and maintenance.;Training of students, initially 120 students with about 50% girls.;Project Plan: In total 120 students would be trained over the three year period. Hostel accommodation required will be for 32 students at a time per year as DAPP is expecting the number of youth interested in this kind of training to be increased.
sector-text: Vocational training

title: Sustainable livelihoods Chiradzulu and Thyolo
description: Goal Overview: Increase livelihood sustainability of 9500 households in Chiradzulu and Thyolo districts by creating environmental awareness, planting 1 million trees and promoting the use of firewood saving stoves within one year.;Summary: As an integrated project within DAPP Child Aid project in Chiradzulu and Thyolo Districts capacity building for Community Environment and Conservation comes as a rescue plan, in which families and communities will be mobilised and encouraged to establish/strengthen Village Forest Areas (VFAs), plant more trees and to look after their natural environment.;Target Groups: About 9500 households will be mobilised and educated about the importance of protecting the environment spread over 250 villages in T/A Mtchema, Mpama and Kadewere in Chiradzulu district and TA Changata, Bvumbwe and Nsabwe in Thyolo district.;Project Plan: DAPP intends to implement a one year Community Environment and Conservation capacity building project to manage natural resources and mitigate climate change impact by planting over 1,000,000 trees on the bare lands, in the gardens, around homesteads and village woodlots. The programme will cover 250 villages in T/A Mtchema, Mpama and Kadewere in Chiradzulu district and TA Changata, Bvumbwe and Nsabwe in Thyolo district and directly reach 9,500 families. The project will preserve the existing natural indigenous trees in (VFAs). The idea is to make one tree nursery per village and have a total of 250 nurseries
sector-text: Agricultural development

title: Carpentry Course Mikolongwe VTC
description: Goal Overview: the goal is to reduce youth employment by creating self-reliance of 60 adolecents (age 18 to 24) by educating them in carpentry and life skills according to modern standards at Mikolongwe Vocational school within 3 years.;Summary: The DAPP Vocational School project resonates well with governmentâ€˜s youth development programme to promote business development amongst the youths in order to contribute towards the eradication of poverty, unemployment, prostitution, alcohol and drug abuse among youths. The school seeks to offer quality training in livelihoods skills to the enrolled students with a core component of general education. This Carpentry course will target the youth and in service carpenters that would want to upgrade their career or skills by using new methodologies and technologies in a more conducive environment.;Summary: The DAPP Vocational School project resonates well with governmentâ€˜s youth development programme to promote business development amongst the youths in order to contribute towards the eradication of poverty, unemployment, prostitution, alcohol and drug abuse among youths. The school seeks to offer quality training in livelihoods skills to the enrolled students with a core component of general education. This Carpentry course will target the youth and in service carpenters that would want to upgrade their career or skills by using new methodologies and technologies in a more conducive environment.;Target Groups: 60 students (30 male and 30 female) in the age of 18 to 24. Mostly the students would come from poor backgrounds. Poor in the sense that they can not raise the full amount of school fees for their education and struggle to raise funds for basic needs. ;Project Plan: This action will benefit 30 young men and 30 young women at the school to acquire modern skills and knowledge in Carpentry techniques. The students will be equipped with skills to establish and run a successful carpentry and joinery workshop. They can also get employed in the construction industry. There is a great impact of poverty in the country. Some of the students will be enrolled due to their vulnerability as per government standards. Mostly the students would come from poor backgrounds. DAPP Management will organize for professional upgrading of its staff for this course
sector-text: Vocational training

title: Nutrition Education Teacher Training College Caxito
description: Goal Overview: Primary school children taught by the graduated TTC teachers have a broad understanding of how to change their nutritional status by changes in the daily diet. Through practicing setting up and maintaining a (door-size) home garden, the pupils are able to apply this at home and spread the knowledge and skills to their peers and parents. ;Summary: The proposed project aims to implement a Nutrition education and School Garden course at the ADPP Teacher Training College (TTC) in Caxito. The student teachers will learn how to develop nutrition education lessons for every grade and they will create practice school gardens at TTC Caxito, and at the primary schools where they teach during their teaching practice. The fruits and vegetables grown in the school garden will benefit the children, but the primary aim is that they gain improved knowledge and skills about what a healthy daily diet is, as well as about growing and eating healthy produce which they can introduce at home. ;Target Groups: 80 Student teachers at the Teacher Training College Caxito;Project Plan: The teacher training course at the ADPP Teacher Training Colleges has a duration of 2,5 years. The trainee teachers carry out two periods of teaching practice. In the fourth period, they have half day practice in nearby schools. In the seventh period, they do a full year of teaching practice at rural schools throughout the province.
recipient-region: Angola - Caxito in the province of Bengo
sector-text: Teacher Training

title: Basic Academic and professional School (EPP) Caxito, team 2013
description: Goal Overview: To offer Angolan youth a lower secondary education through which they acquire academic and practical skills, as well as general knowledge and life skills to enable them to become productive citizens, able to create a good life for themselves and their families and to contribute to the development of the country ;Summary: : In cooperation with the Ministry of Education, ADPP is launching a new type of education in Angola: Basic Academic and Technical Education, known as EPP. The three year courses will combine regular schooling with vocational subjects and successful students will graduate with a nationally recognized academic and vocational certificate, corresponding to 9th grade. On graduation they will be able to continue to the next level of education (upper secondary) or find employment / start their own enterprise.;Target Groups: The direct target group consists of 70 young people, 12 â€“ 18 years of age, from all municipalities in Bengo province, who have concluded primary school.;Project Plan: The first year of the EPP program is a basic year, during which the students learn the academic subjects at 7th grade level through untraditional pedagogical methods link-ing theory with daily life and practice in the professions, learn to work in a group, to carry out investigations in the community, to speak in public and much more, and also try their hand at three professions, namely Community Health Agent, Food Producer, and Environment Pro-moter. During the second and third year the students will specialize in one of the three professions offered at EPP Caxito, which are: Energy Assistant, Food Producer, and Modern Cook.
sector-text: Secondary education

title: Basic Academic and professional School (EPP) Caxito , team 2012
description: Goal Overview: To offer Angolan youth a lower secondary education through which they acquire academic and practical skills, as well as general knowledge and life skills to enable them to become productive citizens, able to create a good life for themselves and their families and to contribute to the development of the country ;Summary: : In cooperation with the Ministry of Education, ADPP is launching a new type of education in Angola: Basic Academic and Technical Education, known as EPP. title: Nutrition education & schoolgardens TTC2
description: Goal Overview: Primary school children taught by the graduated TTC teachers have a broad understanding of developing and maintaining a (door-size) home garden and they are able to apply this at home and spread the knowledge and skills to peers and their parents. The project will secure a widespread appreciation of the use of local vegetables and fruits, use of organic and human manure as well as of use of conservation gardening methods. ;Summary: The Nutrition education and schoolgardens TTC2 is a follow up project of the 2011 project. Innovative ideas were brought to the college and the schools â€“ the growing of local vegetables and fruits, involvement of even young children in the garden as well as the construction of latrines and use of human manure. The project has also gained valuable experience in cooperation with other stakeholders with in School Health and Nutrition in Malawi â€“ both within the Ministry of Education Structures and in other NGOs. By extending the project for a few more years a bigger impact can be reached. The proposed extension of the project will be relying on the already implemented curriculum development and the experiences gained in teaching practice schools. Improvement en continuation of the demonstration gardens at the TTC and the gardens in the primary schools is needed for 2 years and at the same time to construct additionally 6 Skyloo latrines in the primary schools. Additionally the school would like to act as an knowledge centre on nutrition education and the implementation of schoolgardens. ;Target Groups: Teacher students, of the Chilangoma Teachers Training Colleges in South West Education Division in Blantyre district, and primary school children. ;Project Plan: The project will be implemented in Teaching practice schools of DAPP Chilangoma Teachers Training Colleges in South West Education Division in Blantyre District. The DAPP Teacher Training Program has a duration of 2.5 year in Malawi. Students will have their practice period in the second year.
sector-text: Teacher Training

title: Renewable energy and electricity course Mikolongwe VTC
description: Goal Overview: Training 50 students in sustainable Energy within 1 year (1 april 2015 â€“ 30 maart 2016) op Mikolonge vocational school in Malawi.;Project Plan: The 50 students are divided within two groups. Ten formal students follow a 1 year course while the other 40 students follow a shorter course of 4 months.;Summary: Humana supports the Vocational School in Mikolongwe, Malawi. This is one of few private schools completely accredited by TEVETA. Much attention is given to the good connection between training and the business field. In 2011 en 2012 the school has extended up to 32 training places. Since Electricity is considered an important catalyst for development and creating many opportunities in the field of Sustainable development we are supporting the course on Sustainable Energy since 2012. Students are trained as regular electricians ;Target Groups: School leavers between the age group of 18-36. The eligible students for electrical installation course are the holders of MSCE certificate, with passes in all science subjects and those who have skill for electrical installation, have added advantage.
sector-text: Vocational training

title: Farmers Club (FC) Chiradzulu
description: The project goal: Social and economic women empowerment through training of 1,200 women farmers. ;Summary: The project aims to increase agricultural productivity and economic empowerment among 1,200 young female farmers in Chiradzulu District.Through intensive trainings the participating farmers will be equipped with the skills, knowledge and hands-on experience enabling her/him to increase productivity of crops and livestock, practice small-scale irrigation, and process food for adding value and making the products more marketable ;The primary target group is young female farmers. Women have been selected as a priority group because of the disproportionate impact that poverty has on women in all its forms. To achieving MDG 3 requires a change for women. The project will both empower the participating female farmers via the program as well as include men in the process. Men from the individual households ( spouses, brothers or fathers) will be invited for demonstrations in the club demonstration gardens, for agriculture shows, for workshops together with the participating females on health, nutrition, budgeting and planning â€“ as well as for discussions on â€œgenderâ€ù issues in the families. ;The project activities will take all take their point of departure in the Clubs which will have 50 farmers in each. 50 members constitute a Club. 6 Clubs constitute a Cluster headed by 1 Farming Instructor. The Farming Instructor trains, instructs and ensures program implementation. Then proposed project will have 24 clubs and 4 Clusters. The 4 Clusters are headed and supervised by a Project Manage. Finally based at DAPP National Headquarter the Program Coordinator oversees the entire program, management and implementation. Each Club is the corner stone in the sustainability of the activities. Each Club chooses its own committee of 5 members.
sector-text: Agricultural Development

title: Wetlands Research
Tri-people Children Development Program
description: The focus is on children in 13 Indigenous People (IP) and Moro communities. Many are school drop outs because of poverty and the inability to access education. We facilitate access to the Conditional Cash Transfer (CCT) program of the government to increase education of the children. At the same time school buildings are expanded and the quality of education is enhanced by respect education;The aim of this project is to give children in the IP and Moro communities a better chance in life. Better access to education is facilitated by the use of the CCT program. The quality of education is improved by giving attention to better understanding between the different ethnic groups in the Respect lessons which include also a twinning component with the Day of Respect in Netherlands. The Respect methodology is also used in coaching the children and improving the learning outcomes. The shortage of classrooms is adressed by construction of schoolbuildings in remote areas;Target Groups: The direct target are 5000 children and 8000 families of 13 Moro and IP barangays in General Santos City and in Palimbang

title: Improving the sustainability of safe water, good hygiene and sanitation practices for rural communities in Malawi
description: This project will meet the need of rural Malawi communities for a clean, safe, reliable source of drinking water which is easily maintained by the households which will benefit from it. We will build, with community support, 1,500 Elephant (rope) Pumps (500 per annum) to provide a protected source of clean water to approximately 150,000 people who currently have no access to safe water supplies, and we will work with communities to embed good practice and increase sustainability.

title: Reduction of Maternal and Child Mortality and Morbidity in Haiti, through improving nutrition, hygiene and maternal and child health-seeking behaviour.
description: This project will improve nutrition, hygiene, and maternal and child health seeking behaviours among 793 pregnant women and 6,407 caregivers of children under five in Bellevue La Montagne and commune of Ken scoff in Haiti, thereby contributing to a reduction in the high maternal and under-five mortality and morbidity rates in these communities.
implementing_organisations: ;Food for the Hungry UK;Food for the Hungry Haiti

title: Livestock market development to alleviate poverty for Kenyan pastoralists and traders
description: The project will reduce poverty for 45,900 rural pastoralists and traders by improving livestock-based income generating opportunities in three markets in northern Kenya. This will take place through activities that will strengthen community management of livestock markets; increasing market vibrancy by linking traders, producers and bankers; and facilitating discussions within the community regarding optimum use of the market.
implementing_organisations: ;Food for the Hungry UK;Food for the Hungry Kenya

title: Reducing the Impact of Poverty on Maternal and Child Health by Improving Food Security and Access to Basic Health Services for 18,000 people in the Karnali Region of Western Nepal
description: This project will contribute to reducing maternal and child deaths within a total population of 18,000 living in poverty in the Karnali Region, West Nepal. Poor health is linked to malnutrition and lack of access to health services; we will improve access to nutritious foods and basic health services, specifically for mothers and children (but also everyone else in the community). Support to government health services, health education and work with womenâ€™s groups will ensure people have access to and use health services appropriately and attend early with treatable illness; preventative services will help reduce illness. Food security will be improved through seed and stock distribution, access to better stud goats and training for male and female farmers in animal fodder production, soil management, irrigation methods and vegetable / vegetable seed production.

title: Integrated Community Health, Education and Livelihood Programmes in Remote Himalayan Nepal (Gorkha, Humla, Bajura, Kabre and Sindhulpalchok)
description: PHASE Worldwide funds our partners organisation PHASE Nepal to run 16 primary health care centres, teacher training, alternative education programmes and training and skill development for farmer in 3 regions of remote Nepal

title: Improve access to, and quality of, antiretroviral treatment for HIV-positive children, adolescents and their families in Zambia and Zimbabwe
description: Improving access to, and quality of, antiretroviral treatment for HIV-positive children, adolescents and their families in Zambia and Zimbabwe through use of Expert Patients

title: GEARR (Girls Enrolment, Attendance, Retention and Results)
description: Through GEARR, PEAS will reach 6,200 marginalised girls in remote areas of Uganda. The project will focus on improving girls' access to quality secondary education and ensure their learning.

title: PROOFS
description: PROOFS stands for Profitable Opportunities for Food Security. The objective of the PROOFS project is to improve food security and prevent malnutrition for farmersâ€™ households in rural Bangladesh. PROOFSâ€™ has an innovative approach which includes small farmers, as well as retailers, traders, financial institutions and (local) government institutions. Farmers will be organized in competitive Farm Business Groups (or FBGs).

title: Improving maternal and child health services and livelihood opportunities for 37,280 poor women in two Districts of Uttar Pradesh, India
description: The project aims at improving maternal and child health outcomes of marginalised sections of population while contributing to poverty reduction at individual and household level. This will be achieved by strengthening community processes, institutions and health systems in facilitating women from marginalised sections for their improved access and inclusion in health and livelihood opportunities.

title: Agriculture Value Chains Team
description: The AVC team provides a high quality consulting service to leading edge market facilitation projects - helping their staff to learn faster, be more innovative and create deeper behaviour change in the market actors they are targeting.

title: Entreprenariat Rural Agricole
description: To promote the Family Farm Advisory Service (FFAS). FFAS is an approach to help farmers to manage strategically and financially their farm. Working with farmer-based organisations in Burkina Faso to design and implement a FFAS service that bring value to farmers while developing organisational systems and processes for the organisation overall. Developing several workshops, tools and a design process that allow our partners to develop a performing FFAS system.

title: GaRI - Governance and Rural Infrastructure
description: Focus on working within government offices in Ghanaâ€™s Northern region that are working with civil servants to develop the tools, processes and skills required to make evidence-based decisions and plans that ensure Ghanaâ€™s infrastructure continuously improves.
