Girls Education Challenge - Improving Girlsâ€™ Learning Outcomes
description: Led by Plan UK, The Open University is supporting 550 girls of senior secondary age and above in a scheme which prepares them for entry into teacher training, through a combination of self-supported study and experience in a primary school. Funded by UK aid funding through the Girls Education Challenge Programme, set up by the UK Government. Local partners include international and national NGOs and a teacher training college, through which the project reaches over 180 rural primary schools.

title: Mozambique Women's Intertidal Resource Management Project
description: Increasing income and savings of 540 of the most vulnerable women in coastal communities in Cabo Delgado Province northern Mozambique through incentivising intertidal resource management groups and introducing village savings and loans associations
sector-text: Women's equality organisations and institutions

title: Improving the productivity and environmental sustainability of farming systems for 1,000 women farmers in Ghana
description: The project will assist women subsistence farmers in Ghana to improve the sustainability of their farming systems and help them adapt to the impacts of climate change. The results will be increased productivity and incomes, as well as improved food and nutrition security for women farmers, their families and their communities. Their communities will benefit further from long term availability of forest resources and increased access to potable water.
sector-text: We are helping women farmers increase their food crop production through training in organic farming and agroforestry and increased crop diversity and improved productivity to increase productivity ;We are training the women farmers in climate change adaptation, organic farming and agroforestry;We are educating the women about climate change impacts, mitigation and adaptation so they can be better prepared and adapt their farming systems to the impacts;We are providing rural marginalised communities with boreholes for a sustainable supply of potable water

title: IMPROVING MATERNAL HEALTH AND REDUCING CHILD MORTALITY THROUGH DEVELOPING HEALTH SERVICE DELIVERY FOR THE POOR AND MARGINALISED COMMUNITY OF BAGHBANAN, NORTH WEST PAKISTAN
description: The project will significantly extend the range of health care sevice provision at Baghbanan HC for approximately 29,800 women, men, girls and boys from Baghbanan community. This will improve their health status and contribute to achieving MDG4 and MDG5 in this poor and marginalised population with limited access to affordable primary health care. Staff and local health care providers will be recruited locally and trained, thus building capacity for a sustainable future.

title: END AIDS Portal
description: The End AIDS portal is an innovative project that responds to the acute shortage of health personnel in most health centres delivering ARVs. It also provides an opportunity for people who are not free to seek medical advice from health service providers to ask this same kind of information in the comfort of their homes or any other place without their identity being known. The End AIDS Portal is a web based intervention that uses cell phones to access health information anonymously. The resource is run for and by people living with HIV. It uses text messages to reach out to people living with HIV and the affected who are marginalised and lack safe access to support and services such as sex workers or men who have sex with men without exposing them to stigma and discrimination or even prosecution. So far, the portal has demonstrated potential in filling the information and service delivery gaps that currently exist in health facilities.
sector-text: Health Education

title: sustainable natural resource manangement in the Albertine Rift area - Hoima
description: Empowering communities for sustainable natural resource manangement in the Albertine Rift area - Hoima ;Empowering communities for sustainable natural resource manangement in the Albertine Rift area - Hoima

title: Capacity Building of the Pamir Times Network
description: Pakistan is part of PF 2.0. The programme aims for capacity building in rural reporting, empowering women reporters and strengthening reporting on religious and current affairs. Pamir Times (PT; www.pamirtimes.net) is the only semi-professional news website serving the greater Pamir region (primarily Gilgit-Baltistan in northern Pakistan, but with correspondents and an audience in Afghanistan and Tajikistan, and a mandate to include the Chinese Pamiri areas, also). PT has proved to be successful in the region and beyond, attracting over 3 million hits since 2007. A self-financed network, PT is composed exclusively of amateur volunteers, numbering approximately 25. Pamir Times lacks the resources to further develop its institutional capacity. FPU will offer support to PT along four primary themes, in addition to the formative equipment support extended in late 2011/early 2012: professionalization and institutional formalization of PT; formal training and further equipment support for correspondents network; digital protection and backup; minority/indigenous language reporting.

title: Teen Voice (KNN Indonesia)
description: Create news program for teens: News expands from teen issues such as education to topics such as corruption, in which teens can voice their opinions from their perspectives. Seeing and hearing their peers voice opinions will stimulate the target audience to form and voice their own opinions. This will enhance teenager's confidence to, for example, they can be braver to speak in public. In the long term, it is expected that teens will develop sensitivity to problems of their daily life. This sensitivity is combined with the ability to express themselves openly, orally or in writing. Confidence to express themselves in such young age will build strong foundation for dialogues useful in their adult years. Through tailor-made training from the Kids News Network, the editorial team will produce high quality, independent and balanced kids news episodes.

title: Support the strategic planning of Ziarul de Garda
description: ZdG was established in 2004 as an investigative journalism newspaper in Moldova. It appeared in a complicate political situation, as well in a hard economical while, with state monopoly for national distribution of newspapers and with high prices for printing. Due the fact that Ziarul de Garda publishes weekly stories on corruption and human rights, putting critical opinions on Government members, the paper has very small access to advertisement and means â€“ to alternative sources of income, due the fact that business was always politically controlled or politically oriented. The project took place in the situation while the Ziarul de Garda newspaper was in need to improve its management and become sustainable.

title: TNN Operational Grant I
description: Tribal News Network (TNN) aims to provide fair, balanced and independent news to the people of Pakistanâ€™s tribal areas through partner FM radio stations in the dominant local language, Pushto. Radio has grown rapidly in Pakistan in recent years. Local audiences in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province and in the remote Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) now have many entertainment channels to listen to, with lots of music and chat shows, but audiences also want radio stations to broadcast news and information about important events in their community. In FATA and KP, however, local radio still provides very little news reporting. As a result, the people of the tribal areas depend on foreign radio services for information on local events because no independent media outlet is providing this local news for radio broadcast. The growth of private television stations has benefited many people in Pakistan but in the tribal areas cable television is often not available. Being a conservative area, local people often consider television to be inappropriate and because of widespread illiteracy, especially among women, many people cannot read newspapers, so radio has long been the most popular medium for news and information in Pashto-speaking areas. Tribal News Network hasÂ been created to meet the needs of people in FATA and KP who want reliable news about their communities. ;The general objectives of TNN are as follows: * To provide fair, balanced and independent news to audiences in Pushto-speaking areas. * To provide local news to underserved areas. * To empower local citizens by providing information on social and political issues. * To provide female audiences in particular with access to information, as women often lack other means of access to information. * To encourage more women to work in journalism to improve content for female audiences. * To help integrate the 50% of KP-FATAÂ´s population who are illiterate into mainstream society by providing essential information. Objectives of TNN with this one-year operational grant are the following: * TNN is operating as a professional organisation broadcasting local radio news items and with a clear plan for the future. * TNNÂ´s network of radio partners is increased to at least 10 stations. * The local population is better informed and able to understand events in their community based on independent news information provided by TNN, thus enabling them to make sensible political and life decisions.;* Tribal News Network * Local audiences of TNN\'s local radio partner stations in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province and in the remote Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA)

title: WADADA News for Kids - PROMEDIA
description: This project is relevant because it fills a gap in the supply of information to children and youth in Nicaragua. This age group is targeted by the media with consumption goods and entertainment. They are hardly ever targeted as potential active agents of change. The proposed project aims to increase the access of children and youth to relevant news and current affairs, to inform them about their rights and spark their sense of citizenship. FPU develops independent media channels: media in Nicaragua is torn between government propaganda and commercial considerations and programming. Even public television is at the service of the political party ruling the country. Most media outlets are dedicated to repeating official propaganda, or air-brushing reality, to create the illusion of the country as utopia. A few independent outlets remain. Only DHTV is aimed at children and youth. In terms of audience, Furthermore this new project is relevant because it will, next to contributing to the production of De Humo, also have a strong focus on the sustainability of the news program. They are on the right track but need more time to explore and roll out different options. The sustainability of De Humo will contribute to the KNN network. In addition, PROMEDIA is a private production company which considers itself to have a watch dog function in society. Given the strong influence of the state and business world on media in Nicaragua, a partner with this profile is the only guarantee for editorial independence. ;Nicaragua is a country â€œoverflowing with youthâ€ù; over one third is aged 14 or under. The potential audience for the proposed project is over two million children. ;To promote the rights of children and youth, educating a new generation into becoming informed, active citizens. To achieve sustainability and expand sources of income beyond the support of FPU.

title: WADADA News for Kids - NICOBIS
description: The Bolivian media enviroment is dominated by private ownership, although recent years show an increase in state-owned media. Bolivia\\\\\\\'s television landscape is characterized by scarcity in terms of quality children\\\\\\\'s programming. Very little good and relevant information is available on TV and online which encourages children, teenagers and young people to actively participate in society. Internet access is increasing thourghout the country, but few websites provide the target group with relevant and at the same time entertaining information. Television programming for minorities is in development; in 2012, ATB, a national commercial channel and host of PICA, launched a daily news programme in Quechua, one of Bolivia\\\\\\\'s native languages. Mis- and underrepresentation of vulnerable groups in the media is a global and endemic phenomenon. FPU is part of the Child Rights Alliance (CRA) lead by Plan Netherlands. The CRA focuses on improving the lives of girls and young women in developing countries. Project partner Nicobis believes that a KNN programme in Bolivia will contribute to this aim because the television programmes can raise awareness on the social inequality in gender and the ethnical exclusion in children and young people. The children and young people can speak with their own voices about the poverty, socio-cultural diversity, segregation, asymmetrical relations in education and healthcare, differences in access to goods and services, stereotypes and stigmatisation based on relationships of superiority and power. KNN News shows the discrimination against children and youngers in both rural and urban areas, but also show their contribution in many areas of the families life.;Main objective: To give children, youth and women a voice and to involve them in shaping their future, by supporting media organization Nicobis to improve the quality, availability and accessibility of independent, fair and complete information for children, youth and women. Specific objectives: Make available to children and youth (13-16 years old) a television programme and website with quality information and news relevant to them. Enabling children and youth to participate as producers of information that is relevant to them. Improve the journalistic quality and distribution of childrenÂ´s news programmes in Bolivia. ;children and youth (13-16 years old)

title: Increasing successful family and community reintegration for 110 women and child survivors of human rights abuses in Cambodia
description: This project assists women and children from backgrounds of extreme human rights abuse towards safe re-integration into their family and/or community. This involves piloting provincial-based case management and counselling services to build the protective factors that contribute to an individualâ€™s stability and empowerment, developing referral systems to local services and resources.

title: Partnership Monitoring Evaluation and Learning Project (PMEL)
description: Partnership management evaluation and learning services to the Government of Sierra Leone\'s IRMNH programme

title: Educating Nigerian Girls In New Enterprises
description: This project is a collaboration between UKâ€™s Department for International Development (DFID) Girlsâ€™ Education Challenge (GEC) and The Coca-Cola Export Corporation. It seeks to improve learning outcomes and the economic status of marginalised adolescent girls in various states across Nigeria.

title: Improve the quality of life and opportunities for young rural Ethiopians with cleft conditions by providing access to free treatment and building the patient referral skills of local health workers.
description: The project will enable 540 young people in the Somali region, one of the poorest regions in Ethiopia, to reach free treatment for cleft conditions, enabling them to eat, speak and breathe and to participate in community life. It will also build the skills of 150 local health workers in identifying cleft conditions and referring patients for treatment, and will facilitate the expansion of free cleft treatment to a local hospital â€“ making access to treatment easier for many more young Ethiopians.
sector-text: Access to free treatment for cleft conditions;Building health understanding of facial disabilities (particularly cleft conditions) as well as patient referral skills of local health workers

title: Typhoon Haiyan
description: Typhoon Haiyan (locally known as Yolanda) made landfall on 8 November 2013 with maximum sustained winds of 235 kph and gusts of up to 275 kph. The typhoon and subsequent storm surges have resulted in extensive damage to infrastructure, making access a challenge. Over two million families (9.67 million people) across 41 provinces were affected.;The Red Cross supports the survivors of Haiyan to survive and cope with their losses. We aim to prevent further losses of live and livelihoods and the outbreak of epidemics.;The Red Cross distributes food, shelter materials, cooking equipment, hygiene supplies and cash. Families are assisted to find relatives that have gone missing in the disaster. The Red Cross offers psychosocial support, provides water and sanitation facilities and supports families to rebuild their livelihoods.;The emergency operation is targeting families and individuals affected by the Haiyan typhoon, based on their basic needs.;Although Tacloban City, in the province of Leyte, is the hardest hit, the effects of Haiyan have been hard on other areas such as Guiuan in Eastern Samar, where it had made the first landfall, the northern tip of Cebu and Bantayan Island. Other affected areas include but are not limited to the provinces of Northern Samar, Samar, Southern Leyte, Bohol, Negros Occidental, Guimaras, Masbate, Biliran, Capiz, Aklan, Antique, Palawan and Romblon.
sector-text: ;;Disaster type;Project type

title: Partners for Resilience
description: People world-wide live in disaster-prone areas. Disasters damage the eco-systems they live in and upon which their livelihoods depend. Their vulnerability to disasters is aggrevated by climate change, which increases the frequency, scale and inpredictability of disasters. Eco-systems, if protected and managed well, can play an important role in mitigating the impact of disasters (holding more excess water, sheltering form storms, ...). ;' ... ' ;We help communities to use eco-systems better for protection from disasters and to support their livelihoods. We provide information on climate change and disaster risk reduction and assist communities to organise themselves and develop disaster risk and mitigation plans. We advocate with governments to support communities with appropriate legislation and action (more resources for risk reduction; stop environment degradation).;We work with vulnerable communities in disaster-prone conditions.;This programme is carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Mali, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, Uganda, Nicaragua and Guatemala, in disaster-prone areas.

title: Kepa's programme for 2013-2015
description: Kepa is an NGO platform and an expert on global development. At the moment Kepa has more than 300 member organisations, ranging from small voluntary-based organisations to major national organisations. Kepa\'s main objective for the 2013-2015 are: 1) Along with its member organisations, Kepa influences political decision-making for eliminating poverty and inequality 2) In their common work, Kepa and its member organisations raise public awareness and increase public activity for a just world 3) Kepa builds capacity of its member organisations. The fourth main component of the programme consist of leadership, management and support functions. Through country and regional offices in Mekong, Mozambique, Nicaragua and Tanzania Kepa has extensive contacts with Southern civil society actors. Kepa aims to strengthen Southern civil societies by supporting civil society actorsâ€™ competencies in advocacy themes and in the promotion of enabling operating environment as well as by supporting cooperation and networking at the national, regional and global levels. Cooperation with Southern civil society organisations (CSOs) provides Kepa with expertise, personal experiences and credibility.

title: Kepa and its members influence political decision-making for eliminating poverty and inequality
description: Kepa influences the political decision-making in Finland, focusing especially on the quantity and quality of development cooperation, global economic policy and climate justice. Kepa\'s aim is that: 1) Development cooperation receives sufficient resources that are put to effective and optimal use, 2) Economic policy is fair. Fair economic policy means putting an end to tax evasion and avoidance, taxing the financial markets, corporate responsibility, tackling developing country debt, and fair terms for international trade, 3) The international community shares responsibility for mitigating climate change and adapting to it fairly and democratically. Each of Kepa\'s country and regional offices work on at least two advocacy themes and, within these themes, seek medium to long-term cooperation with two to four strategically selected civil society partners. These partnerships are be based on joint objectives and designed to benefit both Kepa and the Southern partner. The Southern partners are committed and courageous advocacy actors working with links to local, national and regional/global level. Southern realities and experiences form the basis for Kepa\'s advocacy messages. Contacts and dialogue with Southern CSOs working on the same policy themes as Kepa brings credibility and effectiveness to Kepa\'s advocacy work. Cooperation with Southern CSOs engaged in advocacy towards the same policy objectives as Kepa, creates opportunities to join forces in order to influence global processes, often in the context of international CSO networks. Kepa offers the Southern CSO partners expertise and topical information on advocacy themes as well as support in networking on national, regional and global levels.

title: Kepa and its members influence public opinion in Finland
description: Kepa brings together CSOs and active citizens in Finland to take part in public debate and to highlight issues of global responsibility. Kepa\'s aim is to act as a platform that organisations can use in their own awareness raising and advocacy work. Main activities to influence public opinion are the World Village Festival, support and networking of local organisers of the Markets of Possibilities events, supporting the cooperation of actors of global education, Globbarit network and campaigning and ETVO Volunteer Programme. Training and communication work are included in all these activities. In addition Kepa Kepa provides journalistic information, backgrounds and viewpoints that other media is not offering through Kepa.fi news production, Maailman Kuvalehti magazine and social media.

title: Kepa strengthens the capacities of its member organisations
description: Kepa wants to highlight civil society\\\'s diverse functions in promoting a just world. The learning and enabling environment of Finnish CSOs are promoted so that they will be able to realise their full potential and various functions as civil society actors as well as support their Southern partners to realise their potential and functions in their own contexts. Kepa pilots partnerships with Southern CSOs and networks that strengthen, coordinate and represent civil society. The partnerships will provide information and subjective experience about the strengthening of civil society actors in the South. Kepa will support the Southern partners in their work to strengthen the civil society and promoting the different roles of civil society in their respective societies. Kepa will support its partners by proving links to global discussions on and actors in civil society debate and CSO effectiveness processes. The main activities to strengthen the capacities of member organisations are member relations and communication, open and tailored training and learning processes, advise and looking after members\' interests.

title: Kepa's leadership, management and support functions
description: Kepaâ€™s headquarters are in Helsinki, Finland. Kepa also has offices in Mozambique, Nicaragua, Tanzania and the Mekong region of Southeast Asia. In Finland, Kepa has a staff of approximately 50 persons and in country and regional offices around 30 persons. Leadership, management and support functions aim to ensure and enable the smooth internal functioning and effective performance of Kepa\'s organisation in order to reach the organisational objectives. The support functions include offices, general and final administration, human recourses management and information management. Leadership, management and support functions are guided by Kepa\'s operational values â€“ responsibility, openness and courage â€“ as well as by the Istanbul principles (especially transparency, accountability and sustainability).

title: Improving diagnosis, treatment and care for children with cancer in Myanmar
description: World Child Cancer UK's project will reduce poverty and work towards the achievement of MDGs 1, 4 and 6 in improving diagnosis, treatment and care for children with cancer in Myanmar by building capacity through a twinning partnership between Yangon Children's Hospital and hospitals in the UK and USA - Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.
implementing_organisations: ;Yangon Children's Hospital;Guy's & St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust;Dana-Farber Cancer Institute

title: To save lives of conflict affected and IDP's through health and nutrition intervention
description: Short description: To improve the health and nutrition status among of the IDP population, particularly children and women, in Kandahar Detailed description: The action will increase access to health services by establishing mobile health teams and health posts, increase access to food for food insecure households via provision of cash transfers and engaging communities in cash for work, and improve the understanding of malnutrition and people's access to food. R1: SC will hold orientation sessions with community representatives and conduct a situation analysis with the support of the Public Health Directorate to identify areas where MHTs and the OTP will operate. A MHT will be staffed with one male health provider (doctor or nurse), one female health provider (doctor, community midwife or female nurse), one vaccinator and one driver. Mobile health staff will receive initial training and refresher and on the job trainings. Each MHT will establish a service delivery point in the community and will work approx. 20 days a month. The package of services provided by MHTs will be based on the BPHS guide for MHT. MHTs will refer more serious cases to primary health facilities. Community Health Workers (CHWs) will be trained by Community Mobilisers and Health Posts will be established, supervised, and supplied by AHDS (local partner) and the mobile team. After initial training, the MHTs and Community Health Supervisors (CHSs) of the nearest health facility will be responsible for conducting supportive supervision, collecting reports, provision of on the job training and re-supplying. In addition, the Community Mobilisers will be responsible for holding sessions with the IDP population to educate communities, and particularly women and caregivers, on breastfeeding, hygiene sanitation, diarrhea, acute respiratory illness, and vaccinations. Routine MoPH monitoring and supervision tools will be used for reporting. A quarterly schedule for monitoring visits will be prepared in advance. As per MoPH regulations, each MHT will be assigned a code to link it with the HMIS and GPS system. R2: Acute food deficit families will be identified from amongst the displaced food insecure families in collaboration with UNHCR and with support of the community according to the beneficiary selection criteria. Conditional cash transfers will be made to 1000 highly vulnerable households for an initial three months at the rate of $40/month/HH. Beneficiaries will attend five training session each month on health, nutrition and hygiene education - these sessions will be followed up by community mobilizers. Another 500 highly vulnerable HHs suffering from acute food deficit will be facilitated to identify appropriate cash for work according to their need. They will receive a cash transfer $60/month/HH for 3 months. R3:SC will conduct a SMART nutrition survey to assess the nutritional status of children 6 to 59 months and estimate retrospective mortality rates in the IDP communities in Kandahar province. SC will expand its existing Community Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) programme by establishing one additional OTP in an IDP location. Children with severe acute malnutrition but no medical complications are treated through an OTP that provides ready-to-use therapeutic food and treatment of common illnesses. These OTP services are set up in partnership with BPHS health facility staff and will be established within a MHT. Children with moderate acute malnutrition will be referred to a supplementary feeding programme implemented by AHDS with the support of WFP. Education sessions for caregivers will raise awareness on infant feeding, hygiene and hand washing practices. CHWs will be trained in case finding referral of acutely malnourished children using mid upper arm circumference (MUAC) and follow up. In addition to the proposed action in Kandahar, SC will work with NRC to deliver a Household Economy Approach (HEA) for one food economy zone in the north of Afghanistan, covering Saripul, Southern Balkh and Samangan.;The action will deliver an integrated approach to address the humanitarian needs of displaced populations in Kandahar. The action will increase access to health services by establishing mobile health teams and health posts, increase access to food for food insecure households via provision of cash transfers and engaging communities in cash for work, and improve the understanding of malnutrition and people's access to food.;The beneficiary target group are IDPs. In Kandahar, IDPs have been primarily displaced from within Kandahar or surrounding provinces (Helmand, Uruzgan) due to conflict. A smaller number are displaced by natural disasters, or due to economic hardships. ;De dorre provincie Kandahar is een van Afghanistan's grootste en minst bevolkte provincies. Het deelt een poreuze internationale grens met het Balochistan district in Pakistan. Kandahar heeft een bevolking van 990.100, waarvan 68% in de rurale districten woont die gekenmerkt worden door een hoog niveau van armoede en conflict. Kandahaar is zeer ontvankelijk voor conflict en onveiligheid wat de grootste veroorzakers van humanitaire noden blijven. De provincie wordt als een van de hoogste, waar het gaat om aantal gerapporteerde veiligheidsincidenten en open conflicten, gerangschikt. Doelgerichte moorden, bezetting van de gezondheids en onderwijs infrastructuur, intimidatie en onrust hebben geleid tot ontheemding, burger slachtoffers, de onderbreking van basisdiensten of het onvermogen van mensen om toegang tot diensten te hebben. Bescherming van burgers is een grote zorg. Ondanks bijvoorbeeld ICRC's taxi diensten die vervoer zonder medische ondersteuning naar het ziekenhuis verzorgen, is er nog steeds een significant gebrek aan medische voorzieningen voor slachtoffers van het conflict. Het gebrek aan zulke diensten vertaalt zich direct in toegenomen sterftecijfers met name onder burgers. Tevens heeft Kandahar een groot aantal ontheemden. Volgens schattingen van UNHCR zijn er 40.257 ontheemden Kandahar-stad en 5.250 in Daman. De IDP en vluchtelingen autoriteit in Spin Boldak schat dat er 19.481 ontheemden in het district zijn. Hoewel er geen informatie is over de toestroom van ontheemden als gevolg van het conflict in de periode 2011 - 2013 wordt er verwacht dat als gevolg van het verwachte oplaaiende conflict in Kandahar de toestroom van ontheemden zal toenemen. UNHCR schat dat, de komende 12 maanden, 2-3,000 huishoudens zullen vluchten naar Kandahar, afkomstig uit Kandahar, Helmand en Uruzgan. Provinciala data laten zien dat Kandahar de provincie is met het hoogste aantal gevallen van diarree, zware verkoudheid en zware oor, neus en keelontstekingen. In 2013 waren er 13 uitbraken van cholera en de mazelen. Verder blijkt uit de informatie uit de focus groep discussies dat er ernstige beperkingen in de toegang tot medische diensten zijn. De gemiddelde afstand tot de dichtstbijzijndste gezondheidsfaciliteit is 1,5 uur lopen. Vooral vrouwen worden hierdoor beperkt omdat zij deze afstand om culturele redenen niet alleen kunnen lopen. Een ambulance of ander transport zijn niet beschikbaar bij de medische faciliteiten en de kosten om ander zelf transport te organiseren zijn niet op te brengen door de ontheemden. Tevens is de kwaliteit van de diensten zeer slecht door een gebrek aan adequaat personeel, lange wachttijden, het gebrek aan medische apparatuur en medicijnen. Tevens is ondervoeding een groot probleem voor de kindergezondheid in Afghanistan. Bij een screening van 219,796 kinderen onder de 5 in Kandahar en districten werden er 13,722 gevallen van ondervoeding en 3,891gevallen van zware ondervoeding geregistreerd. Dit is onder de WHO drempel, maar recente data van het SC DFATD gefinancierde project survey baseline rapport, uitgevoerd in 2013, geeft aan dat net iets meer dan een derde van de moeders in Kandahar gewone groei monitoring rapporteerde en tweederde van de gemeenschaps gezondheidswerkers rapporteerde dat ze niet wisten hoe ze een diagnose van zware ondervoeding moesten vaststellen of behandelen. Deze informatie is verergerd door de onofficiÃ«le resultaten van de NNS (Nationale voedingssurvey) die een percentage van 5.7% aangaf voor de provincie. Daarbij genomen, de lagere weerbaarheid van ontheemden en het gebrek aan toegang tot gezondheidsdiensten, doet verwachten dat de ondervoedingscijfers in werkelijkheid hoger liggen. De rapid assessment die gedaan is door SC in December geeft duidelijk aan dat een gebrek aan dieet diversiteit en calorie-opname de onderliggende oorzaken zijn. De resultaten van de geÃ¯nterviewde huishoudens laten zien dat 75% van de ontheemden niet in staat is om de nodige energie behoefte te behalen en 63% is niet in staat de helft van de minimale voedselinname te behalen (2100 kcal). Minder dan een derde van de hushoudens consumeerde slechts vier van de zeven essentiÃ«le voedsel groepen en het gemiddelde huishouden verdient 4,096 Afghanis per maand- ruim beneden de overheids armoede grens. Deze groep besteed meer dan 70% van het huishouden inkomen aan voedsel. ;Het verstrekken van levensreddende hulp aan ontheemden en de lokale bevolking en het verbeteren van de gezondheids en voedingsstatus van deze doelgroep, in het bijzonder kinderen en vrouwen, in Kandahar.;De begunstigden van dit project zijn 67.580 mensen (51% man/49% vrouw) zowel ontheemden als de lokale bevolking.

title: Verbeterde vaardigheden van jongeren ter vergroting kansen op de arbeidsmarkt
description: Hoewel de Chinese economie snel groeit de laatste 30 jaar, leven 128 miljoen Chinezen nog steeds in absolute armoede volgens de door de Wereldbank gedefinieerde standaard van 1,25 dollar per dag. Het belang van onderwijs in het tegengaan van de vicieuze cirkel van armoede van de ene generatie op de andere is breed erkend door de Chinese overheid. Sinds 2005 zijn het aantal onderwijsinschrijvingen significant toegenomen, maar in de arme en afgelegen rurale gebieden blijven er problemen op het gebied van onderwijskwaliteit. De provincie Yunnan ligt in het Zuidwesten van China en heeft 46.31 miljoen inwoners en is China's op 3 na armste regio. In deze provincie is lage kwaliteit van het onderwijs Ã©Ã©n van de grootste oorzaken van ongelijkheid en armoede, met toenemende ongelijkheden in de inzetbaarheid van jeugd tussen rurale en stedelijke gebieden. Tevens is 10-15 % van de bevolking analfabeet (Na Tibet, de provincie met het hoogste niveau van analfabetisme). Daarnaast is Yunnan multi-etnisch met een bevolking bestaande uit 51 verschillende etniciteiten. Deze multi-etniciteit zorgt voor barriÃ¨res in het onderwijs systeem, vooral in het basisonderwijs. Dit komt, omdat kinderen les krijgen in het Mandarijn (Chinees) wat voor vele scholieren niet hun moedertaal is. Hoewel de instroom onder etnische gemeenschappen hoog is in de eerste jaren, vallen er een hoop scholieren af door een slechte beheersing van het Mandarijn wat als communicatiemedium wordt gebruikt. De lage onderwijskwaliteit in Yunnan is (verder) te wijten aan de capaciteit van leraren. Deze zijn namelijk niet in staat om in te spelen op de behoeften van kinderen, omdat in meeste gevallen: I) ze niet bevoegd zijn: 2) onvoldoende training hebben gehad voorafgaand aan hun dienstverband; 3) Er weinig tot geen trainingsmogelijkheden zijn tijdens het dienstverband. Dit zorgt voor verouderde leerpraktijken in scholen en activiteiten planningen die, de specifieke behoeften voor wat betreft vaardigheden die de professionele en individuele ontwikkeling van middelbare scholieren zou vergroten, niet in ogenschouw nemen. Het gevolg hiervan is dat kinderen vaak slagen met weinig direct toepasbare vaardigheden en met een basiskennis die de realiteit van het leven in hun gemeenschappen niet weerspiegelt. Slechts enkele kinderen hebben de economische mogelijkheid of steun vanuit familie om door te stromen naar hoger onderwijs of beroepsonderwijs na het voltooien van het voortgezet onderwijs. Dit komt niet alleen door armoede, maar ook door het geringe vertrouwen in onderwijs en toekomstperspectieven. Veel kinderen komen relatief vroeg in aanraking met een leven van volwassenen met alle gevolgen van dien. Door gebrek aan vaardigheden en geletterdheid lopen ze een groter gevaar om in aanraking te komen met mensenhandel, HIV/aids uitbuiting en mishandeling. Daarnaast hebben veel van hen een slecht betaalde baan waarin ze ook uitgebuit worden of raken ze werkeloos. De provincies Yunnan en Guizhou zijn de voornaamste bron provincies voor mensenhandel terwijl Fuijan, Guangdong en Shangdong (de rijkere provincies) de bestemmingen zijn van de binnenlandse mensenhandel. Daarnaast vindt er binnen Yunnan ook veel intra provinciale mensenhandel plaats. De meeste slachtoffers in Yunnan zijn jonge vrouwen die verkocht worden als bruiden aan mannen in meer geÃ¯soleerde gebieden. Dit komt, omdat deze mannen in rurale gebieden de bruidsschat die een formeel huwelijk vereist, niet kunnen betalen. De mensenhandelaar voorziet deze mannen zo van een veel goedkopere bruid. Tevens worden er veel mensen vanuit Yunnan gesmokkeld naar Thailand. En, omdat jonge vrouwen traditioneel minder onderwezen worden dan jongens is deze groep extra kwetsbaar voor uitbuiting. ;Door middel van kennis en vaardigheden jeugd in staat stellen hun levensvooruitzichten te verbeteren en toegang tot een betere toekomst bieden;2000 kinderen met een leeftijd van 11-18 jaar en 360 docenten van 5 scholen in twee rurale en etnische minderheid provincies. Indirecte begunstigden: 4000 ouders/verzorgers.;Although Chinaâ€™s economy has been growing at a fast pace for the last 30 years, 128 million Chinese still live in absolute poverty according to the World Bank standard of $1.25 per day. The importance of education in stopping the cycle of poverty from one generation to the next has been widely recognised by the Chinese government who in 1986 universalised nine-year compulsory education. Since 2005, when the policy was actually implemented at local level, then, enrolment in compulsory education has dramatically increased, but issues remain especially in terms of quality of education in poor remote rural areas. Yunnan province is located in Southwest part of China, with a population of 46.31 million, is ranked third among Chinaâ€™s poorest regions. Here, poor quality of education has become one of the biggest drivers of inequality and poverty, with increasing disparities in employability of youth between rural and urban areas. In Yunnan, teachers are not able to respond to the needs of children as in most cases: 1) they are not qualified; 2) have had inadequate pre-service trainings; 3) in-services training opportunities are rare or non-existent. This translates into obsolete teaching practice in schools and activity plans which donâ€™t take into account the specific needs in terms of hard and soft skills that would benefit the professional and individual development of middle school students. As a result, children often graduate with few directly applicable skills, as well as a knowledge base that does not reflect the realities of life in their communities. Only few children have the economic possibility or family support to continue into high school education or vocational schools after completing compulsory education. This is not only due to poverty, but also little trust in education and prospective for the future. Children therefore tend to step into an adult life at a young age and their lack of skills and literacy, places them at greater risk of harm from trafficking, HIV, conflict with the law and other forms of exploitation and abuse. Many end up either unemployed or exploited in low-paying labour intensive jobs, excluded from urban opportunities throughout their lives and locked in a self-perpetuating situation.;The goal of the project is to empower youth with knowledge and skills they need to improve their life prospects and have access to a better future. ;Direct beneficiaries after year 1: 2,000 children aged 11-18 and 360 teachers from 6 schools in two rural and ethnic minority counties. Indirect beneficiaries: 4,000 caregivers Over three years, we could reach 6,000 children aged 11-18 in 10 schools.

title: Increased basic service delivery and socioeconomic empowerment of women and youth in Afghanistan & Pakistan, a future for the next generation
description: Het voorgestelde programma richt zich op het bewerkstelligen van synergie tussen capaciteitsversterking, economische ontwikkeling, en vredesopbouw. Dit draagt bij aan het verbeteren van de veiligheid van de burgers in Afghanistan en Pakistan. Save the Children is al geruime tijd actief in zowel Afghanistan en Pakistan en heeft de afgelopen jaren in beide landen veel geÃ¯nvesteerd in de uitvoeringscapaciteit van omvangrijke meerjarenprogramma\'s. In het bijzonder legt Save the Children zich toe op het creÃ«ren van betere toekomstperspectieven van kinderen in moeilijke omstandigheden door het verlenen van directe hulp en hulp gericht op de naaste omgeving van kinderen. In Afghanistan heeft SCNL zich de afgelopen jaren voornamelijk beziggehouden met het thema onderwijs en wel voor jongens en meisjes die niet of nauwelijks toegang hadden tot het basis onderwijs. Scholing werden dichterbij aangeleverd in de verschillende gemeenschappen - ook door community participatie, en ook werd er door het Accelerated Learning (AL) voor aansluiting gezorgd bij het reguliere basisonderwijs. Ook werd er aandacht besteed aan de bouw en inrichting van scholen, en beurzen voor huidige en toekomstige onderwijzenden (toegang, kwaliteit). Daarnaast is er aandacht voor de bevordering van kinderrechten en het bieden van vakonderwijs aan werkende kinderen, investering in counseling en behandeling van drugsverslaafden (vnl opium). In Pakistan heeft SCNL zich voornamelijk bezig gehouden met noodhulp en wederopbouw (ten gevolge van overstromingen en aardbeving), als ook in de twee huidige programma\'s op het thema onderwijs. In het district Baluchistan wordt op dit moment het Baluchistan Education Programme uitgevoerd, wat zich sterk maakt voor toegang tot (inclusief ECE) en kwaliteit van basisonderwijs en hoger onderwijs in 3 districten, planning van onderwijs systemen en budgetering door de overheid, en bevorderen van gezondheid & hygiene op alle 340 scholen in het programma (73,000 kinderen). Door de onveiligheid en weersomstandigheden heeft de bouw van de scholen vertraging opgelopen, maar andere delen van het programma, waaronder ook conflict management, hebben wel plaatsgevonden. Zes maanden geleden is het Programme Establishing Partnership and Stability (PEPAS) van start gegaan in het noordelijke district Battagram, die zicht richt op basis en middelbaar onderwijs (toegang en kwaliteit), inclusief onderdeel voor madrassas, in 260 scholen, met daarnaast ook een livelihood (verbeterde omstandigheden in levensonderhoud voor 300 jongeren) en advocacy component. Het is verwacht dat de onderwijs en livelihood componenten zullen bijdragen aan vrede en veiligheid in het district. In zowel Afghanistan en Pakistan is de huidige situatie in de verschillende provincies niet stabiel. Voor beiden geldt dat conflicten over grenzen, grondgebieden, en natuurlijke bronnen (schaarse bronnen) en ten tweede gebrek aan governance in lokale en nationale overheidsstructuren. Onveiligheid door aanslagen of door sectorial killings, dan wel ontvoeringen hebben en blijven van invloed op het uitvoeren van de programma activiteiten. Daarnaast zijn het vertrek van troepen uit en minder beschikbare fondsen in Afghanistan van invloed op de algehele stabiliteit. In Pakistan is de onveiligheid in vnl de grensgebieden met Afghanistan (FATA areas) en ook in het westen (Baluchistan) groot, en in de aanloop op de verkiezingen in 2012 worden deze niet minder. De grensgebieden worden ook wel \'\'cash insecure regions\'\' genoemd, door gebrek aan land voor landbouwgebruik, gebrek aan industrien en gebrek aan werkgelegenheid. ;Doel van het programma is om de kennis en de capaciteit van overheidsfunctionarissen te versterken wat bijdraagt aan een betere dienstverlening van de overheid. Daarnaast beoogt het programma jongeren en vrouwen in staat te stellen deel te nemen aan de sociale en economische ontwikkeling van Afghanistan en Pakistan. Door zich in te zetten op het verbeteren van de zwakke structuren in de gemeenschappen, dan wel die van de overheidsorganen kan de onveiligheid verminderen. Door het blijven implementeren van onderwijs en ook andere thematische projecten beoogd SC dat deze bijdragen aan stabiliteit en veiligheid in de gemeenschappen. Activiteiten zoals inkomensverbetering en vakonderwijs, specifiek voor vrouwen en jongeren zullen hieraan bijdragen. Ook capaciteitsopbouw van lokale overheden zal een kwaliteitsverbetering teweegbrengen in het bieden van basic services. Daarnaast zullen door het organiseren van cross border workshops voor overheidsfunctionarissen, geleerde lessen gedeeld worden. ;Social empowerment van vrouwen en jongeren door het opstarten van income generation activities, het verzorgen van trainingen om de duurzaamheid van het voorgaande te vergroten en de mogelijkheid te bieden aan vrouwen en jongeren om samen te werken als groep, en om zodanig hun eigen economische situatie te verbeteren. Uit lessons learned van een recente evaluatie, wordt ook meegenomen dat duurzaamheid vooral wordt verkregen door langere trainings periodes in te bouwen, zich met name richten op vrouwen, en zich specifiek te richten op communities. daarnaast is het van belanfg om lokale overheden nauw te betrekken en ook deel te laten nemen aan markt surveys, basline surveys, ontwikkeling van duurzame livelihoods en income generating activities, en best practices voor voedselzekerheid en livelihood, als ook innovatieve strategien. Ook zullen door training op basic hygiene en nutrition, zullen huishoudens betere beslissingen kunnen nemen. - 80 overheidsfunctionarissen - 6.353 jongeren en vrouwen - 80 gemeenschappen

description: The Foundations for Peace (FFP) programme aims to increase stability by bridging divisions between communities, as well as those within them. Conflict prevention & resolution (applicable both for inter and intra-communal conflicts) is increased by means of capacity strengthening of civil society and by bringing about a structural improvement of the economic and societal position of two important groups, most at risk of structural poverty and rights-abuse: women and youth.

title: Burundi programme 2014
description: In 2014, NIMD and its local partner organization the Burundi Leadership Training Programme (BLTP) will continue its EU-funded programme with the political parties to develop party programme positions on key thematic issues. The aim is to contribute to the unblocking of the political stalemate in Burundi. A follow-up to this programme that aims to continue and deepen the work with the parties on manifesto development is being explored. NIMD is further planning to start a programme focussed on technical capacity training for parties in the run-up to the elections. Based on a request from the political parties, NIMD is also starting activities with representatives of the youth wings of political parties. The aim is to improve relations in order to decrease tensions between the youth wings and contribute to more constructive youth participation in political parties and the political and electoral process. This will be closely linked to the UN-led process of party dialogue. At the local level NIMD wants to expand its Schools for Democracy to six provinces, with a thematic focus on how communities can deal with security and development issues. This will be done by actively involving the community police in the training programme. Finally, next year NIMD will focus on strengthening the capacity of its local partner to ensure that the diverse portfolio of activities can be implemented.
funding_organisations: ;The Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs;European Union Instrument for Stability

title: Improving the physical and mental health, promoting social inclusion and increasing the household income of carers of mentally ill individuals in Nepal
description: Based in Baglung and Myagdi districts in the Western region of Nepal, the project will work with 1500 unpaid family carers of individuals with mental illness. As a result of the project: - medical and counselling facilities for carers will be strengthened - 60 carers mutual support groups will be formed and operational - alternative care and respite arrangements for carers will be set up and working - carers will have access to livelihoods and skills training opportunities - support will be in place to enable child carers to attend school regularly - capacity of the partner organisation in Nepal, local government staff, community volunteers and carers will be strengthened to promote needs of carers and advocate for policy change

title: Discovery Project
description: The Discovery Project is a unique public-private partnership between Discovery Communications and the UK Department for International Development (DFID) to improve education opportunities for marginalized girls, and boys, in Sub-Saharan Africa. The initiative furthers Discovery\'s commitment to advancing global education through its implementing partner, the Discovery Learning Alliance. The Discovery Project is empowering teachers and families of marginalized children to raise the quality of education and prioritize access for all children. The Discovery Project advances education through: â€¢ Improving student outcomes in literacy and numeracy (impacting 126,000 students). â€¢ Improving the quality of education through media in the classroom and teacher professional development (reaching 11,900 teachers and 841,000 students in 1,500 schools). â€¢ Community training and engagement activities designed to address gender marginalization, including the formation of clubs to connect out-of-school youth with educational opportunities where they are and support access to education. â€¢ National talk shows that will use an entertaining medium to shift knowledge, attitudes and practices around education, (broadcast to over 10,000,000 people). Using a cost-effective, research-based approach and technology-driven development that is scalable, sustainable and proven to help attain educational goals, the Discovery Project will get more girls and boys in school, keep them in school and make sure they are learning when they get there. About Discovery Learning Alliance Discovery Learning Alliance is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization using the power of media to transform education and improve lives in under-resourced schools and communities around the world. Launched by Discovery Communications in 1997, we are opening new doors to learning in 16 countries reaching millions through schools and millions more through broadcast television and mass media initiatives in the developing world. Leveraging Discoveryâ€™s world-class programming and education expertise, Discovery Learning Alliance extends Discovery Communicationsâ€™ mission to help people satisfy their curiosity.

Skills Building for Empowerment and Self-reliance Among Out of School Adolescent Girls in Northern Uganda and South Sudan (SHONGLAP)
description: The Shonglap project empowers adolescent girls (13 to 19 years) who dropped out of school or never had a chance to go to school .The project aims to reduce the vulnerability of 6,750 adolescent girls in highly impoverished areas of South Sudan and Northern Uganda through training in life and occupational skills, through a dialogue-based empowerment process involving both the girls and their environment (community, parents and authorities). The project combats violence against girls, illiteracy, vulnerability to diseases, early marriages and pregnancies, while promoting economic independence and community participation

description: People affected by leprosy and disabilities often suffer from various kinds of wounds, which can result in medical complications. This can to disabilities. This project will support the creation and functioning of Self-Care Groups (SCGs). People will learn in these groups to take care of their wounds and improve their social and economic skills.;The objectives are - to create 30 new SCGs; - to support 30 exciting SCGs; - to provide relevant medical treatment for app. 100 people.;The target group in this project is people affected by leprosy and persons with disabilities.
recipient-country: Two provinces were targeted: Nampula and Niassa.
sector-text: SCGs are partly supported on health education. Also relevant social-economic support is provided.

title: Equal Access to Education for Nomadic Populations in Northern Afghanistan
description: This project funded by the UK Department for International Development through its Girlsâ€™ Education Challenge initiative (GEC) and implemented by ChildFund Afghanistan aims to â€œimprove the life chances of marginalized girlsâ€ù by increasing their access to schools and improving their learning outcomes. This project will provide 1,200 marginalised girls (and 800 boys) from the Nomadic population in northern Afghanistan to complete a full cycle of lower primary education without abandoning the traditional Nomadic lifestyle. The project will place special emphasis to ensure that classes, qualified teachers and a supportive community enable and equip at least 900 young girls to be able to complete one full cycle of lower primary education and demonstrate learning. The project aims to increase enrolment, attendance and learning enabling the girls to complete a full cycle of schooling through a flexible system of community based classes established with the support of the community in summer sites, while utilizing existing school facilities to the extent possible in winter sites. In addition, the project will create peer-learning groups (where children will learn both independently and from one another), and collaborate with â€œEducation Shurasâ€ù to support the girlsâ€™ education. The project creates several conditionsâ€”a mentored and supported teaching cadre, community based education to suit the Nomadic life style, supportive families, including strong collaboration and alignment with the Department of Education.

title: Technical Assistance Facility
description: The Technical Assistance Facility (TAF) is a pool of funding within the PIDG Trust to assist PIDG companies to support capacity building and to help scope out potential investment opportunities. TAF achieves its goals by helping PIDG companies and clients to evaluate, develop and/or implement risk mitigation, financial and regulatory mechanisms, standards, systems and procedures essential to raising funds in the capital markets. This enables developing countries to make a strong and positive contribution to growth and poverty reduction. Through the issuance of technical assistance grants, and through the provision of advisors, training, secondments and workshops, TAF provides mechanisms for delivering short-term and medium-term projects of technical assistance and capacity building. TAF is also able to provide VGF support, which is designed to make projects that are economically viable over the long term, commercially viable for investors Equipment and other capital expenditures are not normally eligible for support under TAF. TAF supports activities and interventions mainly in the public sector, but is also able to support private sector activities where inputs relate to achieving TAF objectives;3.1 The overall purpose of the TAF is to support the objectives of the PIDG and the PIDG Facilities by enhancing the ability of public and private sector clients to attract private capital to the financing of infrastructure and related services, thus enabling developing countries to make a strong and positive contribution to growth and poverty reduction. 3.2 The key specific objectives of the TAF is to: a. Build capacity in both the public and private sector in order to facilitate the aims of the PIDG. b. Facilitate private investment and mobilise additional resources directed towards the implementation of initiatives sponsored by the PIDG Facilities. c. Promote better co-ordination in the delivery of technical assistance associated with projects sponsored by the PIDG Facilities. d. Enhance inclusion and other social development opportunities associated with projects supported by the PIDG Facilities. e. Provide post-transaction support for projects supported by the PIDG Facilities. f. Strengthen environmental sustainability of PIDG supported projects. g. Promote development or improvement of capital market systems in selected countries or regions. h. Facilitate affordability by the poor of infrastructure services provided on a commercially viable basis.

title: The Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund Ltd
description: The Emerging Africa Infrastructure Fund Ltd. (EAIF) is a Public Private Partnership able to provide long-term debt or mezzanine finance on commercial terms to finance the construction and development of private sector infrastructure projects. EAIF was set up in 2001 as the first multi-donor PIDG facility, and is the first dedicated debt fund able to operate across sub-Saharan Africa (except Mauritius). EAIF aims to address the market gap created by the high-interest short-term loans provided by commercial banks in the region, which are typically inappropriate for infrastructure financing. While EAIF lends on commercial terms, it aims to support projects that promote economic growth and reduce poverty, benefit broad population groups, address issues of equity and participation, and promote social and cultural rights.;The objective of EAIF is to increase the volume of private sector flows to infrastructure projects with private sector participation in Sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Green Africa Power LLP
description: Green Africa Power (GAP) has been set up to stimulate private investment in renewable energy in Africa by acting as a long term source of financing and policy support to projects. GAP is a multi-donor Facility formed after a scoping exercise funded by the UK Department for International Development (DFID) and the Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (Norad) concluded that there was definite potential for a fund to address key market failures and stimulate private sector investment in renewable energy in Africa. Africa is the worldâ€™s most power-starved region, with more than 700 million people lacking access to electricity. There is a shortage of all types of power generation projects in Africa, but particularly renewable power projects. GAP has been designed to counter the pronounced market failures inhibiting the growth of renewables in the region by reducing the upfront cost of capital while maintaining overall commercial returns, providing cover for specific construction phase risks, and facilitating policy dialogue to move towards cost reflective tariffs.;GAP has the ambitious target to finance approximately 270MW of new renewable energy generation capacity in four years, saving 3.9m tonnes of carbon emissions and improving the supply of clean energy to millions of people in Africa.
funding_organisations: ;Royal Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA);UK Department of Energy & Climate Change (DECC) (through DFID);UK - Department for International Development (DFID)
sector-text: Including: (i) Start-ups or Greenfield Developments: investments in Renewable Energy Projects that have received (or will have received prior to disbursement) the relevant permits, licences and concessions from governmental entities; (ii) Operating Renewable Energy Projects: Renewable Energy Projects that are in operation but require finance for upgrades, expansions or other forms of growth; (iii) Other Operating Projects: conversion or expansion of existing power projects to the extent that such conversion or expansion is based on Renewable Energy. (iv) Associated grid connection infrastructure: where this is a link of limited length that is an integrated part of a Renewable Energy Project as defined at (i) to (iii) above connecting the project to the local distribution or national transmission system

title: GuarantCo Ltd
description: GuarantCo provides guarantees to lenders to support local currency finance for infrastructure projects in low-income countries, promoting domestic infrastructure financing and capital market development. GuarantCo offers partial guarantees which serve as credit enhancements to facilitate local debt instruments. Well functioning capital markets are vital to facilitate private sector investment, and to deliver necessary infrastructure projects that improve service coverage and quality. Capacity building in local markets will enable projects to eventually be refinanced with reduced support from GuarantCo.;GuarantCo's two key objectives are to encourage domestic financing of infrastructure services and to promote local capital market development.

title: Girl Power Sierra Leone
description: Build capacity in local civil society, to support the empowerment of girls and young women for gender equality ;1) Promote child rights for 6,000 teenage girls in selected communities in Kaiyamba, Dasse, Fakunya, Bumpeh, Bagruwa, and Lower Banta in Moyamba and Western Area. 2) Reduce child rights violations by strengthening reporting and response mechanisms in Moyamba District and Western Area. 3) Organize and support Civil Society Organizations and networks to undertake joint child protection initiatives in Project District. 4) Promote the development of effective child protection systems with capable institutions and adequate procedures for identification, reporting, referral, investigation, treatment and follow-up 5) Strengthen the capacity of relevant duty bearers to effectively conduct their roles in promoting child rights and protecting children.

Improving clinical outcomes for 10,000 burn patients in Bangladesh and Nepal by implementing improved standards of burn care
description: Interburns has developed the first set of operational standards for burns services in Low and Middle Income Countries, guidelines that define the staff skills and knowledge, equipment and operational capabilities required to achieve good outcomes for burn patients, despite limited resources. This project will pilot the standards in Bangladesh and Nepal, using training and education programmes to drive improvements in burn care in 14 selected burn services across both countries, ranging from small rural units to national burn centres in Dhaka and Kathmandu. The project will address a target population of more than 10,000 burn patients - the majority children and young women - improving the quality of care they receive and reducing the massive burden of preventable suffering, death and disability from burn injuries in Bangladesh and Nepal.
implementing_organisations: ;Acid Survivors Foundation, Bangladesh;Nepal Burn Society, Nepal

title: Improving maternal health and infant survival rates in Pakistan
description: This project aims to improve maternal health and infant survival rates for rural communities in Pakistan by (1) Improving access to antenatal and post-natal care and delivery services for pregnant women and (2) Fostering improved health and hygiene practices amongst amongst community members that affect women and girls. These outcomes will be achieved through the development of the following outputs: 1. Establishing Women\'s Health Committees in each rural village to coordinate health education initiatives and ensure access to community midwifery services for the most marginalised women; 2. Providing health education programmes to raise awareness and change behaviour in health and hygiene practices amongst women and girls. 3. Establishing a network of trained community midwives to provide antenatal and post-natal care and delivery services for pregnant women. 4. Building the capacity of communities to advocate for improved health services, particularly for mother and child health.

title: Delivering transformational teacher training to support the introduction of active and play-based learning, to achieve enhanced educational outcomes for early primary school children in Ghana.
description: This 3 year project will transform the way kindergarten teachers are trained in Ghana, by creating 34 model practice classrooms around Holy Child College of Education. Each of the 34 classrooms will be staffed by a mentor teacher and will offer improved practical placements to 2 student teachers. 187 teachers will receive intensive training, promoting active and play-based learning. As a result, at least 4,760 children will receive a higher quality start to their education, with proven later life benefits.

title: Integrating Education Health and Income generation services for 14,000 school students, their mothers and families, in Pakistan.
description: This is a synergistic project, connecting three ongoing initiatives related to Sexual and Reproductive Health education, services and improving livelihoods. Using the platform of schools, the project will reach out to adolescents, their mothers and families in ten districts of Pakistan, to increase knowledge and access to nutrition and Sexual and Reproductive Health services, improve health and education outcomes, as well as to empower women and benefit deserving families through enhancement of their employment skills and provision of micro-credit facilities for income generation.

title: Drought and Food Insecurity in East Africa
description: This project has been designed to provide emergency life saving services to drought affected people in the target areas. Provision of emergency food and WASH services will help fight against drought. The distribution of food packs will help improve the nutritional situation of the people due to lack of food and unbalanced diet. The distribution of srinking water will help to access clean water drinking water for themselves and their livestock and reduce vulnerability. We particularly selected to response to this crisis so that we can tackle and help before the situation gets out of hand to emergency of level 4. ;The objective is to provide emergency life saving services to drought affected people in the target areas of Somalia
